controls imposed on Russia and certain Russian companies, individuals, and allies as well as related
Russian countermeasures and countersanctions, have severely restricted the level of economic
activity in Russia and Ukraine, increased volatility and uncertainty in the global financial markets,
disrupted supply chains, resulted in price slumps for products, significant increases in the prices of
many raw materials and energy and adversely affected the operations of many of our customers. A
number of companies, including ourselves and a number of our customers, have announced plans to
divest interests or otherwise curtail business dealings in Russia and/or with Russian businesses, or
have been required to halt, reduce or delay production due to the unavailability of raw materials or
components, such as springs and friction linings, which adversely affects those customers’ demands
for our products. In addition, a lack of preliminary products from the Ukraine led to production
disruptions in Europe, particularly in Germany. The ramifications of the war in Ukraine and related
economic sanctions and export controls, may not be limited to Russia, Ukraine and Russian and
Ukrainian companies, and may also negatively impact other regional and global economic markets
(including Europe and the U.S.), companies in other countries (particularly those that were previously
doing business with Russia and Ukraine), various sectors, industries, securities markets and
commodities globally (such as oil, natural gas, engineering, and metals and mining), global supply
chains, inflation, growth in gross domestic product (“GDP”) and possibly lead to rationing of gas
supplies.

Further economic sanctions could also be imposed on countries, companies or persons that seek to,
or are perceived to, circumvent existing economic sanctions or provide military or other support to
Russia, which could further exacerbate these risks. In addition, Russia has taken and may take
additional retaliatory actions and other countermeasures, including restricting gas exports, seizure of
the assets of U.S. and European companies and persons located in Russia or territories under its
control, cyberattacks and espionage against other countries and companies, or undertaking or
provoking other military conflict elsewhere, any of which may negatively impact our customers and
the countries in which we operate. While we cannot currently reliably predict the direct or indirect
impact that the war in Ukraine or any related international economic sanctions may have on our
business, results of operations, cash flows and financial condition, we caution investors that they
could be material and adverse.

Also, in response to rising inflation and increased concerns with regards to an economic recession,
some governments have raised interest rates and/or curtailed quantitative easing policies and


-----

indicated their intention to continue to do so. The inflationary environment and resulting wage and
production cost pressure and price increases (in particular due to rising energy costs) combined with
rising interest rates, may lower purchasing power and result in declining customer demand, and
significantly impact our results of operations. A failure to accurately anticipate and factor rising
inflation into our product pricing assumptions may also result in mispricing of our products, which
could materially and adversely impact our results of operations. Rising interest rates are likely to
have a dampening effect on overall economic activity, the financial condition of our customers and
the financial condition of the end customers who ultimately create demand for the products we
supply, all of which could negatively affect demand for our products. Higher interest rates also
increase our financing costs, which may weaken demand and impact our ability to execute on our
growth strategies or future acquisitions or finance the increased costs.

China’s economic health, including its present debt situation and potential market disruptions due to
ongoing and iterative COVID-19 measures such as the lockdowns that continued into 2023, which
negatively affected demand in China and led to supply chain disruptions, potentially presents
additional economics and political uncertainty. Further, the current coalition government in Germany
has signaled a shift in foreign policy that could lead to increased trade tensions between Germany
and China, and though the United States and China reached a trade agreement, an escalation of
trade tensions between the United States and China or Germany and/or Europe and China, including
if China is, or is perceived to, provide support to Russia in the war in Ukraine or to circumvent
economic sanctions imposed against Russia and its allies, may result in further uncertainty in the
global economy and may jeopardize economic growth in China.

Additional risks to the economic environment, international trade and demand for our products
could also arise from rising protectionist tendencies, which could result in, inter alia, higher customs
charges. Increasing protectionism in trade policy or changes in the political and regulatory
environment in markets in which we do business can impact our net assets, financial position and
results of operations. Import/export control regulations, customs regulations and other trade
barriers can also bring sales in individual countries to a complete standstill. See also “—The
_imposition of tariffs or non-tariff trade barriers on automobiles and other goods could have a material_
_adverse effect on us.” These and other changes in trade policies could trigger additional retaliatory_
actions, resulting in “trade wars.”

There also continues to be uncertainty about a potential deterioration of the sovereign debt of
several Eurozone countries, particularly in the context of rising interest rates, which could also affect
more stable countries and adversely affect the stability of the Economic and Monetary Union.
Political developments and uncertainties in certain European countries, such as the election or
appointment of Eurosceptic governments, could further exacerbate these uncertainties.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_Prices of many of our raw materials and energy have increased significantly and may rise further,_**
**_which may lead to higher production and manufacturing costs._**

Our manufacturing processes consume significant amounts of raw materials and energy, the costs of
which are subject to worldwide supply and demand as well as other factors beyond our control. Steel
is the principal raw material used in many of our products. Price increases for raw materials, as well
as energy, whether as a result of inflation, shortages or interruptions in supply, or otherwise, may
affect the production and manufacturing costs of our products, and we may not be able to pass those
costs on to our customers. The prices of nearly all our significant input materials, including steel,
aluminum, copper and plastic as well as energy prices increased significantly in 2021 and 2022. For
example, the benchmark price for hot-rolled steel reached its all-time high in 2021, in Europe, natural


-----

gas prices reached historic highs in August 2022, natural gas and electricity saw annual average prices
of 136% in Europe and 75% in the U.S. in 2022 as compared to 2021.

In addition, the war in Ukraine and the related economic sanctions and export controls could
exacerbate the rising inflation trend, further increase energy and raw material prices and negatively
impact global supply chains. For example, as a result of the war in Ukraine, oil prices recently reached
multi-year highs with the average price of crude oil reaching prices approximately 42% higher than in
2021 and governments have considered restructuring their energy policies. For example, the U.S.
government has prohibited the import of Russian oil into the U.S., and both the U.S. and the EU have
imposed price caps on the purchase of certain Russian petroleum products. In the event that Russia
stops the export of energy sources to the EU or as a result of embargos on Russian energy sources,
emergency measures may be implemented to conserve energy, which could include shutting down
non-critical industries or rationing energy supply, and we could be required to reduce our energy
consumption by, for example, reducing or stopping production at one or more of our production
locations in the EU.

Freight and logistics costs have also grown significantly since 2020, due to a number of factors,
including persistent transport capacity shortages, imbalances in global trade and countries locking
down and reopening at different times due to varying patterns of COVID-19 outbreaks and the war in
Ukraine, which resulted in changes to our shipping routes between Europe and China, in order to
avoid transit through Russia. The difficult situation on the transport market has also impacted our net
working capital development. Longer transport times have caused an increase in goods in transit,
while specific shortages have also caused imbalances within our stock. In certain areas we have
intentionally increased stock to cover certain volatilities and secure supply, but this has been limited
by the material shortages.

In addition to fixing purchase prices for certain of our raw materials, such as steel, for six to twelve
months by entering into forward purchase contracts, we also entered into short-, medium-, and longterm price and supply agreements to mitigate the risk of rising energy prices arising on energy
purchases for our own use, because this risk increased in 2022 as compared to prior years. However,
there can be no assurance that energy price and supply agreements will continue to be available on
commercially reasonable terms or that it will be sufficient to address the increased levels of volatility.
In addition, early termination of energy price and supply agreements may trigger significant
termination fees, all of which may make the use of derivative financial instruments economically
unattractive, thereby exposing us to the risks of fluctuations in raw material prices. In addition, there
can be no assurance that our energy price and supply agreements, which themselves represent a
cost, will be adequate to cover the additional costs generated by potential future increases in energy
prices. Although energy price and supply agreements can offer protection against energy price
fluctuations for a limited period of time, they do not lessen the long-term effects of structural
worldwide energy price increases. Changes in the fair values of financial instruments we use to
mitigate the risk of rising energy prices, which depends on future market prices for electricity and
available electricity amounts and can be very volatile, can also have a significant negative impact on
our operating results.

Furthermore, increases in raw materials and energy prices could only be partially passed on to
customers during 2022, which adversely affected margins in 2022 and could have a material adverse
effect on our results of operations. Pricing dynamics differ among our Divisions and businesses, price
recovery is partial in most cases, and may at times be delayed. It is particularly difficult to pass price
increases onto the customers of our Automotive Technologies Division; direct negotiation with each
customer is necessary to change the terms of our customer contracts and the business is facing
considerable pricing pressure, driven by increasing customer demands for price reductions,
purchasing cooperatives, and certain focused and leaner competitors, especially in growth markets.
Even to the extent that we are successful in compensating for or passing on our increased costs to
our customers by increasing prices, the positive effects of such price increases may not occur in the


-----

periods in which the additional expenses have been incurred, but in later periods. In that event, the
price increases will not have a compensating effect for the periods in which the costs increased. If
costs of raw materials and energy continue to rise, and if we are not able to undertake cost-saving
measures elsewhere in our operations or increase the selling prices of our products, we will not be
able to compensate for such cost increases.

During periods of declining raw material or energy prices, customers may demand price reductions
for our products, despite the fact that we may be using existing inventories that were purchased at
higher prices. This could in turn have a negative effect on our profit margins, particularly if we enter
into forward purchase contracts with respect to such raw materials and, as a consequence, lower
market prices are reflected in our inventories on a delayed basis.

Any events leading to fluctuations in prices or scarcity of raw materials, energy and increased freight
and logistics costs could disrupt our operations, or could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_We are exposed to risks associated with market trends and technological developments, including_**
**_trends toward electric mobility and digitalization, and we may not be able to adapt sufficiently or_**
**_in a timely manner._**

Our future success depends on our ability to recognize market trends and technological changes and
to develop and bring to the market new and improved products in a timely manner. The markets for
the products offered by us are subject to significant technological change, continuously developing
technological standards, changing customer preferences, constantly emerging innovative products
and increasing numbers of new market entrants, particularly in the fields of electric mobility and
autonomous driving. The political and societal drive towards action against climate change and
increasing environmental regulation are key drivers for changes in customer demand and consumer
behavior. The automotive market, in particular, is characterized by progressive development towards
higher performance and simultaneously more fuel-efficient, less polluting and quieter engines,
electronic control and assistance systems, autonomous driving, connectivity, as well as towards
medium range cars and hybrid and electric vehicles. The emergence of hybrid, electric and hydrogen
powertrains represents a fundamental change to established vehicle technology. Existing
technologies and products may be entirely replaced by newly developed and marketed technologies
and newly introduced products, putting further development of the conventional powertrain under
pressure.

Trends in automotive technology such as electrification and the increase in automated transmissions
are expected to have an impact on our future product portfolio. As electrification of automobiles is
progressing, the further development of conventional powertrains has come under pressure, driven
in particular by increasing regulatory constraints related to CO2 emissions. For example, EU
Regulation 2019/631 provides for stricter CO2 emissions targets, which require EU fleet-wide CO2
emissions from passenger cars to be 37.5% lower than the 2021 level beginning in 2030. In February
2023, the EU Parliament adopted the EU Commission’s July 14, 2021 proposal to amend Regulation
2019/631, which aims to accelerate the transition to low- and zero emission vehicles by requiring
average CO2 emissions of new passenger cars and light commercial vehicles to be reduced by 55% by
2023 and 100% by 2035, each as compared to 2021 levels. This would mean that all new vehicles
registered on or after January 1, 2035 would be required to have zero CO2 emissions. In addition, on
February 14, 2022, the EU Commission proposed amending Regulation 2019/1242 to strengthen CO2
emission performance standards for new heavy duty vehicles by requiring average CO2 emissions of
most new heavy duty vehicles to be reduced by 45% by 2030, 65% by 2035 and 90% by 2040, each as
compared to 2019 levels, as well as requiring that all new city buses have zero CO2 emissions as of
2030. See also “—Legal, Regulatory and Tax Risks—We could become subject to additional
_burdensome environmental, safety or other regulations and additional regulation could adversely_
_affect demand for our products and services.” We need to have a competitive cost structure in order_


-----

to further accelerate the transformation process and ensure that we are fully geared for powertrain
electrification and that, in turn, requires us to reduce our cost base and production overcapacity for
conventional powertrains. Improvements to conventional powertrains may become less relevant and
existing products and applications may be replaced. If alternative powertrains, such as electric
vehicles, were to gain further market share sooner than currently expected, such new powertrains
may not require our products or may make use of our products to a lesser extent than conventional
powertrains, which could result in us losing market share and result in us initiating additional cost
saving measures.

Digitalization is progressing rapidly and has already completely transformed certain sectors. The pace
of implementation and adaptation represents an important success factor in this regard and,
therefore, also a risk. For example, in the wind sector, technological developments in wind power
gear boxes could lead to an increasing shift away from conventional rolling bearing solutions and
result in a decrease in demand for our products.

Should we fail to develop appropriate strategies as a response to the market trends described above
or similar market trends, growth opportunities could be lost or we could lose existing customers.

There can be no assurance that (i) we will be successful in developing new products or systems or in
bringing them to market in a timely manner, or at all, (ii) products or technologies developed by
others will not render our offerings obsolete or non-competitive, (iii) our customers will not
substitute our products with competing products or alternate technology, (iv) the market will accept
our innovations, (v) our competitors will not be able to produce our non-patented products more
cheaply, or (vi) we will be able to adjust our cost structure in the event of contraction of demand.

Should we fail to develop appropriate strategies as a response to these or other market trends and to
enhance existing products, develop new products or keep pace with developing market trends or
technology, growth opportunities could be lost or we could lose existing customers.

If we devote resources to the pursuit of new technologies and products that fail to be accepted in the
marketplace or that fail to be commercially viable, all or part of these research and development
(“R&D”) expenses may be lost and our business may suffer. Our revenues from business related to
electromobility, in particular, are heavily concentrated on individual customer projects and, as a
result, are more dependent on the market success of those customer projects. As no standards have
been established for electric mobility to date, our customers continue to develop a variety of
technological solutions and we devote resources to develop novel solutions and products specific to
those technological solutions. If one or more of those technological solutions fail to be accepted in
the marketplace or fail to be commercially viable, or if a customer project is stopped before the
anticipated end of the project, or after volume production commenced or realized volumes are lower
than originally anticipated, it may result in the impairment of assets before they are fully amortized
and our business may suffer. In addition, the development and range of assistance systems up to
fully automated vehicles and the introduction of so-called “people movers” are accelerating. If the
realization does not correspond to the assumed development, this can impact our financial, asset
and earnings situation. The assumptions of this development are subject to an ongoing strategic
review. See also “—We may not be able to obtain the funding required for our R&D activities and
_these activities may not lead to the development of commercially successful products.”_

In addition, we currently rely on a high degree of vertical integration and comprehensive production
expertise to facilitate improvements in the production process and ultimately safeguard our ability to
maintain our margins. The evolution of our business from being component-driven toward being
more systems-based is ongoing, and, because these systems may employ a greater proportion of
components not manufactured by us, but purchased from other suppliers, this change could reduce
the proportion of value added by us.


-----

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_The imposition of tariffs or non-tariff trade barriers on automobiles and other goods could have a_**
**_material adverse effect on us._**

Beginning in 2018, the United States announced a series of potential measures relating to
international trade, which individually or in the aggregate could have a material adverse impact on
the global economy, international trade or the automotive industry. In January 2018, the U.S. began
to impose tariffs on certain products, which were later expanded to include a 25% tariff on imports of
steel, a 10% tariff on imports of aluminum in June 2018, and then to products containing a high
proportion of these metals, such as nails, cables, and certain automotive parts in January 2020. In
2021, the United States reached agreements with the EU and Japan to eliminate or lower these
tariffs, but they remain in effect for other countries (including, for example, China). The U.S. also
negotiated a replacement of the North American Free Trade Agreement in October 2018. On July 1,
2020, the new United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement entered into force, and includes more
stringent rule of origin provisions requiring automobiles to have 75% of their components
manufactured in Mexico, the U.S., or Canada to qualify for zero tariffs (previously 62.5%) and
requiring a minimum percentage of manufacturing to be produced with labor earning above a certain
minimum wage. We have operations in Mexico and Canada and the imposition of additional import
restrictions, non-tariff trade barriers or tariffs could adversely affect our ability to supply customers
in the U.S. In addition, new import restrictions, non-tariff trade barriers and/or tariffs could result in
higher prices for light duty and heavy duty vehicles, which could in turn have a negative impact on
the demand for our products. In addition, our results of operations could also be affected by
retaliatory measures from Europe, China or other countries imposing tariffs on the U.S.

In February 2019, the U.S. Department of Commerce determined the import of automobiles,
uranium, and titanium sponge threaten to impair national security, but has not imposed tariffs or
quotas on those imports to date. This could however result in the imposition of additional duties on
imports of vehicles into the U.S. in the future. Such import tariffs, if imposed, could have a material
adverse effect on the demand for non-U.S. light duty vehicles in the U.S. Through our European
operations, we, directly and indirectly, supply a number of original equipment manufacturers
(“OEM”) that currently export a large number of light duty vehicles into the U.S. market. A significant
decrease in demand for these cars in the U.S. market would therefore materially and adversely affect
demand for our products. Any such decrease in demand could have a material and adverse effect on
our business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations, which could in turn
adversely affect our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes or cause the market price of the
Notes to decline.

Higher tariffs or the imposition of new tariffs, could materially and adversely affect complex supply
chains in the automotive industry. The automotive industry supply chain has developed over decades
and relies on existing trade arrangements to provide for cross-border supplies of raw materials,
automotive parts and other components. The impact of terminating existing trade arrangements
could be materially disruptive to the supply chains resulting in immediate shortages of critical parts
and components necessary to manufacture automobiles and other vehicles. This could have a
material adverse effect on the automotive industry as a whole and our business in particular.

**_We operate in industries that are cyclical and affected by numerous trends and developments,_**
**_which makes it hard to correctly forecast demand for our products._**

As a global automotive and industrial supplier, the demand for our products is largely determined by
the global economic environment. Demand for our products depends to a significant extent on
overall economic developments. In addition, demand is subject to cyclical fluctuations.


-----

Our business is very capital intensive and characterized by high fixed costs. On the one hand, we risk
underutilization of our facilities if the markets in which we operate decline, which has occurred most
recently in the course of the COVID-19 pandemic and in the course of the war in Ukraine.
Underutilization of our facilities could result in idle capacity costs, write-offs of inventories, losses on
products due to falling average sale prices. Furthermore, falling production volumes cause declines in
revenues and earnings.

On the other hand, we risk having insufficient capacity to meet customer demand if the markets in
which we operate grow faster than anticipated and thus may lose market share. Fluctuations in
demand also make it difficult for us to predict our working capital requirements, which could
adversely affect our cash flows and liquidity. Regional shifts in demand could also require us to
relocate production facilities, which could result in disruptions in production, higher cost or capital
expenditure requirements, or require us to record impairment charges.

Sales of our Automotive Technologies Division, which accounted for 60.1% of our consolidated
revenue in 2022, are cyclical and depend, among other things, on global vehicle production volumes,
general economic conditions, such as supply chain stability and freight and logistics costs, and
consumer spending and preferences, which can be affected by a number of factors, including
employment, consumer confidence and income, energy costs and fuel prices, interest rate levels,
inflation and the availability of consumer financing. Given the variety of such economic parameters
influencing the global automotive demand, the volume of automotive production has historically
been, and will continue to be, characterized by a high level of fluctuation, making it difficult for us to
accurately predict demand levels for our products aimed at the automotive sector. Demand for
automotive products can also be affected by various other factors. For example, the global
semiconductor shortage significantly impaired automobile production, particularly in the second half
of 2021 and in 2022, which has also had a significant negative impact on demand for our products.
The war in Ukraine could also further negatively impact the supply of certain critical materials and
metals, such as neon gas and palladium, which are used in semiconductor manufacturing and for
which a significant portion of global production comes from Russia and, in the case of neon gas,
Ukraine, and platinum and other metals used in automobile production, which could again impair
automobile production and have a significant impact on demand for our products. In addition,
purchase incentives and the expansion of the charging infrastructure can contribute to increased
demand for products for hybrid and electric powertrains, which may contain a smaller percentage of
our products, thereby significantly impacting demand for our products. Demand for our automotive
products can also be affected by regulatory developments or investigations affecting our customers.
For example, in recent years, authorities in the United States and Europe determined that certain
OEMs intentionally programmed automobiles with diesel engines to restrict emissions during testing
to pass applicable requirements. A number of OEMs have been subject to negative press coverage
and/or criminal investigations and/or civil actions in multiple jurisdictions, in some cases leading to
product recalls and substantial fines. In response, regulators in California have implemented new
testing and inspection regulations for diesel vehicles which will take full effect in 2024. Other U.S.
regulators have indicated more stringent testing standards for diesel vehicles may be developed as
well, alongside increased emissions standards for diesel vehicles already imposed by California and
other states. See “—Legal, Regulatory and Tax Risks—We could become subject to additional
_burdensome environmental, safety or other regulations and additional regulation could adversely_
_affect demand for our products and services.” Additionally, certain groups and initiatives have_
announced voluntary or local-level restrictions on the use of diesel vehicles, even if they are
compliant with applicable standards, including the mayors of Paris, Mexico City, London, Madrid and
Athens. In China, limited access to vehicle registration is used to slow the increase in traffic and
related pollution. If, as a result of these investigations, actions and increased scrutiny regarding diesel
vehicles, our significant OEM customers curtail, or discontinue, their production of diesel vehicles
that incorporate our products, the sales of our Automotive Technologies Division could be adversely
affected.


-----

In addition, OEM customers generally do not commit to purchasing minimum quantities from their
suppliers. Inability to correctly forecast demand for our automotive products could lead to
underutilization of our facilities or insufficient capacity to meet customer demand. Attempts to react
to such inaccurate forecasts by increasing or reducing our capacity at short notice may cause us to
incur additional costs (e.g., severance payments or overtime surcharges).

Sales of our Automotive Aftermarket Division, which accounted for 12.9% of our consolidated
revenue in 2022, depend, among other things, on general economic conditions as well as on
consumer spending and preferences, available innovations in products and technologies, on
complexity, growth and average age of global vehicle population as well as on average usage and
lifetime of parts before a replacement is required. Inability to correctly forecast demand for our
aftermarket products could lead to underutilization of our facilities or insufficient capacity to meet
customer demand.

Sales of our Industrial Division, which accounted for 27.0% of our consolidated revenue in 2022,
depend on the development of global industrial production, especially in the mechanical engineering,
transportation means and electrical equipment sectors. Due to the high diversification within the
Division, various factors, such as fiscal policies, infrastructure programs or consumer behavior and
customer loyalty in general, in certain countries or in certain industry sectors, influence demand for
our products. The variety of factors makes it difficult for us to estimate requirements for production
capacity and to reliably forecast future working capital requirements. Inability to correctly forecast
demand for our industrial products could lead to underutilization of our facilities or insufficient
capacity to meet customer demand.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_Our business environment is characterized by intense competition, which could reduce our revenues_**
**_or put continued pressure on our sales prices._**

The markets in which we operate are highly competitive, technologically fast-paced and have been
characterized by changes in market penetration, increased price competition as well as the
development and introduction of new products, product designs and technologies by significant
existing and new competitors. We compete primarily on the basis of price, quality, timeliness of
delivery and design as well as the ability to provide engineering support, repair know-how and
service on a global basis. Some OEMs have begun to reduce the number of vendors in their supply
base in an effort to simplify their value chain and focus on their relationships with a limited number
of vendors. Should we fail to secure the quality of our products and the reliability of our supply and
service in the future, our customers could decide to procure products from our competitors, which
could lead to a loss in our market share.

The automotive supply industry has been characterized by significant investments, rapid
technological change, for example, in electric mobility and autonomous driving, particularly in the
Greater China region, continuous advancements in process technologies and manufacturing facilities,
intense pricing pressure from major OEM customers and periods of oversupply. In addition, new
customers could enter the market with whom we do not have any existing or extensive customer
relationship and the market share of automobile manufactures that do not use or that use a below
average amount of our products per vehicle could increase. We compete with other international
suppliers and, to a lesser extent, regional companies and new market entrant suppliers, particularly
in the fields of electric mobility and autonomous driving. The end customers for our products are
increasingly affected by innovation and cost-cutting pressures from competitors and seek price
reductions in both the initial bidding process and during the term, or upon expiration, of an existing
contract. In particular, vehicle manufacturers expect lower prices from suppliers for the same, and in
some cases even enhanced functionality, as well as a consistently high product quality. We may not


-----

be able to pass some or all of these demands for extensive price reductions on to our own suppliers.
If we are unable to offset price reductions through improved operating efficiencies and the
realization of synergies, price reductions could impact our profit margins.

Our industrial business is also increasingly faced with competitors from growth economies that are
exerting pressure on market prices, considerably so in some cases. In certain industries, customers
increasingly prefer standardized products over customer-specific developments, and this trend
benefits competitors from growth economies as well, which could lead to a loss in our market share.
In addition, some of the industries and markets in which we are active, particularly the Automotive
Aftermarket business, are characterized by consolidation among competitors. Any future
consolidation among our competitors could allow them to benefit from economies of scale, offer
more comprehensive product portfolios, and increase the size of their serviceable markets. This
could require us to accept reductions in our profit margins and the loss of market share due to price
pressure.

Our profit margins have decreased in recent years as a result of our expanded systems business,
which tends to have lower profit margins because the systems we produce include a number of parts
that we purchase from other suppliers, and also because of lower profitability in the component
business, which may continue in the future because of price pressure by customers and overcapacity
at suppliers.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_We depend on a limited number of large OEMs and Tier 1 suppliers for the sale of a substantial_**
**_portion of our products and adverse developments relating to these customers could also adversely_**
**_affect our own business._**

In 2022, we generated revenue of €1,377 million from one key customer, representing 8.7% of our
total revenue and 14.0% of the revenue of the Automotive Technologies Division. In the Automotive
Technologies Division, the ten largest customers accounted for approximately 64.8% of the Division’s
total revenue in 2022. Many of our customers are large OEMs and Tier 1 suppliers (i.e., suppliers that
sell their products directly to OEMs). A number of factors, including loss of market share by these
customers, termination of supply agreements and/or the failure to renegotiate new agreements or
new terms, loss of contracts, reduced or delayed customer requirements, bankruptcy or insolvency
of a customer, plant shutdowns, strikes or other work stoppages, and changed regulatory
requirements, affecting production by such customers could cause a loss of all or a substantial
portion of sales to any of our major customers. For example, the COVID-19 pandemic caused
decreases in consumer demand, extended work stoppages and travel restrictions at our facilities and
those of our customers and suppliers, and delays and disruptions in vehicle production schedules,
and other adverse global economic impacts and adversely impacted and may continue to adversely
impact our customers’ and our business and operations. In addition, as a result of the war in Ukraine,
some of our customers have ceased operations and sales in Russia and more of our customers may
also cease operations and sales in Russia or other countries that provide military or material support
to Russia, which has adversely impacted and may continue to adversely impact vehicle production
and demand for our products. Furthermore, any reputational damage incurred by such customers
(e.g., due to compliance violations, product defects) could also damage our reputation, even if the
actual facts and parts in question are completely unrelated to us.

Furthermore, our customers may consolidate or merge from time to time. Consolidation among our
customers could result in an increasingly concentrated client base of large customers which could,
among others, increase the bargaining power of our current and future customers. In the course of a
merger or proposed merger, disclosure and sharing of pricing information and consolidation of
purchasing volumes provides transparency regarding pricing and cost structures, and could lead to


-----

increased pricing pressure. Mergers of our customers with entities that are not our customers could
also materially impact our financial position and results of operations if the resulting entity is no
longer our customer. For example, in 2021, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles and Peugeot S.A. merged to
form Stellantis N.V. and we are currently negotiating a new relationship with Stellantis N.V., which
could result in contractual terms less favorable to us than our prior separate contracts with Fiat
Chrysler Automobiles and Peugeot S.A.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_The significant bargaining power of our major customers may adversely affect our profit margins._**

Our major customers have substantial bargaining power with respect to price and other commercial
terms. Most OEM customers, for example, have recurring price-reduction initiatives and objectives
with their suppliers. Our customers’ demand for price reductions drives us to constantly improve our
production process in order to reduce costs. If we are not successful in these improvements, our
profit margins may be adversely affected. In addition, if any of our major customers discontinue their
business relationship with us or terminate a supply contract prematurely, the original investments
made by us to provide products to this customer could be wholly or partially lost.

The timing and amount of sales to our major customers ultimately depend on factors that are beyond
our control (such as, sales levels and shipping schedules for the customer products into which our
products are incorporated). We cannot be certain that our customers will continue to manufacture
products that incorporate our products at current levels or at all. Failure of our customers to achieve
significant sales of products incorporating our products and fluctuations in the timing and volume of
such product sales could adversely affect our business. Furthermore, failure by these customers to
inform us of changes to their production needs in a timely manner could also impede our ability to
effectively manage our business. The effect on our business would be particularly acute if a number
of customer relationships were terminated or the number of products we deliver under such
relationships were substantially reduced within a short period of time.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_We could be adversely affected by our customers defaulting on payments._**

In addition to the impact that production cuts and permanent capacity reductions by OEM customers
may have on our business and results of operations, the financial condition of these customers can
also affect our own financial condition. In the past, OEM customers and other customers have
suffered from declines in sales and production, tightened liquidity and increased cost of capital,
which, together with structural issues specific to these companies (such as significant overcapacity
and pension and healthcare costs), have caused many of these companies to undergo unprecedented
restructurings, including reorganizations under bankruptcy laws.

If the creditworthiness of our OEM customers or other customers were to decline, we would face an
increased default risk with respect to our trade receivables. There can be no assurance that any
financial arrangements provided to these companies, or even a successful reorganization of such
companies through bankruptcy, will guarantee their continued viability. Such risks are insured at
levels considered economically reasonable and on standard market terms by us, but we do not carry
insurance on all of our receivables and our insurance coverage could prove insufficient. If certain of
our OEM customers are unable to make payments for products that we have already delivered, we
may not be able to recover those receivables. In addition, if any of our customers becomes insolvent,
the original investments made by us to provide products to this customer could be wholly or partially
lost. This customer default risk has increased due to COVID-19 and trade restrictions.


-----

Payment defaults by customers could have a material adverse effect on our business, net assets,
financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_Longer product lives of OEM parts could adversely affect aftermarket demand for some of our_**
**_products._**

The average useful life of parts, particularly in the end products of OEMs, has increased in recent
years due to innovations in products and technologies. Longer product lives generally lead to lessfrequent replacement of parts over the lifespan of the equipment, leading in turn to decreased
aftermarket sales of the relevant products. This dynamic has adversely affected our aftermarket sales
in the past and could do so in the future. Further increases in average useful lives of parts could also
further adversely affect aftermarket demand for certain of our products.

Lower demand for our products due to longer product lives of OEM parts could have a material
adverse effect on our aftermarket revenue and, accordingly, our business, net assets, financial
condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_Climate change and related regulatory responses may adversely impact our business._**

There is increasing concern that a gradual increase in global average temperatures due to increased
concentrations of CO2 and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere will cause significant changes
in weather patterns around the globe and an increase in the frequency and severity of natural
disasters. Changes in weather patterns, including prolonged droughts, and an increased frequency,
intensity and duration of extreme weather conditions could, among other things, disrupt the
operation of our production sites and supply chain, increase our product costs and impact demand
for our products. For example, water is an essential component of our production operations.
Limitations or restrictions on our ability to secure sufficient amounts of water (including limitations
from natural causes such as drought) could impact our operations and could require us to make
significant investments or move to different locations. In certain areas with higher water risks, we
may be required to make significant investments to reduce the use of fresh water in our operations
or to implement technologies for water treatment or rainwater capture. As a result, the effects of
climate change could have a long-term adverse impact on our business, financial condition, results of
operations and prospects.

In many of the countries in which we operate, governmental bodies are increasingly enacting
legislation and regulations in response to the potential impacts of climate change as well as specific
levies related directly to energy consumption (such as taxes on CO2 emissions), which are expected to
increase in the future. These laws and regulations have the potential to impact our operations
directly or indirectly as a result of any required compliance by us, as well as by our suppliers,
wholesale partners and distributors. In addition, our manufacturing processes have been and may be
affected by new regulations in response to climate change. If we are perceived to be a significant
contributor of greenhouse gas emissions or global warming, or if we are perceived as not taking
appropriate steps to mitigate our effect on the environment, this could result in damage to our
reputation. Any of these events could have a material adverse effect our business, net assets,
financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

In addition, we have and expect to continue to take voluntary steps to mitigate our impact on climate
change. As a result, we may experience increases in energy, production, transportation and raw
material costs, capital expenditures or insurance premiums and deductibles. See “Business—
_Environment, Social and Governance.”_


-----

**_We may not be able to benefit from our expansion in growth markets._**

We have dedicated significant resources to enhance our local presence in growth markets and we
intend to continue to pursue this growth strategy, particularly in the Greater China, Asia/Pacific and
Americas regions. However, should we be unable to secure sufficient funding to finance our
development and growth activities in the future, we could lose our competitive position in these
important and rapidly growing regional markets. Furthermore, if we invest in growth markets that do
not develop as expected, or that deteriorate due to economic, political or other reasons, all or part of
these investments may be lost. We also depend on the success of our customers in the growth
markets.

In addition, the success of our investments in growth markets will depend on attracting and retaining
qualified personnel (including the need to identify, recruit, train and integrate additional employees),
maintaining our high-quality standards and implementing our standardized process and quality
management globally.

If we fail to recoup our investments in growth markets, this could have a material adverse effect on
our business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_Our business in growth markets is subject to a variety of business, economic, legal and political_**
**_risks, the materialization of which could adversely affect our business._**

We manufacture our products in many countries and market and sell them worldwide. We are
actively operating and may continue to expand our operations in rapidly growing and developing
markets, including China, India and Vietnam. Potential social, political, legal and economic instability,
such as that caused by the war in Ukraine, may pose significant risks to our ability to conduct our
business and expand our activities in certain markets. Inherent in our international operations is the
risk that any number of the following circumstances could adversely affect our operations:

  - underdeveloped infrastructure;

  - lack of qualified management or adequately trained personnel;

  - divergent labor regulations or cultural expectations regarding employment;

  - currency exchange controls, exchange rate fluctuations and devaluations;

  - changes in local economic conditions;

  - governmental restrictions on foreign investment, transfer or repatriation of funds;

  - protectionist trade measures, such as anti-dumping measures, duties, tariffs or embargoes;

  - prohibitions or restrictions on acquisitions or joint ventures;

  - changes in laws or regulations and unpredictable or unlawful government actions;

  - the difficulty of enforcing agreements and collecting receivables through foreign legal systems;

  - variations in protection of intellectual property and other legal rights;

  - business environments in which fraud, bribery or corruption are common, condoned or
encouraged by private or official actors;

  - potential nationalization of enterprises or other expropriations;

  - political or social unrest or acts of sabotage or terrorism; and

  - international sanctions or boycott measures.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.


-----

**_We may be unable to successfully integrate or achieve expected benefits from recent or future_**
**_acquisitions or investments and may be subject to risks relating to joint ventures or other_**
**_arrangements where we do not exercise full control and we may be exposed to risks in connection_**
**_with dispositions._**

We have pursued and may in the future pursue selected acquisitions, such as the acquisitions of
Ewellix AB and its subsidiaries (collectively, “Ewellix” or the “Ewellix Group”), SPV Solarpark 106.
GmbH & Co. KG (“SPV Solarpark”), CERASPIN S.à r.l. (“CERASPIN”), Schaeffler ByWire Technologie
GmbH & Co. KG (“Schaeffler ByWire”), Schaeffler Ultra Precision Drives GmbH (“Schaeffler Ultra
**Precision Drives”) and Bega international B.V. (“Bega”), and investments in joint ventures and other**
arrangements where we do not exercise full control, such as our recently established joint ventures
Cofinity-X GmbH (“Cofinity-X”) and Innoplate SAS (“Innoplate”). To the extent that we are successful
in making acquisitions or investments, we may need to expend substantial amounts of cash, incur
additional debt or assume loss-making divisions. Acquisitions, investments and joint ventures also
involve a number of other risks, including:

  - overestimation of the target value;

  - unexpected losses of key employees of the acquired operations;

  - extraordinary or unexpected legal, regulatory, contractual or other costs;

  - difficulties in integrating the employees and financial, technological and management
standards, processes, procedures and controls of the acquired business with those of our
existing operations;

  - unexpected or higher than expected costs related to the integration of an acquired business;

  - challenges in managing the increased scope, geographic diversity and complexity of our
operations;

  - mitigating contingent and/or assumed liabilities;

  - the possible loss of customers and/or suppliers;

  - control issues in relation to investments in joint ventures and other arrangements where we
do not exercise full control;

  - possibility that partners or co-investors may become bankrupt, fail to fund their required
capital contributions or perform their obligations poorly or not at all;

  - possibility that co-investors have objectives that are inconsistent or that conflict with our
business interests or goals and may be in a position to block or impede action with respect to
our investments or take actions contrary to our policies, objectives or interests;

  - disputes may arise between us and our co-investors that may consume significant financial and
other resources and result in the loss of business opportunities and growth; and

  - actions by our co-investors, of which we may be unaware, or which we may be unable to
control, such as political affiliations, illegal or corrupt practices and other activities, may cause
reputational damage to us or result in adverse consequences to our investments.

We may not be able to realize the anticipated cost savings, synergies, future earnings or other
benefits that we intend to achieve from acquisitions. We cannot guarantee that any recent or future
acquisition will yield benefits that are sufficient to justify the expenses we incurred or will incur. We
could also take on additional risks as a result of acquisitions.

In addition, following acquisitions, we record goodwill and other intangible assets on our
consolidated financial statements that will be subject to impairment based upon future adverse
changes in our business or prospects. With regards to intangible assets in particular, the net carrying


-----

amounts on our balance sheet are significant. As of December 31, 2022, the intangible assets on our
balance sheet totaled €916 million, including €540 million in goodwill. In addition, the Ewellix
Acquisition is expected to result in significant additional goodwill impact. “Management’s Discussion
_and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of the Schaeffler Group—Key Factors_
_affecting Results of Operations—Acquisitions.”_

Pursuant to current accounting rules, we are required to assess goodwill for impairment at least
annually or more frequently if impairment indicators are present. Impairment indicators include, but
are not limited to, significant underperformance relative to historical or projected future operating
results, a significant decline in share price or market capitalization and negative industry or economic
trends. If such events were to occur, such as during the COVID-19 pandemic or otherwise, the
carrying amount of our goodwill may no longer be recoverable and we would be required to record
an impairment charge. See also “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and
_Results of Operations of the Schaeffler Group—Key Factors affecting Results of Operations—Revenue”_
and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of the
_Schaeffler Group—Key Factors affecting Results of Operations—Acquisitions.” The impairment of any_
goodwill and other intangible assets could result in material non-cash charges and may have a
negative impact on our results of operations in the future.

In the past, we have disposed of certain businesses or operations that we no longer considered core
strategic activities or that were not sufficiently profitable, such as the disposition of our global drive
train business and the planned disposal of our two Russian subsidiaries, and we may make such
disposals in the future. Such disposals expose us to various risks. For example, we could be subject to
liability resulting from breaches of representations and warranties, or under indemnities, that we
provide to purchasers in connection with those disposals or we could continue to be liable, jointly
with the purchaser, for certain obligations of the disposed businesses that arose prior to the disposal,
such as retirement or pension obligations.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_We depend on a limited number of key suppliers for certain products and inability to source_**
**_products from these suppliers, particularly due to supply interruptions, could adversely affect our_**
**_operations._**

We require substantial amounts of raw materials for our production, in particular various types of
steel and other alloys, aluminum, zinc, copper and other non-ferrous metals as well as plastics and
lubricants and electric power. For some of the critical components used as part of our production and
manufacturing processes we rely on a limited number of key suppliers. Accordingly, our procurement
logistics may be adversely affected by supply delays, cancellations, strikes, insufficient quantities or
inadequate quality related to any of our suppliers. These could be the result of a general lack of
production capacity for certain raw materials or components, or of shortages or other external
factors, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, conflicts (such as the war in Ukraine), or climatic events,
delays or disruptions in shipping due to port congestion, port closures, vessel delays or extraordinary
accidents (such as the Suez Canal closure in March 2021), as well as by global economic recoveries,
such as the recent recovery from the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, that have created and may
continue to create pressure on demand for such raw materials or components. In the course of the
first quarter of 2022, the outbreak of the war in Ukraine saw price surges in almost all of the
commodity and energy markets that are important to us. As a result, production further down the
global value chain can be disrupted. The ability to deliver is a decisive competitive factor for a longterm, trusting customer relationship. This is constantly being increased by systematically improving
production and sales logistics. Any of these factors could result in interruptions in production and,
therefore, have an adverse effect on our production capacity and lead to under-utilization of our
production sites, which in turn may cause delays in the delivery of products to our customers. If any


-----

one of our suppliers becomes unable to meet our delivery requirements for any reason (e.g., due to
insolvency, destruction of production plants, strikes or refusal to perform following a change in
control), we may be unable to source input products from other suppliers upon short notice and/or
at the required volume.

In addition, many of our OEM customers have approval rights with respect to the suppliers used by
us, limiting our ability to source input products from other suppliers upon short notice if the relevant
OEM customer has not already approved such other suppliers.

Inability to source the required quantities of raw materials and components when needed could have
a material adverse effect on our business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of
operations. See also “—Prices of many of our raw materials and energy have increased significantly
_and may rise further, which may lead to higher production and manufacturing.”_

**_The COVID-19 pandemic may continue to adversely impact our business, financial condition, results_**
**_of operations and cash flows._**

Although the worst of the COVID-19 pandemic may have passed, any possible future outbreaks or
recurrences, or actual or perceived occurrences of epidemics or pandemics, could have an adverse
effect on us. The global spread of COVID-19 and its variants created significant macroeconomic
uncertainty, volatility and disruption including declining economic growth, numerous business
insolvencies, and significantly increased unemployment, resulting in decreased per capita income and
disposable income. The consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic could continue to affect our
operations. This could include, but is not limited to, decreases in consumer demand, extended work
stoppages and travel restrictions at our facilities and those of our customers and suppliers, delays or
disruptions in vehicle production schedules, postponement or cancellation of our capital expenditure
projects and other adverse global economic impacts. In addition, some continued local lockdowns,
such as in China, may continue to affect operations.

Notably, the supply shortages created by the COVID-19 pandemic could continue to have an impact
on our suppliers and customers. See “—We depend on a limited number of key suppliers for certain
_products and inability to source products from these suppliers, particularly due to supply_
_interruptions, could adversely affect our operations” and “—Prices of many of our raw materials and_
_energy have increased significantly and may rise further, which may lead to higher production and_
_manufacturing costs,” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results_
_of Operations of the Schaeffler Group—Key Factors affecting Results of Operations—Operating_
_Expenses—Raw Material and Energy Costs.”_

Moreover, any impacts on our business operations as a result of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic
could also affect our financial condition. For example, while we did not recognize any impairment
loss in 2022, we recognized an impairment charge in relation to goodwill allocated to the Automotive
Technologies Division in the amount of €249 million in 2020 because the COVID-19 pandemic led to
increased uncertainty and, therefore, to changes in the assumptions used to determine the
recoverable amount of groups of cash-generating units. See also “Management’s Discussion and
_Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of the Schaeffler Group—Key Factors_
_affecting Results of Operations—Revenue” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial_
_Condition and Results of Operations of the Schaeffler Group—Key Factors affecting Results of_
_Operations—Acquisitions.”_

The course and effects of the coronavirus pandemic are continuously analyzed in order to ensure our
earning power and liquidity position are meeting targeted measures. However, any of the foregoing
could still materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, and results of operations.


-----

**_Our future business success depends on our ability to maintain the high quality of our products and_**
**_the punctual delivery of ordered goods._**

For customers, one of the determining factors in purchasing our components and systems is the high
quality of our products, in particular due to their often mission-critical nature. A decrease in the
actual and perceived quality of our products could damage our image and reputation and also the
image and reputation of one or more of our brands. In addition, defective products could result in
loss of sales, loss of customers and loss of market acceptance. Furthermore, our customers could
potentially bring claims for damages, even if the cause of the defect is remedied at a later point in
time.

We manufacture many products pursuant to specifications and quality requirements of our OEM
customers. If the products manufactured and delivered by us do not meet the requirements
stipulated by our OEM customers at the agreed date of delivery, production of the relevant products
is generally discontinued until the cause of the product defect has been identified and remedied.
The above risks also apply in cases where we utilize or rely on third parties in our production
processes and operations. For example, we experienced delivery delays and certain quality issues in
the Automotive Aftermarket Division’s assembly and packaging center in Halle, Germany (the
“AKO”), as a result of the actions of its former third-party operator. These delivery delays and quality
issues have resulted in customer claims and the loss of a number of customers, which has adversely
affected the Automotive Aftermarket Division’s revenues. We terminated the former third-party
operator’s contract and a new third-party operator took over operation of the AKO on August 1,
2022, but may still face further claims from customers affected by delivery delays or quality issues or
the loss of additional customers or revenue. While we were able to reach a settlement for damages
with the former third-party operator, we were not able to recover the full amount of our losses and
there can be no assurance that we will not face further claims in the future as a result of the actions
of the current or any future third-party operator.

In addition, delivery capabilities and delivery performance represent a key competitive factor.
Disruptions to local, regional domestic, or international transportation services for our products due
to shortages in vessels, barges, railcars or trucks, weather-related problems, flooding, droughts,
accidents, mechanical difficulties, bankruptcies, strikes, lockouts, bottlenecks, trade restrictions,
pandemics, or other events may impair our ability to deliver products to customers on time or at all,
and might permit our customers to suspend taking delivery of and paying for our products, result in
contractual penalties, expose us to damage claims from our customers, result in a loss of customers
or negatively impact our reputation.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_Product piracy may adversely affect our operations._**

We aim to maintain a high quality standard for our products and believe that our brands enjoy a
reputation of high performance and reliability. A resulting side effect is that we have been the target
of product piracy in the past, covering nearly the entire product portfolio of our Automotive
Technologies and Industrial Divisions’ product catalogs. In the last few years, there have been cases
of counterfeit bearings being delivered, for example, to public transportation companies, for marine
applications and to the energy industry for installation in offshore wind turbines.

Due to the reputation of our brands, we expect that third parties will continue to produce and
distribute counterfeit products under our brands in the future. Such products are usually sold at
significantly reduced prices or produced with significantly shorter lead times as the production
standards and steel quality are inferior to our standards, which might put pressure on us to lower the
prices we charge for original products. We may also lose market share to producers of counterfeit
products, particularly in growth markets. While we actively prosecute product piracy in all of our


-----

markets, fighting product piracy may be costly and prove unsuccessful. Furthermore, the lower
quality standards of counterfeit products illegally sold under our brand names may damage our
brand image if customers unwittingly purchase such products and experience product failures or
poor performance. It could also result in us facing product liability claims and having to pay damages
for the failure of counterfeit products.

Product piracy could therefore have a material adverse effect on our business, net assets, financial
condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_We may not be able to obtain the funding required for our R&D activities and these activities may_**
**_not lead to the development of commercially successful products._**

Developing new and improved products requires a substantial amount of capital funding. If we
devote resources to the pursuit of new technologies and products that fail to be accepted in the
marketplace or that fail to become commercially viable, all or part of these R&D expenses may be
lost. Furthermore, should we be unable to secure sufficient funding to finance our R&D activities, we
could lose our competitive position in a number of important and rapidly growing sub-markets.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_Our operations depend on qualified executives and key employees and the loss of these persons_**
**_could adversely affect our market position and prospects._**

Our success depends on the members of the Board of Managing Directors, and other qualified
executives and employees in key functions throughout Schaeffler Group. The loss of executives or
key employees could have a material adverse effect on our market position and prospects.
Considerable expertise could be lost or access thereto gained by competitors. Due to intense
competition within the industry, there is a risk of losing qualified employees to competitors or being
unable to find a sufficient number of appropriate new employees. There is no guarantee that we will
be successful in retaining our executives and the employees in key positions or in attracting new
employees with corresponding qualifications.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.

**_Our business could be adversely impacted by strikes and other labor disputes._**

With approximately 83,000 employees (as of December 31, 2022), we employ a large workforce
around the world. A significant number of our employees, particularly in Germany, are unionized.
Furthermore, Schaeffler AG and other German entities of Schaeffler Group are subject to the
regulations of the German Co-Determination Act (Mitbestimmungsgesetz). Therefore, we depend on
positive relationships with our employees and employee representatives. These relationships could
deteriorate in the future and we could experience additional strikes, further unionization efforts or
other types of conflicts with employee representatives or our employees. From 2019 through 2022,
we reduced our workforce significantly (from 92,478 employees as of December 31, 2018 to 82,773
employees as of December 31, 2022), mostly in Germany and the rest of Europe and mainly in
connection with our efficiency and portfolio optimization subprograms and other structural
measures aimed at increasing efficiency. In addition, during the COVID-19 pandemic we implemented
various measures, such as short-time work (Kurzarbeit), closure days, using hours in flextime
accounts, workforce reductions, plant closures, and plant holidays. In November 2022, we initiated
further restructuring measures, which will include reducing our headcount by 1,300 positions
worldwide and, within Germany, will mainly impact the Herzogenaurach, Buehl and Homburg
locations. In addition, we are developing strategies for the Ingolstadt and Morbach locations in
consultation with employee representatives for those locations. See “—We may be unable to
_implement our efficiency and portfolio optimization and growth programs successfully.” More_


-----

headcount reductions may be implemented in the future. Though we intend to reduce the workforce
in a socially acceptable manner, this could nevertheless cause our relationships with employees and
employee representatives to deteriorate. Strikes associated with our operations could also damage
our reputation with customers or our public reputation.

In addition, many of our customers and suppliers also have unionized workforces. Refusals to work or
work downtime experienced by our customers or suppliers could reduce demand for our products or
prevent us from obtaining raw materials and other products required for our own production. Strikes
or labor disputes could have a material adverse effect on our business, net assets, financial condition,
cash flows and results of operations.

**_Our operations rely on complex information technology systems and networks, and interruptions of_**
**_these systems and networks, or a material breach in security relating to our information systems,_**
**_could adversely affect us and our business operations._**

We rely heavily on centralized, standardized information technology systems and networks to
support business processes, as well as internal and external communications. These systems and
networks are potentially vulnerable to damage or interruption from a variety of sources and to
security threats, including cyberattacks and espionage. An extended outage in a data center or
telecommunications network utilized by our systems, security breaches or any similar event could
lead to an extended and unanticipated interruption of our systems or networks and affect our
production and other operations. In addition, it is possible that a malfunction of our data system
security measures could enable unauthorized persons to access sensitive business data, including
information relating to our intellectual property, business strategy or confidential customer data.
Unauthorized disclosure, modification or loss of confidential, personally identifiable or sensitive data
or other operational failures may occur through a variety of methods. These include, but are not
limited to, systems failures, in-house employee negligence, fraud or misappropriation, or
unauthorized access to or through our information systems, whether by our in-house employees,
vendors or third parties, or a cyber-attack by hackers, members of organized crime and/or statesponsored organizations. Information security risks have generally increased in recent years, in part
because of the proliferation of new technologies and the use of the internet, and the increased
sophistication and activity of organized crime, hackers, terrorists, activists, cybercriminals and other
external parties, some of which may be linked to terrorist organizations or hostile foreign
governments. Cybersecurity attacks are becoming more sophisticated and include malicious
software, phishing and spear phishing attacks, wire fraud and payment diversion, account and email
takeover attacks, ransomware, attempts to gain unauthorized access to data and other electronic
security breaches. If an actual or perceived breach of security occurs, customer perception of the
effectiveness of our security measures could be harmed which could result in the loss of customers.
Similar risks exist in case of interruption, malfunction or data leakage with respect to information
technology systems of third-party providers that we cooperate with. An incident involving disclosure,
data modification, loss or security breach or a significant technical failure could subject us to
significant monetary damages or losses, litigation, negative publicity, regulatory enforcement actions
and fines, and liability under our contracts, resulting in increased costs or loss of revenue. Our
customers increasingly require us to maintain an information security management system based on
certain industry standards, such as ISO/IEC 27001/TISAX, and reflecting national and sector-specific
regulations. If we fail to implement or maintain security systems required by our customers, this
could have an adverse effect on our customer relationships and we may be in breach of our
contractual obligations. We incur significant costs to protect against security breaches and other
cybersecurity attacks and may incur significant additional costs to address issues caused by any such
breaches or cybersecurity attacks.

The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our
business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results of operations.


-----

**_We could be adversely affected by property losses and unforeseen business interruptions._**

Damage and loss caused by fire, accidents, natural disasters, terrorism, severe weather or other
disruptions of our production process at our facilities or within our supply chain, with respect to
customers and suppliers, can be severe. We, our suppliers and our customers have also been
affected by mandatory or voluntary site closures as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and, as a
result of the war in Ukraine. In addition, as a result of the war in Ukraine, a number of companies,
including ourselves and a number of our customers, have announced plans to divest interests or
otherwise curtail business dealings in Russia and/or with Russian businesses, or have been required
to halt, reduce or delay production due to the unavailability of raw materials or components, such as
springs and friction linings, which adversely affects those customers’ demand for our products and
we, our suppliers and our customers may also be affected by related countermeasures, such as the
seizure of the assets of U.S. and European companies and persons located in Russia or territories
under its control. Such risks arising from business interruption and loss of production are insured at
levels considered economically reasonable and on standard market terms by us, but our insurance
coverage could prove insufficient in individual cases. Furthermore, such events could injure or kill
individuals or damage or destroy third-party property or the environment, which could, among other
things, lead to considerable financial costs for us. In addition, our manufacturing processes are
dependent on critical pieces of equipment such as furnaces, as well as machines and electrical
equipment such as transformers, and this equipment may, on occasion, be out of service as a result
of unanticipated failures, which may result in production bottlenecks and breakdowns, particularly
where a manufacturing site only operates a single unit of a particular type of equipment, which is the
case at several production locations. The materialization of any of the risks described above could
have a material adverse effect on our business, net assets, financial condition, cash flows and results
of operations.

**_Our insurance coverage may be insufficient, and we may be unable to completely insure certain_**
**_risks or obtain sufficient insurance coverage in the future._**

We have taken out insurance coverage for a number of risks, including property damage, product
liability (including extended product liability and automotive recall liability, cybersecurity liability,
damage to rented property and environmental damage liability). There is no guarantee that our
insurance policies will adequately cover all material risks we face. Some risks cannot be insured, and
for certain risks and in certain locations, insurance may not be available or may be available only at
costs that are not economically viable. We cannot guarantee that one or more events will occur for
which the Schaeffler Group is uncompensated or undercompensated by insurance. Furthermore, our
insurance coverage could lapse due to unintentional non-payment of insurance premiums.

Following a number of claims or after a major claim, insurance premiums may be increased or the
terms and conditions of insurance coverage may become less favorable. This may also occur due to a
general change in the insurance markets. There is no guarantee that we will be able to continue to
