**_Cash Flows_**

_Cash dividends_

Cash dividends received during the past three years consist of dividends received from Schaeffler AG,
Continental AG and P A R A V A N GmbH (the Issuer acquired its 25% interest in P A R A V A N GmbH
in 2019 and sold it in 2022).

Cash dividends received in 2020, 2021 and 2022 were €436 million, €120 million and €362 million,
respectively, and consisted of dividends received from Schaeffler AG (in all three years) and
Continental AG (in 2020 and 2022), as well as dividends of €0.4 million received from P A R A V A N
GmbH in 2021. The cash dividend from Continental AG in 2022 (€117 million) was received net of a
withholding tax of €42 million which is expected to be credited against the corporate income tax
liability for 2022, and to the extent exceeding corporate income tax liability, it is expected to be
reimbursed in 2023. Continental AG did not pay cash dividends in 2021 and Vitesco AG has not paid
any dividends since its spin-off from Continental AG in 2021.

We did not pay cash dividends to IHO Beteiligung in 2020, 2021 or 2022. Although we declared a
dividend of €880 million in 2020, which was paid in kind by way of set-off against termination of a
€880 million upstream loan to IHO Beteiligung, and of €550 million in 2021, which was set off against
a subordinated shareholder loan granted by IHO Beteiligung to the Issuer, neither dividend resulted
in a cash outflow.

_Principal Payments On/From Financial Debt_

Our financial debt prior to the Refinancing consisted mainly of drawings under the Issuer Syndicated
Facilities Agreement, the Issuer’s term loan facility (until February 2021) and the Existing Issuer Notes
outstanding during the relevant period. In addition, in 2021 IHO Beteiligung granted a subordinated
shareholder loan in the principal amount of €550 million to the Issuer. Interest on the loan is payable
either in cash or capitalized (by increasing the principal amount of the loan), in the Issuer’s sole
discretion. See “Certain Relationships and Related party Transactions—Transactions of the Issuer—
_Subordinated Shareholder Loan.”_


-----

In September 2022, we repaid €100 million of the Issuer Revolving Facility, reducing the outstanding
amount to €160 million. We did not make any principal payments in respect of the Existing Issuer
Notes in that year.

In February 2021, we repaid in full the €400 million then outstanding under our term loan facility and
terminated that facility. In 2021, we made net repayments of €140 million under the Issuer Revolving
Facility. We did not make any principal payments in respect of the Existing Issuer Notes in that year.

In 2020, we reduced drawings under our term loan facility from €600 million to €400 million. We did
not make any drawings or repayments under the Issuer Revolving Facility and principal payments in
respect of the Existing Issuer Notes in that year.

_Interest_

Interest paid primarily consists of interest payments on the Existing Issuer Notes and borrowings
under the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement and, until February 2021, drawings under a term
loan facility (repaid in full and terminated in February 2021) net of payments received under crosscurrency swaps related to the Existing Issuer Notes. To the extent the Issuer elects to pay interest in
cash, as it did in 2022, interest paid also includes interest on the subordinated shareholder loan
granted by IHO Beteiligung to the Issuer. Interest received primarily relates to interest we received
under a €880 million upstream loan to IHO Beteiligung, which was terminated on March 30, 2020 by
way of set-off of the loan receivable against a dividend-in-kind.

Interest paid in 2020, 2021 and 2022 amounted to €145 million, €141 million and €143 million,
respectively, of which €5 million related to the subordinated shareholder loan. During these periods,
we received interest payments of €16 million, €0 million and €0 million, respectively.

_Income Taxes_

Income taxes received consist of reimbursement of corporate income and trade tax prepayments.
Income taxes paid consists of payments and prepayments for corporate income and trade tax.

In 2020 and 2021, net income taxes paid amounted to €4 million and €14 million, respectively. In
2022, net income taxes received amounted to €3 million.

### Liabilities

**_Financial Debt_**

As of December 31, 2022, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Refinancing, the Issuer’s
financial debt would have amounted to €3,476 million, which primarily consists of the Notes offered
in the Offering, the Existing Issuer Notes (excluding the Redeemed Issuer Notes) and drawings under
the Issuer Revolving Facility. See “Summary—The Refinancing,” “Summary—Summary Financial
_Information—Pro Forma Financial Information,” “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalization.”_

_Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement_

The Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement provides for a €800 million Issuer Revolving Facility, of
which €160 million were drawn as of December 31, 2022.

The Issuer Revolving Facility is secured by the same collateral that will secure the Notes and that
secures the Existing Issuer Notes on a pari passu basis. Up to €50 million of the Issuer Revolving
Facility are available for drawing, in the form of ancillary facilities, on behalf and for the account of
the Issuer, by Atesteo, a wholly-owned subsidiary of IHO Holding GmbH & Co. KG, an indirect
shareholder of the Issuer, which were unutilized as of December 31, 2022.


-----

See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Indebtedness of the Issuer—Issuer Syndicated Facilities
_Agreement.”_

_Existing Issuer Notes_

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer has the following debt securities
outstanding: €750 million in aggregate principal amount of 3.750% / 4.500% senior secured PIK
toggle notes due 2026 and $500 million in aggregate principal amount of 4.750% / 5.500% senior
secured PIK toggle notes due 2026, each issued under an indenture dated September 22, 2016, and
€800 million in aggregate principal amount of 3.625% / 4.375% senior secured PIK toggle notes due
2025, $450 million in aggregate principal amount of 6.000% / 6.750% senior secured PIK toggle notes
due 2027, €500 million in aggregate principal amount of 3.875% / 4.625% senior secured PIK toggle
notes due 2027 and $400 million in aggregate principal amount of 6.375% / 7.125% senior secured
PIK toggle notes due 2029, each issued under an indenture dated June 6, 2019. See “Description of
_Other Indebtedness—Indebtedness of the Issuer—Existing Issuer Notes.”_

The Issuer intends to use the net proceeds from the Offering, together with cash at banks, to redeem
€500 million in principal amount of the Existing 2025 Euro Notes (the “Redeemed Issuer Notes”). The
Issuer expects to redeem the Redeemed Issuer Notes on or about May 15, 2023. See “Use of
_Proceeds.”_

**_Provisions_**

_Tax Provisions_

Tax provisions as of December 31, 2022 amounted to €8 million and primarily relate to the potential
impact of tax audits.

_Provisions for Pensions and Similar Liabilities_

Provisions for pensions and similar liabilities as of December 31, 2022 of €7 million primarily relate to
defined benefit obligations and deferred compensation. See “Risk Factors—Legal, Regulatory and Tax
_Risks—Tax audits may lead to a substantial increase of our tax burden for past periods.”_

### Overview

We develop and manufacture high-precision components, systems and services for powertrains and
chassis, as well as rolling and plain bearing solutions for various industry applications. This includes
innovative and sustainable technologies for hybrid, electric and combustion-engine powered
vehicles. Our offering comprises solutions for automated and autonomous driving, components and
systems for rotary and linear motion, as well as services, maintenance products and monitoring
systems for a wide range of industrial applications. Our portfolio also includes OEM-quality repair
solutions and associated supporting services for the global automotive aftermarket.

We are one of the largest family-controlled technology companies in the world, with approximately
83,000 employees and a network of production and manufacturing locations, R&D facilities and
distribution companies in approximately 200 locations in over 50 countries (as of December 31,
2022). Our 76 plants form the foundation of our operations.

In 2022, we had consolidated revenues of €15.8 billion and Adjusted EBITDA of €2.0 billion. For an
explanation of the components of Adjusted EBITDA and a reconciliation of net income to Adjusted
EBITDA, see “Summary Financial Information—Other Financial and Operating Data—Summary
_Financial Information of Schaeffler AG (IFRS)—Schaeffler AG.” We have a large presence in a number_
of growth markets, such as the Americas, China and the rest of Asia. We believe that we benefit from
our advanced technology platform, high product quality, long-standing and diversified customer
relationships, broad distribution channels, global production footprint and extensive product,
systems solutions and service offering.

We report financial information by based on the following three Divisions: Automotive Technologies,
Automotive Aftermarket and Industrial.

**_Automotive Technologies Division: Our Automotive Technologies Division partners with the global_**
automotive industry in developing and manufacturing components and system solutions for electric
and hybrid powertrains and fuel cell powertrains, as well as for internal combustion engines and
chassis systems. The Division also offers a wide range of rolling bearings that is largely powertrainagnostic. Our Automotive Technologies Division accounted for 60.1% of our consolidated revenue
and 27.9% of our Adjusted EBIT in 2022; in 2022, the Automotive Technologies Division recorded
Adjusted EBIT of €292 million. Until December 31, 2021, our Automotive Technologies Division
comprised four business divisions (“BDs”) with a distinctive product and service portfolio: (i) EMobility, (ii) Engine Systems, (iii) Transmission Systems and (iv) Chassis Systems. As from January 1,
2022, we have reorganized our Automotive Technologies Division’s BDs to include: (i) E-Mobility, (ii)
Engine Systems & Transmission Systems, (iii) Bearings, and (iv) Chassis Systems, which accounted for
approximately 14.2%, 54.2%, 27.6% and 3.9%, respectively, of the Automotive Technologies
Division’s revenue during 2022. See “Business—Our Divisions—Automotive Technologies Division.”
Discussions and figures in this section refer to the previous BDs with regard to financial figures for
2020 and refer to the new BDs with regard to financial figures for 2021 and 2022, except under “—
_Results of Operations—Comparison of 2020 with 2021,” where the discussions and figures refer to_
the previous BDs for comparability reasons.

**_Automotive Aftermarket Division: Our Automotive Aftermarket Division complements the_**
Automotive Technologies Division with an extensive aftermarket offering, which includes the
distribution of spare parts and services to customers globally. The Automotive Aftermarket Division
uses two primary distribution channels to sell its products and services to customers, the original
equipment service (“OES”), which supplies original spare parts to automobile OEMs for their branded
repair shops, and the open (independent) spare parts market or independent aftermarket (“IAM”),
which supplies components and repair solutions and services to a global network of independent
parts distributors, which supply workshops that are not affiliated with any particular automobile
OEM. A considerable portion of IAM’s sales market comprises of distributors organized in trade


-----

cooperatives. Our Automotive Aftermarket Division accounted for 12.9% of our consolidated revenue
and 24.4% of Adjusted EBIT in 2022; in 2022, the Automotive Aftermarket Division recorded Adjusted
EBIT of €255 million.

**_Industrial Division: The Industrial Division develops and manufactures components and systems for_**
rotary and linear movements as well as services such as maintenance products and monitoring
systems for customers in a variety of different industrial sectors, which we group into eight sector
clusters within four market clusters: renewables (wind), transportation and mobility (aerospace, rail,
offroad and two-wheelers), machinery and materials (raw materials and power transmission) and
industrial automation (industrial automation). The Industrial Division is also developing new products
and solutions for the hydrogen economy. In addition, our Industrial Distribution unit manages the
distribution portion of the business. The Industrial Division accounted for 27.0% of our consolidated
revenue and 47.7% of our Adjusted EBIT in 2022; in 2022, the Industrial Division recorded Adjusted
EBIT of €499 million.

Geographically, we manage our Divisions and businesses based on four regions, Europe (Germany,
Western Europe, Middle East & Africa, Central & Eastern Europe), the Americas (the United States &
Canada, Mexico, South America), Greater China (including Mainland China, and also Taiwan, Hong
Kong and Macao) and Asia/Pacific (South Korea, Japan, Southeast Asia and India).

### Key Factors affecting Results of Operations 

Our results of operations, financial condition and liquidity have been influenced in the periods
discussed in this Offering Memorandum by the following events, facts, developments and market
characteristics. We believe that these factors have influenced and are likely to continue to influence
our operations in the future.

**_Revenue_**

Our revenue development is dependent on economic developments in the automotive and the
industrial sectors globally and was particularly impacted in recent years by the COVID-19 pandemic,
the war in Ukraine and inflationary trends. Slower economic growth began in 2019 and was further
exacerbated when, in the spring of 2020, the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic led to a worldwide
health and economic crisis, which heavily affected the automotive industry and all sectors of the
economy. Overall, the COVID-19 pandemic significantly affected our revenues and profitability in
2020, particularly in the first half of the year, and required us to recognize an impairment of €249
million on the goodwill of the Automotive Technologies Division in the first quarter of 2020. In the
second half of 2020, global economic recovery began to emerge and broadly continued throughout
2021, although it slowed in the fourth quarter of 2021. In 2021, our results of operations were not as
significantly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic as in 2020, as market demand recovered.
Vaccinations and the implementation of fiscal and monetary policies further bolstered our results
and contrasted with the impact of supply chain disruptions, new COVID-19 variants, and rising
commodity and energy prices. However, certain side effects of the market recovery, particularly price
increases of raw materials, such as steel, of energy, supply chain disruptions, and the semiconductor
shortage, which negatively affected vehicle production and therefore demand for our products, had
an adverse impact on our revenues and margins, particularly in the second half of the year.

In 2022, the global economic recovery slowed again with the start of the war in Ukraine, which had a
significant impact on the economic environment as well as our business and our customers’
businesses. Our revenues attributable to Russia, Belarus and Ukraine declined significantly in 2022
and amounted to approximately €32 million (€122 million in 2021), €2 million (€16 million in 2021)
and €17 million (€28 million in 2021), respectively. We reduced production at our plant in Ulyanovsk,
Russia (98 employees in Russia) to the minimum possible in order to continue to meet our
contractual delivery obligations, and ceased the operations of our Automotive Aftermarket and


-----

Industrial Divisions in Russia. We had also sourced certain raw materials, such as steel, from sources
in Russia, which we discontinued after the outbreak of the war, and had utilized shipping routes
between Europe and China that crossed through Russia, which we have re-routed. In addition, in
December 2022, we entered into an agreement to sell our two Russian subsidiaries for a sale price of
€10 million. The agreed disposal, which is subject to the approval of Russian authorities, resulted in
an impairment of €12 million in 2022. In Ukraine, though our sales office in Kyiv (six employees in
Ukraine) was initially closed, our operations in Ukraine have resumed. While our direct exposure to
Russia, Belarus and Ukraine has been relatively limited, we will continue to monitor the impacts of
the war in Ukraine on macroeconomic conditions and continually assess the effect these matters may
have on our businesses and compliance obligations. For more information regarding the current and
potential impact of the war in Ukraine on our operations, see “Risk Factors—Risks related to our
_Business Operations and the Markets in which we operate—As a global supplier to the automotive_
_and industrial sectors we are exposed to substantial risks associated with the performance of the_
_global economy, political uncertainty and the performance of the economy in the regions in which we_
_operate.”_

The war in Ukraine and the related sanctions and counter-sanctions worsened the economic
environment that was already weakened by the COVID-19 pandemic, affected trade, resulted in
additional disruptions to global supply chains, significant upward pressure on commodity prices and
led to an energy crisis, in particular in Europe, where imports of Russian natural gas were significantly
reduced. In addition, the resurgence of the COVID-19 pandemic in China, in particular from March to
May of 2022, resulted in renewed lockdowns and additional pressure on global supply chains.
Inflation also continued to rise during 2022 and resulted in central banks enacting measures,
including raising interest rates, seeking to curtail inflation. While the direct impact of these events on
our business activities was limited, these events negatively affected vehicle production and therefore
demand for our products and had an adverse impact on our revenues and margins, particularly in the
first half of 2022. In contrast to the global economic recovery seen in 2021, global GDP growth
declined steadily in 2022, particularly in the fourth quarter.

Global GDP increased by 3.2% in 2022 (Source: Oxford Economics, January 2023), and global
automotive production increased by 6.2% from 2021 to 2022, despite a modest increase of 0.6% in
Europe, as production increased by 9.3% in the Americas, 6.2% in Greater China and 9.0% in
Asia/Pacific (Source: S&P Global Mobility © [S&P Global Mobility Light Vehicle Production Forecast
(Base), January 2023], regions reflect the regional structure of the Schaeffler Group).

In this context, the situation in each of the Schaeffler Group’s regions was as follows: GDP in the
Europe region increased by approximately 2.9% in 2022 as compared to 2021, while economic output
in the Americas region increased by approximately 2.7%. In the Greater China region, GDP rose by
approximately 2.6% in 2022, which was below the prior year level, and the Asia/Pacific region’s
economic output rose by approximately 4.8% in 2022, each as compared to 2021 (Source: Oxford
Economics, January 2023).

_Developments in the Global Automotive Market_

We are a main partner and supplier to the global automotive industry and are therefore highly
dependent on developments in the global automotive market. Our Automotive Technologies
Division’s revenue is primarily affected by global automobile production, which in turn is impacted by
factors influencing consumer demand for new passenger cars and commercial vehicles. The
Automotive Technologies Division is indirectly affected by factors such as unemployment, interest
rates (and, most generally, overall monetary and fiscal policy), inflation, gasoline prices and
consumer confidence. In addition, the Automotive Technologies Division is indirectly impacted by
factors such as the levels of international trade and the availability of vehicle financing, as these
factors affect the demand for commercial vehicles in particular. In 2020, and, to a lesser extent, in
2021, our Automotive Technologies Division’s revenue was affected by the COVID-19 pandemic,


-----

which posed significant challenges to the automotive sector overall and caused automobile
production to decrease by approximately 16.1% during 2020 (Source: S&P Global Mobility © [S&P
Global Mobility Light Vehicle Production Forecast (Base), February 2022]), in contrast to growth of
3.5% during 2021 and 6.2% in 2022 (Source: S&P Global Mobility © [S&P Global Mobility Light Vehicle
Production Forecast (Base), January 2023]). In 2022, automobile production declined in the first half
of the year and recovered to double-digit growth in the second half of the year (Source: S&P Global
Mobility © [S&P Global Mobility Light Vehicle Production Forecast (Base), January 2023]). Despite the
positive trend in global automobile production, our Automotive Technologies Division’s revenue was
affected by the challenging sector environment. These challenges included sustained semiconductor
shortages that led to high production losses, the war in Ukraine that caused a slump in production in
Russia and a shortage of raw materials from Ukraine that caused production disruptions in Europe,
and the resurgence of the COVID-19 pandemic in China, in particular from March to May of 2022,
that significantly disrupted production in China and in Japan due to supply chain disruptions. In
addition to those supply challenges, rising inflation weakened consumer demand in 2022.

Supply chain disruptions, particularly the global semiconductor shortage, have significantly impacted
the automotive sector. After dropping considerably due to COVID-19, demand for passenger cars
rebounded in the third quarter of 2020 and has continued, and in turn, demand for semiconductors
increased rapidly. This surge in demand coincided with geopolitical factors, including disruptions in
the global transportation system and supply chains (such as the Suez Canal closure in March 2021),
lower supply as well as regulations resulting from the trade conflict between the U.S. and China.
These geopolitical factors further exacerbated the existing circumstances in 2021 and then continued
into 2022 as a result of the war in Ukraine and the resurgence of the COVID-19 pandemic in China.
Throughout the remainder of 2021 and into the first half of 2022, the semiconductor shortage
continued to impair the production of automobiles and auto parts, contributing to a markedly
constrained market for OEM programs in particular. This resulted in highly volatile customer call-off
orders and heavily impacted the Automotive Technologies Division’s sales volumes and revenues in
the first half of 2022. Despite a recovery in automobile production and the Division’s sales volumes in
the second half of 2022, the duration and severity of the impact of the global semiconductor
shortage is uncertain, and our business and results of operations may continue to be negatively
affected to the extent that the global semiconductor shortage continues or worsens.

In 2022, automobile production in the Europe region increased slightly by approximately 0.6%. In the
euro region, the number of vehicles produced increased by 4.2% from 2021. Automobile production
in the Americas region was approximately 9.3% above 2021. In the U.S., Canada and Mexico,
automobile production increased by approximately 9.4%, 11.2% and 8.2%, respectively, while
production levels in Brazil increased by 6.7%. Within the Greater China region, the number of
vehicles produced grew approximately 6.2% in 2022 relative to 2021. In the Asia/Pacific region,
automobile production increased by approximately 9.0% in 2022 as compared to 2021. The heaviest
increase of 23.8% was reported in India and South Korea and Thailand saw increases of 7.2% and
9.8%, respectively, while production in Japan decreased 1.1% (Source: S&P Global Mobility © [S&P
Global Mobility Light Vehicle Production Forecast (Base), January 2023], regions reflect the regional
structure of the Schaeffler Group).

_Developments in the Automotive Aftermarket_

The Automotive Aftermarket Division is generally influenced by the growing vehicle population,
measured as the number of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles up to 3.5 tons in weight, as
well as by the rising average age and growing complexity of vehicles. The number of passenger cars
and light commercial vehicles on the road impacts the size of the aftermarket for spare parts for
these vehicles. The global vehicle population has grown steadily over the past years and, in particular
in the Greater China region, is expected to continue to increase significantly in the coming years


-----

(Source: S&P Global Mobility © [S&P Global Mobility Vehicle in Operation (VIO) Forecast, February
2023], regions reflect the regional structure of the Schaeffler Group).

The average age of passenger cars and light commercial vehicles also has an impact on the
distribution aftermarkets in which we operate. In general, older vehicles require more repair and
maintenance services and spare parts than younger vehicles. Therefore, an increase in the age of
vehicles is expected to have a positive impact on the sales of our Automotive Aftermarket Division.
Furthermore, the average age of the vehicle population is impacted by sales volumes and the
production quality of the vehicles in the vehicle population (higher production quality generally
enables vehicles to run longer without repair or replacement). Increased sales and higher production
quality generally lead to decreased demand for the products and services of our Automotive
Aftermarket Division in the short-term. However, the same trends also increase the vehicle
population going forward and stimulate demand for our Automotive Aftermarket Division’s products
and services in the medium-to-long-term.

In 2020, the Automotive Aftermarket Division also experienced considerable declines in demand due
to the COVID-19 pandemic, however it suffered from lower revenue loss as compared to the
Automotive Technologies Division. In 2021, our Automotive Aftermarket Division’s revenue grew
significantly compared to 2020, which was mainly attributable to the increase in sales volumes in the
first half of 2021 as compared to the low basis for comparison in 2020, while the second half
remained relatively flat compared to the first half. In 2022, our Automotive Technologies Division’s
revenue grew compared to 2021. This increase was primarily attributable to a favorable impact from
adjusted sales prices, whereby a significant portion of increased procurement costs were passed on
to the market as well as significant sales volume increases and the low basis in the 2021 comparative
period, which was marked by supply shortages. In addition, the trend towards repairing rather than
replacing vehicles has benefitted the Automotive Aftermarket Division.

_Developments in the Global Industrial Sector_

Within our Industrial Division, we serve customers in a variety of different sectors and sell
components and systems for a diverse range of applications, ranging from wind turbines to
aerospace engines and dentists’ drills. We believe that the high degree of diversification in our
businesses and the stability of our wholesale business (i.e., sale of spare parts and provision of
services) as well as our ability to attract new business and to enhance our portfolio with
opportunistic acquisitions, support the robustness of our revenues against downturns in individual
sectors. Each of these end-markets is influenced by different economic factors and is affected by a
downturn in different stages, making us less vulnerable to adverse changes in the micro-economic
environment or fluctuations of a particular economic parameter in any one of our industry market
sectors. Our Industrial Division’s customers conduct business in the sectors of wind, aerospace, rail,
offroad, two-wheelers, raw materials, power transmission and industrial automation.

In 2020, the Industrial Division experienced considerable declines in demand due to the COVID-19
pandemic, though it suffered from lower revenue loss as compared to the Automotive Technologies
Division, primarily due to the growing wind industry, especially in the Greater China region, which
bolstered the Division’s results. Despite heavy declines in the first half of 2020, the market began to
recover throughout the remainder of the year and in 2021, as recovery continued, global industrial
production grew significantly.

In 2022, our Industrial Division’s was affected by the indirect effects of the challenging sector
environment resulting from sustained semiconductor shortages, the resurgence of the COVID-19
pandemic in China, and the war in Ukraine, which was offset by increased sales volumes. Based on
preliminary estimates, global industrial production in mechanical engineering, transport equipment
and electrical equipment for 2022, measured as gross value added based on constant prices and
exchange rates, slowed considerably to approximately 3.7% from the prior year level, with growth


-----

rates in the second and fourth quarters of 2022 significantly lower than the rest of the year. In the
Europe region, industrial production in those sectors grew by approximately 2.4%, with noticeable
weakening in the fourth quarter due to increasing energy costs. Industrial production in those sectors
in the Greater China region grew by 3.5%, where growth, particularly in the electrical equipment
sector, was offset by declines in the second quarter of the year due to the reimplementation of
COVID-19 lockdown measures. Industrial production in those sectors in the Americas region rose by
3.5% (2.7% in the U.S.), where similar growth rates were reported for the mechanical engineering
and transport equipment sectors. In the Asia/Pacific region, industrial production in those sectors
grew by 6.6%. In Japan, industrial production in those sectors grew 8.2% and in India it grew 2.4%,
primarily as a result of growth in the mechanical engineering sectors in those countries, while in
South Korea, growth in the mechanical engineering sector declined and contributed to a decline in
industrial production of 0.7% (Source: Oxford Economics, December 2022). In 2022, the Industrial
Division benefitted from a strong increase in sales volumes in the industrial distribution and in the
industrial automation sector clusters, primarily in the Europe region. Increased demand in the
Americas, Asia/Pacific and Greater China regions contributed to revenue growth for the Division as
well.

**_Operating Expenses_**

Our key operating expenses are production costs (including raw material and energy costs), selling
expenses, R&D expenses and administrative expenses.

_Raw Material and Energy Costs_

Most of the raw materials that we use, such as steel, aluminum, copper, plastics and lubricants, are
subject to price volatility. Commodity market price trends affect our cost to varying degrees and in
some instances with some delay, depending on the terms of the relevant supplier contracts. The
prices of our production materials primarily depend, directly or indirectly, on the trend in the prices
of scrap steel, coking coal, iron ore and non-ferrous metals. In addition to fixing purchase prices for
certain of our raw materials, such as steel, for six to twelve months by entering into forward
purchase contracts, we also entered into short-, medium-, and long-term price and supply
agreements to mitigate the risk of rising energy prices arising on energy purchases for our own use,
because this risk increased in 2022 as compared to prior years.

The global economic crisis resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic significantly disrupted the
commodities markets. Between January and April 2020, the prices of input materials key to our
operations considerably declined. However, with the third quarter economic rebound, prices rose
again, causing prices of nearly all of our key input materials to close at year-end at levels higher than
before the COVID-19 pandemic. This trend intensified throughout 2021, as strong demand continued
to drive drastic price increases for all input materials significant to us, with some prices even reaching
historic highs during the first half of the year, including steel in particular, which we use to
manufacture rolling bearings and automotive components.

In 2022, the war in Ukraine resulted in significant upward pressure on commodity prices and led to
an energy crisis, in particular in Europe, where imports of Russian natural gas were significantly
reduced. Prices surged in almost all of the commodity and energy markets important to the
Schaeffler Group. As the economic outlook deteriorated and demand for those commodities and
energy declined, prices began to fall throughout the rest of the year, with the most notable exception
being natural gas, for which prices did not peak until August 2022 as a result of the continuing supply
shortage. In Europe, natural gas prices reached historic highs in August 2022, which also caused a
surge in electricity prices in Europe due to the interconnectedness of the two markets. Natural gas
and electricity, which we use to operate our production machines, saw annual average prices in 2022
that were 136% and 75% above 2021 levels in Europe and the U.S., respectively. As a result of the
increase in natural gas prices, electricity prices in most of the EU doubled in 2022 as compared to


-----

2021. In the first half of 2022, steel prices remained at high levels worldwide, before falling in the
second half of the year, to a lower average price in 2022 as compared to 2021 (Source: S&P Global
Commodity Insight © [S&P Global Commodity Insight Pricing and Purchasing Forecasts, January
2023]). In Europe, prices for long steel products increased significantly in the second half of the year
due to the impact of the increase in energy costs on the energy intensive production process for long
steel (Source: S&P Global Commodity Insight © [S&P Global Commodity Insight Pricing and
Purchasing Forecasts, January 2023]). Prices of aluminum, which we use primarily for pressure die
castings, rose by 9% in 2022 as compared to 2021. Prices of copper, which we use primarily for
electric motors and mechatronic components, fell by 5% in 2022 as compared to 2021. Plastics,
which we use to produce cages for rolling bearings and lubricants, which we use both as
preservatives and to reduce friction in components, are often made from crude oil. In 2022, the
average price of crude oil rose by 42% as compared to 2021. Based on the Global Petrochemical
Index (IPEX) of the Independent Commodity Intelligence Service (ICIS), the average price of processed
petrochemical products, including the plastics we use, rose by 2% in 2022 as compared to 2021.

Increases in raw materials and energy prices could only be partially passed on to customers during
2022, which adversely affected margins in 2022. Overall, pricing dynamics are different among our
Divisions and businesses and price recovery is in most cases partial, and often delayed. For example,
in our Automotive Technologies Division, price recovery relies heavily on one-to-one customer
negotiations, which differ among customers and across regions. Comparatively, in our Industrial
Division, pricing initiatives have historically often demonstrated positive effects.

_Research and Development (“R&D”) Expenses_

Innovation regarding product development and production technology is important in order to
maintain the profitability of our business in the long term. R&D expenses reflect the cost of
undertaking R&D activities in our worldwide R&D centers. For accounting purposes, such costs are
predominantly expensed. R&D is key to an innovative and competitive portfolio of products, which in
turn is a key factor in our customers’ purchasing decisions. Therefore, our R&D efforts are focused
not only on strengthening existing business, but also on developing new business.

We employ approximately 7,400 R&D staff and operate a global R&D network comprising 20 R&D
centers and additional R&D locations in a total of 25 countries. Key locations outside Germany are
the U.S., China, South Korea, India and Brazil. While we reduced our R&D spend in absolute numbers
in 2020 in reaction to the COVID-19 pandemic, our R&D ratio remained relatively stable in 2020 and
2021, although it was affected by an accounting policy change relating to the accounting for
development services that we implemented as of January 1, 2021, but applied to 2020 figures
retrospectively. Our R&D ratio declined in 2022, primarily due to the over proportional increase in
revenue as compared to R&D expenses (revenue increased 14.1% while R&D expenses increased
2.7%), in particular due to currency exchange rate effects reflected in revenue.

**_Cost Efficiency Programs and Initiatives_**

We have implemented a number of corporate restructuring, cost saving and efficiency initiatives over
the past years in order to improve our operating efficiency and reduce our cost base. These
initiatives, some of which are ongoing, have had and will continue to have, a material impact on our
results of operations.

Since 2019, we have been implementing programs in each of our three Divisions in order to render
the respective Divisions more efficient and prepare them for future challenges and for the
transformation in mobility and motion that is primarily driven by new technological developments
and changing customer requirements. As part of these programs, we have implemented various
structural and operational measures worldwide, particularly in Germany and Europe, including
downsizing of our workforce (from 92,478 employees as of December 31, 2018 to 82,773 as of
December 31, 2022), adjusting and harmonizing pricing, taking a disciplined approach with respect to
personnel and R&D expenses, reducing overhead and other functional expenses, optimizing
inventory management, adjusting our product and customer portfolios, increasing productivity by,
for instance, enhancing utilization of machine capacity, and improving our capital expenditure ratio
by focusing on profitable products with a promising future. We also made selective business
disposals, including the disposal of our Clausthal-Zellerfeld site in 2021 and of the global chain drive
business of the Automotive Technologies Division in 2022.

In 2020, we implemented various measures to adopt our expenses to the abrupt change in demand
as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic in the first half of 2020, which helped stabilize our earnings
during 2020 when conditions were particularly difficult and sequentially improve them when
revenues rose again thereafter. In September 2020, as part of our restructuring measures, we
announced that we will gradually close our production plants in Eltmann, Wuppertal, and
Luckenwalde, Germany, and relocate their activities by July 2023. Operations at the Wuppertal,
Germany plant were discontinued in 2022.

In November 2022, we initiated further restructuring measures to boost our competitiveness for the
transition from combustion engines to electric mobility (“E-mobility”) and reduce fixed costs and
overcapacity, particularly in the Automotive Technologies Division. The measures include reducing
our headcount by 1,300 positions worldwide, mainly in the Engine and Transmission BD and the
Bearings BD and in our central functions. Within Germany, mainly the Herzogenaurach, Buehl and
Homburg locations will be affected. In Herzogenaurach and Buehl, we plan to adapt our internal
structures to new market conditions and future technologies, such as E-mobility and hydrogen. In
Homburg, we plan to increase automation and develop more efficient internal structures. In addition,
Ingolstadt and Morbach will be affected and strategies for these locations, which produce
components solely for combustion engine vehicles, are currently being developed in consultation
with employee representatives for those locations. The measures are expected to generate
restructuring expenses of approximately €130 million.

As a result of our corporate restructuring, in 2020, we recognized restructuring expenses of €681
million under the efficiency and portfolio optimization programs, primarily in connection with
downsizing the workforce to adjust excess structural capacity. In 2021, we recorded net restructuring
income of €10 million, mainly as a result of a partial reversal of a restructuring provision we had
previously established. In 2022, we recorded restructuring expenses of €173 million primarily related
to the additional structural measures adopted in November 2022.

We believe that the structural and efficiency measures we have implemented significantly
contributed to our ability to withstand the negative impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as the
negative impacts of the war in Ukraine and rising inflation during 2022. We also believe that the
measures we have implemented and are continuing to implement position us well for profitable
growth in the future. The efficiency and operating improvements we anticipate are based on our


-----

estimates and assumptions that are inherently uncertain, although we consider them to be
reasonable, and may be subject to significant business, economic and competitive uncertainties and
contingencies, all of which are difficult to predict and a number of which are beyond our control. See
also “Risk Factors—Risks related to our Business Operations and the Markets in which we operate—
_We may be unable to implement our efficiency and portfolio optimization and growth programs_
_successfully.”_

**_Exchange Rate Fluctuations_**

The Schaeffler Group conducts its business in a large number of countries and in several international
currencies. The most important currencies (in addition to the euro) for the Schaeffler Group, with
respect to transaction and/or transaction exposure, are the U.S. dollar, the Chinese renminbi, the
Indian rupee, the South Korean won, the Mexican peso and the Hungarian forint.

As the Schaeffler Group’s production capacity often matches demand on a regional basis, currency
effects primarily impact currency translation, which has a considerable impact on Schaeffler AG’s
consolidated financial statements, as they are prepared and/or calculated in euro, as well as other
Schaeffler Group key figures that are calculated in euro. Overall, currency exchange rate effects had a
negative effect on the revenues generated during 2020, a positive impact on the revenues generated
during 2021 and a positive impact on the revenues generated during 2022. In 2022, the Schaeffler
Group’s consolidated revenue increased by 14.1% and by 9.4% excluding the impact of foreign
currency translation (as compared to increases of 10.0% and 9.7%, respectively, during 2021). In the
future, these currency exchange rate effects may reverse and lead to a decrease or less pronounced
increase in reported revenues and other key figures of the Schaeffler Group (see “Risk Factors—Risks
_related to our Business Operations and the Markets in which we operate—We are exposed to risks_
_associated with changes in exchange rates and hedging and exchange rate fluctuations could_
_adversely affect our results of operations.”)._

**_Acquisitions_**

In addition to organic growth, we undertook a number of selective acquisitions since 2020 that have
affected or will affect our results of operations. We also expect to pursue selective investments and
acquisitions in businesses and areas with opportunities for growth in the future. When comparing
financial information for different periods, investors should take into account the differences
resulting from these acquisitions, as well as the resulting changes regarding the composition of the
Schaeffler Group.

_Acquisitions_

Ewellix AB and its subsidiaries (collectively, “Ewellix” or the “Ewellix Group”)

On January 3, 2023, we acquired 100% of the shares of Ewellix (the “Ewellix Acquisition”), a
manufacturer of innovative linear motion and actuation solutions used in assembly automation,
medical applications and mobile machinery. The Ewellix Group’s six manufacturing and customization
sites in Europe, the U.S. and Asia and 1,196 employees are now part of the Schaeffler Group (please
note that the Ewellix Group sites and employees are not consolidated with the Schaeffler Group
plants and employees for purposes of the discussions of the latter in this Offering Memorandum).
The aggregate purchase price paid for Ewellix amounted to €582 million. In addition, we repaid a
shareholder loan in the amount of €10 million and repaid outstanding amounts under the Ewellix
Group’s credit facilities in the amount of €109 million. Ewellix reported revenues of approximately
€216 million for 2021 and is currently expected to post revenues of approximately €250 million for
2022. The Ewellix Acquisition is expected to result in significant additional goodwill impact. See note
5.7 to the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements 2022.

The activities of the Ewellix Group are reported in our Industrial Division.


-----

SPV Solarpark 106. GmbH & Co. KG (“SPV Solarpark”)

On December 29, 2022, we acquired 100% of the shares of SPV Solarpark, which operates a solar
energy farm in Kammerstein, Germany, with a total area of just over 26 acres and an installed peak
capacity of almost 10 megawatts (“MW”), which is enough to supply about 2% of our electricity
requirements in Germany. The aggregate purchase price paid for SPV Solarpark amounted to €5
million. The acquisition resulted in additions to property, plant and equipment of €11 million and
assumed liabilities of €6 million. The impact on our results of operations in 2022 was insignificant.

CERASPIN S.à r.l. (“CERASPIN”)

On December 1, 2022, we acquired 100% of the shares of CERASPIN S.à r.l., a manufacturer of highquality ceramic components for roller bearings used in a wide range of strategic growth areas,
including wind energy, rail, aerospace, medical equipment, electrical engineering and the
semiconductor industry. The aggregate purchase price for CERASPIN amounted to €12 million. The
acquisition resulted in the recognition of goodwill in the amount of €4 million. The acquisition did not
have a material impact on our revenues in 2022.

The activities of CERASPIN are reported in our Industrial Division.

Schaeffler ByWire Technologie GmbH & Co. KG, formerly Schaeffler Paravan Technologie GmbH & Co.
KG (“Schaeffler ByWire”)

On October 14, 2022, we acquired the remaining 10% interest in Schaeffler Paravan Technologie
GmbH & Co. KG, that we did not already own, and subsequently changed the corporate name to
Schaeffler ByWire Technologie GmbH & Co. KG. Schaeffler ByWire develops and sells the steer-bywire steering technology (“Space Drive”), a key technology for autonomous driving. The purchase
price for the 10% interest amounted to €74 million. In addition, we have agreed to make payments
that are contingent on Schaeffler ByWire’s revenue from 2028 to 2030, which we expect to be in the
single-digit millions. The acquisition resulted in a negative impact of €5 million on our net income in
2022, since the acquisition closing.

The activities of Schaeffler ByWire are reported in our Automotive Technologies Division.

Schaeffler Ultra Precision Drives GmbH, formerly Melior Motion GmbH (“Schaeffler Ultra Precision
**Drives”)**

On February 1, 2022, we acquired 100% of the shares of Melior Motion GmbH, a manufacturer of
innovative precision gearboxes for industrial robots and subsequently changed the corporate name
to Schaeffler Ultra Precision Drives GmbH. The purchase price paid for Schaeffler Ultra Precision
Drives at closing amounted to €61 million. In addition, we have agreed to make earn-out payments of
up to €60 million based on Schaeffler Ultra Precision Drives’ revenue development during 2023 and
2024. The acquisition resulted in goodwill of €62 million. From the acquisition closing date to year
end, Schaeffler Ultra Precision Drives contributed €29 million to our revenues in 2022.

The activities of Schaeffler Ultra Precision Drives are reported in our Industrial Division.

Bega International B.V. (“Bega”)

On August 2, 2021, we acquired 100% of the shares of Bega International B.V., a manufacturer of
special tools for mounting and dismounting of rolling bearings. The aggregate purchase price for Bega
amounted to €14 million. The acquisition resulted in goodwill of €7 million. The impact on our results
of operations in 2021 was insignificant.

The activities of Bega are reported in our Industrial Division.

### Key Factors affecting Comparability

The financial information for the periods discussed in this Offering Memorandum are taken or
derived from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. Except as otherwise stated, financial
information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 has been taken or derived from the
comparative financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 included in the
Audited Consolidated Financial Statements 2021, and financial information as of and for the year
ended December 31, 2021 has been taken or derived from the comparative financial information as
of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements 2022. Accordingly, the financial information as of and for the year ended December 31,
2020 included herein may differ from the corresponding figures in the Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements 2020, and the financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021
included herein may differ from the corresponding figures in the Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements 2022.

The comparability of the financial information for the periods discussed in this Offering
Memorandum has been influenced by the following events, facts and developments.

**_Accounting Policy Changes_**

Effective as of January 1, 2022, we changed our accounting policy for operating assets (see the notes
to the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements 2022). As a result, starting in 2022, we began
reporting earnings before financial result and income taxes (EBIT) to include income (loss) from
equity-accounted investees. Figures for 2021 have been adjusted retrospectively (except in the
discussion under “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
_Operations of the Schaeffler Group—Results of Operations—Comparison of 2020 with 2021,” or as_
otherwise noted herein, to facilitate comparability between periods) to reflect this change. EBIT and
related figures for 2020 have not been adjusted retrospectively and may, therefore, not be fully
comparable to the figures for subsequent periods.

Effective as of January 1, 2021 we changed our accounting policy for development services. The new
accounting treatment, which was applied retrospectively, reflects the relationship between
development services and future volume production in a different manner. Under the new model,
development costs of all customer projects are capitalized as costs to fulfill a contract starting when a
volume contract with the customer becomes highly probable, and then amortized appropriately over
the period of volume production. Revenue is similarly accrued as a contract liability and realized over
the period of volume production as well. In addition, effective as of January 1, 2021, we changed the
presentation of expenses for production technology and for use of real estate. Figures for the year
ended December 31, 2020 included in the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements 2021 have
been adjusted retrospectively to reflect these accounting changes. The change presents the link
between development services and volume production in the financial information more accurately.
Previously, revenue was recognized for development services that represented a distinct, separately
identifiable performance obligation vis-à-vis the customer and for which we were entitled to
consideration under the contract. This revenue was recognized when the development services had
been rendered in full and the related expenses were expensed as cost of sales when revenue was
recognized. See note 1.4 to the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. Financial figures for the
year ended December 31, 2020 presented in this Offering Memorandum are taken or derived from
the comparative figures for 2020 included in the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements 2021.


-----

**_Schaeffler Group’s Segments_**

_Segment Structure_

We report financial information based on the following three Divisions: Automotive Technologies,
Automotive Aftermarket and Industrial.

_Customer Allocation to Segments_

The allocation of customers to segments is reviewed at least annually and adjusted where necessary.
In each of 2020, 2021 and 2022, such review resulted in the re-allocation of customers between
Divisions. To ensure that segment information is comparable between subsequent periods,
comparative information for the respective prior period included in the Audited Consolidated
Financial Statements for a period has been adjusted using the customer allocation structure from
such period.

_Regional Structure_

Under our matrix organization, we view our business not only in terms of divisions and functions, but
have also grouped it into four regions: Europe (Germany, Western Europe, Middle East & Africa,
Central & Eastern Europe), the Americas (the United States & Canada, Mexico, South America),
Greater China (including Mainland China, and also Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao) and Asia/Pacific
(South Korea, Japan, Southeast Asia and India).

### Explanation of Key Line Items 

**_Revenue_**

Our revenue is mainly derived from sales of bearings for automotive and industrial applications, as
well as transmission components and modules, engine components and systems. These applications,
components, modules and systems are sold to OEMs, Tier 1 and Tier 2 suppliers (i.e., suppliers that
sell their products to Tier 1 suppliers) and through the aftermarket.

**_Cost of Sales_**

Cost of sales consists primarily of the cost of producing products, rendering services or acquiring
merchandise sold. Production cost comprises all direct costs attributable to the process of
manufacturing goods and rendering services (e.g., raw materials, labor, depreciation of production
machinery) as well as allocated production-related overheads.

Our raw material costs are mainly related to steel, aluminum, copper, plastics and lubricants.

**_Gross Profit and Gross Margin_**

Our gross profit is defined as revenue less cost of sales. Gross margin is gross profit in relation to
revenue.

**_Research and Development Expenses_**

Our R&D expenses mainly comprise labor costs for personnel (e.g., for our R&D engineers).
Furthermore, material cost, service fees and amortization of machinery related to our R&D activities
are recognized in R&D expenses.

**_Selling Expenses_**

Our selling expenses generally comprise personnel expenses and general freight and logistics
expenses.


-----

**_Administrative Expenses_**

Our administrative expenses consist mainly of personnel expenses as well as depreciation.

**_Other Income and Other Expenses_**

Other income and other expenses mainly consist of gains and losses from foreign exchange, disposal
of assets, increase and decrease of allowances, refunds of antitrust fines and accruals for
restructurings and legal cases. In 2022, other income and other expenses also included gains and
losses, respectively, arising in connection with recognizing at fair value short-, medium-, and longterm price and supply agreements we entered into to secure our energy supply. In 2020, other
expenses included a goodwill impairment allocated to our Automotive Technologies Division of €249
million. See “—Results of Operations—Comparison of 2020 with 2021—Other Income and Expenses.”

Foreign currency risk arising from operating activities is estimated as the foreign currency exchange
risk from operating activities and investing activities relating to the next twelve months. Our main
foreign exchange exposure is to U.S. dollars and Chinese renminbi. The exposures are generally
hedged in line with the existing hedging strategy for the currency risk from operations of the next
twelve months, using appropriate derivative financial instruments, particularly forward exchange
contracts. Portfolio aspects and the current market environment are taken into account in executing
our hedging strategy.

**_EBIT_**

Effective as of January 1, 2022, EBIT is defined as earnings before financial result and income taxes.
Until December 1, 2021, we defined EBIT as earnings before financial result, income (loss) from
equity-accounted investees, and income taxes (see the notes to the Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements 2022). The discussion of EBIT for the years 2021 and 2022 under “—Results of
_Operations—Comparison of 2021 with 2022” below is based on EBIT pursuant to the new definition_
(and based on retrospectively adjusted figures for 2021), while the discussion for the years 2020 and
2021 under “—Results of Operations—Comparison of 2020 with 2021” below is based on the old
definition to facilitate comparability.

**_Financial Income_**

Financial income includes financial income on pension plan assets, fair value changes and
compensation payments on derivatives, foreign exchange gains, interest income on financial assets
and income from reversal of impairment losses on financial assets in the class “other loans
receivable” and for the year ended December 31, 2021, interest income on excess social tax
previously paid in Brazil, and for the year ended December 31, 2022, interest income on bank
balances in countries with foreign exchange restrictions and the change in the discount rate for
provisions.

**_Financial Expenses_**

Financial expenses mainly comprise interest expense on financial debt, amortization of cash flow
hedge accounting reserve, financial expense on pensions and partial retirement obligations, foreign
exchange losses and fair value changes and compensation payments on derivatives and, for the year
ended December 31, 2020, an impairment on an outstanding convertible loan receivable from a joint
venture.

Fair value changes and compensation payments on derivatives are due to compensation payments
and changes in the value of cross-currency derivatives as well as embedded derivatives.


-----

**_Financial Result_**

Our financial result consists of financial income and financial expenses. For more details, see “—
_Financial Income” and “—Financial Expenses.”_

**_Income Taxes_**

Our income taxes consist of current income taxes and deferred income taxes.

Consolidated revenue increased from €13,852 million in 2021 by €1,957 million, or 14.1%, to €15,809
million in 2022. Excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, consolidated revenue increased
by 9.4% in 2022. Revenue increased across all Divisions and regions in 2022. The growth in revenue
excluding the impact of currency translation was largely attributable to an increase in sales volumes
in each of the Automotive Technologies and Industrial Divisions as well as the favorable impact from
adjusted sales prices in all three Divisions, whereby a portion of increased procurement costs were
passed on to the market. The Automotive Technologies Division generated revenue growth of 7.7%
excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, which was attributable to increased sales
volumes as a result of increased market demand for automobile production, the favorable impact
from adjusted sales prices, as well as the low basis for comparison in 2021, which was marked by
supply shortages.


-----

The Automotive Aftermarket Division generated revenue growth of 7.0% excluding the impact of
foreign currency translation, which was primarily attributable to the favorable impact from adjusted
sales prices and sales volume growth that was partially offset by a considerable decline in sales
volumes in Central & Eastern Europe due to the war in Ukraine. The Industrial Division generated
revenue growth of 14.7% excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, mainly attributable to
higher sales volumes globally, and particularly in the Europe region, within the industrial distribution
and industrial automation sector clusters.

_Automotive Technologies Division_

The Automotive Technologies Division’s revenue increased by €1,064 million, or 12.6%, from €8,436
million in 2021 to €9,500 million in 2022. Excluding the impact of foreign currency translation,
revenue in the Automotive Technologies Division increased by 7.7%. The growth of the Automotive
Technologies Division’s revenue was attributable to increased sales volumes as a result of increased
market demand for automobile production, the favorable impact from adjusted sales prices, as well
as the low basis for comparison in 2021, which was marked by supply shortages. Growth in the EMobility and Chassis Systems BDs as a result of higher sales volumes driven by market demand and
product ramp-ups positively impacted revenue. Compared to the average growth rate of regional
automobile production volumes of 6.2% in 2022 (Source: S&P Global Mobility © [S&P Global Mobility
Light Vehicle Production Forecast (Base), January 2023]), at 7.7% growth, the Automotive
Technologies Division’s growth in revenue excluding the impact of foreign currency translation
exceeded the market trend in automobile production in 2022.

Revenue for the Europe region increased by 11.9%, or 11.8% excluding the impact of foreign currency
translation, in 2022, while automobile production increased by 0.6%. In the Americas region, revenue
increased by 26.0% in 2022, or 14.1% excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, while
automobile production increased by 9.3%. In the Greater China region, revenue increased by 5.7%, or
decreased by 1.4%, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, while automobile
production increased by 6.2%. The Asia/Pacific region reported revenue growth of 6.8%, or 4.5%,
excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, while automobile production increased by 9.0%
(Source: S&P Global Mobility © [S&P Global Mobility Light Vehicle Production Forecast (Base),
January 2023], regions reflect the regional structure of the Schaeffler Group).

The E-Mobility BD’s revenue increased by 29.9%, or 24.2% excluding the impact of foreign currency
translation in 2022. The Engine Systems and Transmission Systems BD’s revenue increased by 9.9% in
2022, or 4.5% excluding the impact of foreign currency translation. The Bearings BD’s revenue
increased by 8.3% in 2022, or 4.6% excluding the impact of foreign currency translation. The Chassis
Systems BD’s revenue increased by 30.5%, in 2022, or 28.4% excluding the impact of foreign currency
translation.

_Automotive Aftermarket Division_

The Automotive Aftermarket Division’s revenue increased by €190 million, or 10.3% (7.0% excluding
the impact of foreign currency translation), from €1,848 million in 2021 to €2,038 million in 2022. The
growth in revenue during the year was primarily attributable to the favorable impact from adjusted
sales prices and sales volume growth that was partially offset by a considerable decline in sales
volumes in Central & Eastern Europe due to the war in Ukraine. In the Europe region, the Automotive
Aftermarket Division’s revenue increased by 6.2% in 2022 (6.4% excluding the impact of foreign
currency translation), primarily driven by adjusted sales prices and an increase in sales volumes in the
second half of 2022. Higher sales volumes in the Western Europe and the Middle East & Africa
subregions more than offset the considerable decline in sales volumes in Central & Eastern Europe
due to the war in Ukraine. In the Americas region, the Automotive Aftermarket Division’s revenue
increased by 19.6% (6.5% excluding the impact of foreign currency translation), primarily driven by
the favorable impact from adjusted sales prices, which offset the negative impact of decreased sales


-----

volumes in the automotive OES business in the U.S. & Canada subregion, which were not fully offset
by increased sales volumes in the independent aftermarket business in the South American and
Mexico subregion. In the Greater China region, revenue grew by 15.1% (or 6.7% excluding the impact
of foreign currency translation), mainly due to the expansion of the Division’s e-commerce business.
In the Asia/Pacific region, revenue grew by 21.5% (or 16.4% excluding the impact of foreign currency
translation), mainly due to higher sales volumes in the independent aftermarket business in India.

_Industrial Division_

The Industrial Division’s revenue increased by €704 million, or 19.7% (14.7% excluding the impact of
foreign currency translation), from €3,568 million in 2021 to €4,271 million in 2022. This increase was
primarily attributable to the strong increase in sales volumes in the industrial distribution and in the
industrial automation sector clusters globally, and particularly in the Europe region. All market
regions of the Industrial Divisions increased their revenue, with the Europe and Asia/Pacific regions
reporting the highest growth rates. Revenue in the Europe region increased by 19.8% (20.4%
excluding the impact of foreign currency translation), primarily due to the strong increase in sales
volumes referenced above. Revenue in the Asia/Pacific region increased by 17.5% (13.2% excluding
the impact of foreign currency translation), primarily due to volume growth in the industrial
distribution and two wheelers sector clusters. Revenue in the Americas region increased by 25.0%
(11.6% excluding the impact of foreign currency translation), were attributable to both higher sales
volumes and a favorable impact of sales prices in industrial distribution and the offroad and raw
materials sector clusters. In the Greater China region, revenue grew by 17.7% (8.8%) excluding the
impact of foreign currency translation), mainly due to increased volumes in the raw materials and
industrial automation clusters and increased volumes in the wind sector cluster in the second half of
2022.

**_R&D Expenses_**

R&D expenses increased by €20 million, or 2.7%, from €748 million in 2021 to €768 million in 2022.
R&D expenses increased in our Automotive Technologies Division from €602 million in 2021 to €604
million in 2022. R&D expenses increased from €16 million in 2021 to €18 million in 2022 in our
Automotive Aftermarket Division. R&D expenses increased from €130 million in 2021 to €146 million
in 2022 in our Industrial Division. In 2022, R&D expenses represented 4.9% of our revenue, a
decrease of 0.5 percentage points from 5.4% in 2021.

**_Selling Expenses_**

Selling expenses increased from €977 million in 2021 by €148 million, or 15.2%, to €1,126 million in
2022. This increase was primarily due to higher freight and logistics costs.

**_Administrative Expenses_**

Administrative expenses increased from €540 million in 2021 by €69 million, or 12.7%, to €609
million in 2022. This increase was primarily due to increased expenses in connection with
digitalization and sustainability activities.

EBIT decreased from €1,220 million in 2021 by €247 million, or 20.2%, to €974 million in 2022. As a
result, the EBIT margin decreased by 2.7 percentage points, from 8.8% in 2021 to 6.2% in 2022. EBIT
in 2022 was adversely affected by special items in the amount of €72 million.

Special items in 2022 relating to restructuring had a negative effect on EBIT of €173 million and were
mainly attributable to the further restructuring measures initiated in November 2022 and expenses
related to the consolidation of our footprint in Europe. Special items related to M&A had a net
positive effect on EBIT of €5 million and were mainly attributable to the revaluation gain related to a
business combination achieved in stages. Other special items in 2022 of €97 million, mainly affecting
the Automotive Technologies and Industrial Divisions, related to net gains that arose in connection


-----

with recognizing at fair value short-, medium-, and long-term price and supply agreements we
entered into to secure our energy supply.

In 2021, special items in the amount of €1 million adversely affected EBIT. Special items in 2021
relating to restructurings had a net positive effect on EBIT of €10 million and were mainly
attributable to the Roadmap 2025 divisional sub-programs, resulting in a reversal of a restructuring
provision established in the previous year, since the cost of implementing certain structural measures
was less than the originally planned costs, while expenses of consolidating the footprint in Europe
had a partially offsetting effect. Special items for restructurings in 2021 also included an adjustment
to a provision for the setup of a shared services center started in 2017. Special items relating to legal
cases in 2021 had a net positive effect of €32 million and primarily included income related to a court
ruling and related follow-up litigation in Brazil. Other special items in 2021, with a negative effect on
EBIT of €43 million, included adjustments for expenses of remediating past environmental impacts
and rehabilitating commercial land, the effect on net income of reversing an impact of foreign
currency translation related to a subsidiary that is no longer consolidated as it is no longer active, and
special projects.

Accordingly, EBIT before special items, or Adjusted EBIT, decreased to €1,046 million in 2022 (prior
year: €1,222 million), and the EBIT margin before special items decreased from 8.8% by 2.2
percentage points to 6.6% (prior year: 8.8%). The decrease in EBIT margin before special items in
2022 was primarily due to the lower gross profit margin, which resulted from significantly higher
procurement costs that were only partly offset by adjustments to sales prices, as well as higher
freight and logistics costs.

The Automotive Technologies Division’s total EBIT decreased from €579 million in 2021 by
€327 million, to €253 million in 2022. The Automotive Technologies Division’s EBIT margin decreased
by 4.2 percentage points from 6.9% in 2021 to 2.7% in 2022. Special items recognized by the
Automotive Technologies Division in 2022 had a negative impact on EBIT of €39 million. In 2021,
special items of the Automotive Technologies Division positively affected EBIT by €35 million.
Accordingly, EBIT before special items decreased to €292 million in 2022 (prior year: €544 million),
and the EBIT margin before special items decreased to 3.1% (prior year: 6.4%). The decrease in EBIT
margin before special items was primarily due to the lower gross profit margin, which resulted from
significantly higher procurement costs, which were only partially offset by adjustments to sales prices
as well as the negative impact of volatility in customer call-off orders, which negatively impacted
production efficiency. The main additional adverse impact came from higher freight and logistics
costs.

The Automotive Aftermarket Division’s total EBIT decreased from €274 million in 2021 by €24 million,
or 8.6%, to €251 million in 2022. The Automotive Aftermarket Division’s EBIT margin decreased from
14.8% in 2021 to 12.3% in 2022. EBIT in 2022 was negatively impacted by €5 million in special items,
as compared to 2021 when EBIT was positively affected by €18 million in special items. As a result,
EBIT before special items decreased to €255 million in 2022 (prior year: €256 million), and the EBIT
margin before special items decreased to 12.5% (prior year: 13.9%). The decrease in the EBIT margin
before special items was primarily due to higher selling expenses, partly attributable to the prior year
impact of a favorable one-off item related to the reimbursement of expenses by a service provider
for the AKO.

The Industrial Division’s total EBIT increased from €367 million in 2021 by €103 million to
€470 million in 2022. The Industrial Division’s EBIT margin increased from 10.3% in 2021 to 11.0% in
2022. In 2022, EBIT was adversely negatively affected by special items amounting to €28 million, as
compared to 2021 when EBIT was negatively affected by €55 million in special items. As a result, EBIT
before special items increased by €77 million, or 18.3% to €499 million (prior year: €421 million). The
Division’s EBIT margin before special items remained stable at 11.7% in 2022 (prior year: 11.8%)
despite the negative impacts of significantly higher procurement costs as well as freight and logistics


-----

costs and non-operating one-off items, which were offset by adjustments to sales prices and
economies of scale realized due to increased sales volumes, which improved the gross profit margin
and decreased functional costs as a percentage of revenue.
