Consolidated revenue increased from €12,589 million in 2020 by €1,263 million, or 10.0%, to €13,852
million in 2021. Excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, consolidated revenue increased
by 9.7% in 2021. Revenue increased across all Divisions and regions in 2021. The Automotive
Technologies Division generated revenue growth of 7.4% excluding the impact of foreign currency
translation, which was attributable to the increase in demand in the first half of 2021 from the very
low basis in the first half of 2020. In the second half of 2021, growing bottlenecks in global supply
chains, particularly those for semiconductors, significantly reduced customers’ call-off orders and
considerably lowered sales volumes of the Automotive Technologies Division, driven by the market.
Unlike the Automotive Technologies Division, the Automotive Aftermarket and Industrial Divisions
grew in the second half of 2021 as well, resulting in both Divisions generating full-year growth rates
of 12.6% and 13.9%, respectively (13.0% and 13.6%, respectively, excluding the impact of foreign
currency translation).

_Automotive Technologies Division_

The Automotive Technologies Division’s revenue increased by €620 million, or 7.9%, from €7,816
million in 2020 to €8,436 million in 2021. Excluding the impact of foreign currency translation,
revenue in the Automotive Technologies Division increased by 7.4%. The growth of the Automotive
Technologies Division’s revenue was attributable to the increase in sales volumes for the first half of
2021 from the low basis for comparison across all BDs and regions. In the second half of 2021,
however, the Division’s revenue was adversely affected by supply chain disruptions, particularly the
global semiconductor shortage and the reduction in the production of passenger cars and Iight
commercial vehicles by more than 10% (Source: S&P Global Mobility © [S&P Global Mobility Light
Vehicle Production Forecast (Base), January 2023]), which significantly reduced customer demand,
while the second half of 2020 had already been characterized by noticeable catch-up effects
following the significant declines in the first half of the year. In contrast to the general market trend,
the E-Mobility BD ended the second half of 2021 slightly ahead of the prior year level due in part to
product ramp-ups, generating a full-year growth rate well into the double-digits. Compared to the
average growth rate of regional automobile production volumes of 3.4% in 2021 (Source: S&P Global
Mobility © [S&P Global Mobility Light Vehicle Production Forecast (Base), January 2023]), at 7.4%
growth, the Automotive Technologies Division’s growth in revenue excluding the impact of foreign
currency translation exceeded the market trend in automobile production in 2021.

Revenue for the Europe region increased by 6.7%, or 7.1% excluding the impact of foreign currency
translation in 2021, while automobile production declined by 2.5%. In the Americas region, revenue
increased by 5.5% in 2021 or 6.8% excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, while
automobile production increased by 2.5%. In the Greater China region, revenue increased by 9.2% or


-----

5.7% excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, while automobile production increased by
5.6%. The Asia/Pacific region reported revenue growth of 12.6%, or 13.8% excluding the impact of
foreign currency translation, while automobile production increased by 7.7% (Source: S&P Global
Mobility © [S&P Global Mobility Light Vehicle Production Forecast (Base), January 2023], regions
reflect the regional structure of the Schaeffler Group).

The E-Mobility BD’s revenue increased by 18.9%, or 17.8% excluding the impact of foreign currency
translation in 2021. The Engine Systems BD’s revenue increased by 4.9% in 2021. Excluding the
impact of foreign currency translation, revenue increased by 4.8%. The Transmission Systems BD’s
revenue increased by 6.6% in 2021. Excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, revenue
increased by 6.4%. The Chassis Systems BD’s revenue increased by 7.4%, in 2021. Excluding the
impact of foreign currency translation, the Chassis Systems BD’s revenue increased by 7.1%.

_Automotive Aftermarket Division_

The Automotive Aftermarket Division’s revenue increased by €206 million, or 12.6% (13.0% excluding
the impact of foreign currency translation), from €1,642 million in 2020 to €1,848 million in 2021. The
considerable growth in revenue during the year was attributable to the increase in sales volumes in
the first half of 2021 from the very low basis for comparison across all BDs and regions. Although the
Automotive Aftermarket Division’s revenue for the second half of 2021 was close to flat with the first
half of 2021, the growth rate nevertheless declined considerably over the course of the year since
the second half of 2020 had already been marked by noticeable catch-up effects following the heavy
slumps earlier that year. Full-year revenue recovered across all regions compared to 2020;
considerably higher sales volumes in the Europe and Americas regions were the main drivers behind
the Division’s growth. In the Central & Eastern Europe, Western Europe, South America, and U.S. &
Canada subregions, the IAM business, in particular, grew considerably. The OES business in the
subregions of Germany and Western Europe grew substantially as well. In addition, the Greater China
region significantly expanded its e-commerce business in the fiscal year 2021, which contributed a
majority of the Division’s growth in the region. The growth reported by the Asia/Pacific region
resulted mainly from considerably higher sales volumes in both the independent aftermarket and
original equipment manufacturer businesses in India.

_Industrial Division_

The Industrial Division’s revenue increased by €436 million, or 13.9% (13.6% excluding the impact of
foreign currency translation), from €3,132 million in 2020 to €3,568 million in 2021. This increase was
primarily attributable to strong growth in industrial distribution, industrial automation, power
transmission and offroad sector clusters. Throughout the year, regional revenue trends varied, for
example, while the revenue trend in the Europe region remained moderate in the first half of 2021,
the Division generated considerable growth in the region throughout the second half of 2021,
especially in the industrial distribution and in the industrial automation and power transmission
sector clusters. In contrast, the Greater China region experienced a considerable decrease in its
growth rate in the second half of 2021, primarily due to a heavy decline in demand in the wind sector
cluster following a pull-forward effect due to the anticipated termination of subsidies for offshore
wind turbines at year-end 2020. The America’s region revenue trend was primarily attributable to
growth in the industrial distribution cluster. Growth in the Asia/Pacific region resulted primarily from
increased volumes in India, mainly due to the wind, two-wheelers and offroad sector clusters as well
as industrial distribution cluster.

percentage points to 29.4% in 2021, primarily due to economies of scale.

**_R&D Expenses_**

R&D expenses increased by €64 million, or 9.4%, from €684 million in 2020 to €748 million in 2021,
mainly as a result of the lower base in 2020, when we adjusted our R&D expenses in line with the
lower revenues in light of the COVID-19 pandemic. R&D expenses increased in our Automotive
Technologies Division from €540 million in 2020 to €601 million in 2021. R&D expenses decreased
from €18 million in 2020 to €15 million in 2021 in our Automotive Aftermarket Division. R&D
expenses increased from €126 million in 2020 to €131 million in 2021 in our Industrial Division. In
2021, R&D expenses represented 5.4% of our revenue in line with 5.4% in 2020.


-----

**_Selling Expenses_**

Selling expenses increased from €881 million in 2020 by €96 million, or 10.9%, to €977 million in
2021. This increase was primarily due to the recovery of business in 2021 from a low base in 2020 as
well as to the commencement of operations of the Automotive Aftermarket Division’s assembly and
packaging center. Favorable one-off items in selling expenses related to an agreement reached on a
retroactive reimbursement of expenses by a service provider as well as higher sales volumes had an
offsetting impact.

**_Administrative Expenses_**

Administrative expenses increased from €491 million in 2020 by €49 million, or 10.1%, to
€540 million in 2021. This increase was primarily due to the recovery of business in 2021 from a low
base in 2020.

** Effective as of January 1, 2022, we changed our accounting policy for operating assets (see the notes to the Audited Consolidated
Financial Statements 2022). As a result, starting in 2022, we began reporting earnings before financial result and income taxes (EBIT) to
include income (loss) from equity-accounted investees. Figures for 2021 have been adjusted retrospectively. EBIT and related figures
for 2020 have not been adjusted retrospectively and may, therefore, not be fully comparable to the figures for subsequent periods.
See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Presentation of Financial Information” and “—Key Factors affecting
_Comparability—Accounting Policy Changes.”_

EBIT increased from a negative €149 million in 2020 by €1,413 million to €1,264 million in 2021. As a
result, the EBIT margin improved from a negative 1.2% in 2020 by to 9.1% in 2021.

EBIT in 2021 was adversely affected by special items in the amount of €1 million. Special items in
2021 relating to restructurings had a net positive effect on EBIT of €10 million and were mainly
attributable to the Roadmap 2025 divisional sub-programs, resulting in a reversal of a restructuring
provision established in the previous year, since the cost of implementing certain structural measures
was less than the originally planned costs, while expenses of consolidating the footprint in Europe
had a partially offsetting effect. Special items for restructurings in 2021 also included an adjustment
to a provision for the setup of a shared services center started in 2017. Special items relating to legal
cases in 2021 had a net positive effect of €32 million and primarily included income related to a court
ruling and related follow-up litigation in Brazil. Other special items in 2021, with a negative effect on
EBIT of €43 million, included adjustments for expenses of remediating past environmental impacts
and rehabilitating commercial land, the effect on net income of reversing an impact of foreign
currency translation related to a subsidiary that is no longer consolidated as it is no longer active, and
special projects.

Special items in 2020 amounted to €946 million and included €681 million in expenses incurred to
expand the efficiency and portfolio optimization programs, especially in connection with downsizing
the workforce to adjust excess structural capacity. €580 million of these expenses related to the
package of measures adopted in September 2020. In addition, we recognized an impairment charge


-----

in relation to goodwill allocated to the Automotive Technologies Division in the amount of €249
million, which was recognized in 2020 because the COVID-19 pandemic led to increased uncertainty
and, therefore, to changes in the assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount of groups
of cash-generating units. Special items in 2020 also included €21 million for legal risks.

Accordingly, EBIT before special items, or Adjusted EBIT, increased to €1,266 million in 2021 (prior
year: €798 million), and the EBIT margin before special items increased to 9.1% (prior year: 6.3%).
The increase in EBIT margin before special items in 2021 was primarily due to economies of scale
during the first half of 2021, which resulted in an improved gross margin, as well as structural cost
reduction measures. In the second half of 2021, the market-driven decline in sales volumes in the
Automotive Technologies Division, in addition to the increased procurement costs, negatively
impacted EBIT before special items.

The Automotive Technologies Division’s total EBIT increased from a negative €344 million in 2020 by
€964 million, to €620 million in 2021. The EBIT margin increased from a negative 4.4% in 2020 to
7.4% in 2021. Special items recognized by the Automotive Technologies Division in 2021 had a
positive impact on EBIT of €35 million. In 2020, special items of the Automotive Technologies Division
negatively affected EBIT by €608 million. Accordingly, EBIT before special items increased to €585
million in 2021 (prior year: €263 million), and the EBIT margin before special items increased to 6.9%
(prior year: 3.4%). The increase in EBIT margin before special items was primarily due to economies
of scale during the first half of 2021 and production costs that remained low at the time, particularly
in the first quarter, which resulted in a significantly improved gross margin. Structural cost reduction
measures previously implemented also had a positive impact. In the second half of 2021, the
significant market-driven decline in sales volumes as well as the significant increase in procurement
costs had a growing adverse impact on EBIT before special items.

The Automotive Aftermarket Division’s total EBIT increased from €228 million in 2020 by €44 million,
or 19.3%, to €272 million in 2021. The EBIT margin increased from 13.9% in 2020 by 0.8 percentage
points to 14.7% in 2021. EBIT in 2021 was positively impacted by €18 million in special items, as
compared to 2020 when EBIT was negatively affected by €30 million in special items. As a result, EBIT
before special items decreased to €254 million in 2021 (prior year: €258 million), and the EBIT margin
before special items decreased to 13.8% (prior year: 15.7%). The decrease in the EBIT margin before
special items is attributable to higher product expenses that considerably decreased the gross profit
margin and increased selling expenses related to the commencement of operations at the assembly
and packaging center. Higher sales volumes as well as favorable one-off items in selling expenses
related to an agreement on a retroactive reimbursement of expenses by a service provider had an
offsetting impact.

The Industrial Division’s total EBIT increased from a negative €33 million in 2020 by €404 million to
€372 million in 2021. The EBIT margin increased from a negative 1.0% in 2020 to 10.4% in 2021. EBIT
for 2021 was adversely affected by special items amounting to €55 million. In 2020, EBIT was
adversely affected by special items amounting to €309 million. As a result, EBIT before special items
increased by €150 million, or 54.4% to €426 million (prior year: €276 million). The Division’s EBIT
margin before special items increased by 3.2 percentage points to 12.0% (prior year: 8.8%) largely
driven by economies of scale, which improved the gross profit margin and decreased functional costs
as a percentage of revenue, as well as by the structural cost reduction measures expanded in 2020.

### Liquidity and Capital Resources

For 2020, 2021, and 2022, our principal source of liquidity was cash generated from operating
activities. Our liquidity requirements arise primarily from the need to fund our working capital
requirements and capital expenditures, including acquisitions, to make interest and principal
payments on our indebtedness and to make dividend payments to our shareholders. As of December
31, 2022, we had cash and cash equivalents totaling €1,063 million, of which €241 million related to
countries with foreign exchange restrictions and other legal and contractual restrictions, such as
Brazil, South Korea and India. We also have the €500 million Schaeffler Group Term Loan Facility (of
which €350 million were drawn on January 2, 2023, and we intend to draw the additional €150
million available in March 2023) and the €2.0 billion Schaeffler Group Revolving Facility (of which €55
million were utilized as of December 31, 2022, in the form of letters of credit), each under the
Schaeffler Group Syndicated Facilities Agreement. In addition, we have certain committed lines of
credit available to us in the equivalent of approximately €118 million, of which €17 million were
utilized as of December 31, 2022, primarily in the form of letters of credit. We have also established
the Schaeffler Group Commercial Paper Program, of which €50 million (book value: €50 million) was
utilized as of December 31, 2022. We expect to meet our working capital, capital expenditures
according to cash flow statement, dividend payment and investment requirements for the next
twelve months primarily through cash flows from operating activities. We may also, from time to
time, seek other sources of funding, which may include debt or equity financings, depending on our
financing needs and market conditions.

**_Cash Flows from Operating Activities_**

Cash flows from operating activities decreased from €1,276 million in 2021 by €137 million, or 10.8%
to €1,139 million in 2022. This decrease was primarily due to the €223 million decline in EBITDA over
the prior year as a result of increased non-cash expenses, in particular related to the additional
structural measures adopted in November 2022. Cash flows from operating activities in 2021 were
adversely affected by restructuring expenditures and an expansion of working capital. Cash outflows
from working capital of €340 million in 2022 increased by €52 million from €288 million in 2021,
driven by the increase in business activity and sales volumes. €240 million of the change from the
prior year period was due to higher trade receivables and lower trade payables of €240 million and
€91 million, respectively. A decrease in inventories had an offsetting impact of €277 million.

Cash flows from operating activities increased from €1,254 million in 2020 by €22 million, or 1.7% to
€1,276 million in 2021. This increase was primarily due to the €1,119 million improvement in EBITDA
over the prior year. EBITDA in 2020 was negatively affected by largely non-cash restructuring
expenses related to the structural measures taken in Europe. Cash flows from operating activities in
2021 were adversely affected by restructuring expenditures and an expansion of working capital.
Cash outflows from working capital of €288 million increased by €279 million from €10 million in
2020, driven by the increase in business activity. €694 million of the change from the prior year
period was due to an increase in inventories. Lower trade receivables and higher trade payables had
an offsetting impact of €119 million and €298 million, respectively.

**_Cash Flows from Investing Activities_**

Cash outflow for investing activities consisted of €990 million in 2022, €716 million in 2021 and €642
million in 2020. Of these outflows, capital expenditures on property, plant and equipment and on
intangible assets amounted to €791 million in 2022, €671 million in 2021, and €633 million in 2020
(see “—Capital Expenditures,” which describes the balance sheet impact of our capital expenditures).
Cash outflow for M&A activities (net cash flow used for/from acquisition and disposal of subsidiaries
and interests in joint ventures) in 2022 was €195 million, which was primarily related to the
acquisitions of SPV Solarpark, CERASPIN, Schaeffler ByWire and Schaeffler Ultra Precision Drives,
which was partially offset by proceeds from the sale the global chain drive business of the
Automotive Technologies Division. Cash outflow for M&A activities (net cash flow used for/from
acquisition and disposal of subsidiaries and interests in joint ventures) in 2021 was €23 million
(approximately a third of which related to the acquisition of Bega International B.V.). Cash inflow
from M&A activities in 2020 consisted of €12 million, relating to a refund of a portion of the purchase
price for the acquisition of the interests in Elmotec Statomat GmbH in 2019 and to the disposal of
Schaeffler Bio-hybrid GmbH.

**_Cash Flows from Financing Activities_**

Cash from financing activities consisted of an outflow of €891 million in 2022, €527 million in 2021,
and an inflow of €526 million in 2020. Outflows of €336 million, €165 million and €298 million related
to dividends paid to shareholders and non-controlling interests in 2022, 2021 and 2020, respectively.

In 2022, changes in financial debt resulted in €547 million in net cash outflows and related mainly to
the redemption of bonds in the amount of €545 million.

In 2021, changes in financial debt resulted in €302 million in net cash outflows and related mainly to
the redemption of €259 million in principal amount of Schaeffler Group Promissory Notes in October

As of December 31, 2022, our financial debt amounted to €3,298 million (€3,238 million non-current

in connection with the Ewellix Acquisition, we drew €350 million under the Schaeffler Group Term
Loan Facility on January 2, 2023 and we expect to draw the remaining €150 million available under
the Schaeffler Group Term Loan Facility in March 2023 to replenish cash on hand used for the Ewellix
Acquisition in January 2023. The main sources of financing made available to us are the Schaeffler
Group Term Loan Facility, the Schaeffler Group Revolving Facility, the Schaeffler Group Notes and the
Schaeffler Group Promissory Notes (Schuldscheine) as described below. We also have access to
various bilateral lines of credit, the Schaeffler Group Factoring Program established in 2021 and the
Schaeffler Group Commercial Paper Program established in 2019.

Schaeffler AG is party to a €2.5 billion syndicated ESG linked term loan and revolving credit facilities

_Dividend Policy of Schaeffler AG_

Schaeffler AG aims to balance the expectations of investors with regard to dividend payments with
the profit retention requirements of Schaeffler AG to secure its capital base and to support its
ambition for long-term continuity and value creation. Schaeffler AG intends to pay dividends in the
ordinary course of business of between 30% and 50% of the Schaeffler Group’s annual net income
before special items. However, there can be no assurance with respect to any given year that
Schaeffler AG will pay dividends in this amount or at all.

The holders of the non-voting shares benefit from preferred dividend payments of €0.01 per share. In
determining whether or not to declare a dividend, the Board of Managing Directors will take into
account its view of the general business environment and market conditions, the Schaeffler Group’s
operating results, its operating cash flow, its investment and capital management initiatives, its
future funding and financing requirements, its ambition to maintain a sound and solid capital
structure, taxation considerations, any contractual, legal or regulatory restrictions on the payment of
dividends and any other factors that it may deem relevant.

In April 2022, we paid a dividend of €0.50 per non-voting share and €0.49 per voting share for the
fiscal year 2021, for a total dividend pay-out of €328 million to the shareholders of Schaeffler AG.
Dividends paid 2021 (for 2020) consisted of a dividend of €0.25 per non-voting share and €0.24 per
voting share, for a total dividend pay-out of €162 million. Dividends paid in 2020 (for 2019) consisted
of a dividend of €0.45 per non-voting share and €0.44 per voting share, for a total dividend pay-out
of €295 million to shareholders of Schaeffler AG. In the invitation to Schaeffler AG’s annual general
meeting of shareholders, which is scheduled to be held on April 20, 2023, the Board of Managing
Directors and the Supervisory Board have proposed a dividend for the fiscal year 2022 of €0.45 per
non-voting share and €0.44 per voting share, which, if approved, would amount to a total dividend
payout of €295 million.

### Qualitative Disclosure on Market Risk

We are exposed to a number of financial risks arising from the ordinary course of business, such as
credit risks, interest rate risks and currency risks. See also “Financial risk management” in note 4.16
to the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements 2022 included elsewhere in this Offering
Memorandum.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that we will not be able to meet our payment obligations as they come due.
Our approach to managing liquidity risk is to ensure that there is always sufficient liquidity available
to meet liabilities as they come due without incurring unacceptable losses or risking damage to our
reputation. We monitor and manage short-and medium-term liquidity risk using a rolling liquidity
budget with a forecasting period of up to fourteen months.

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk is the risk that we will incur a financial loss as a result of a default by a customer or
business partner. Credit risk arising on trade receivables is managed by continuously monitoring
customers’ financial status, creditworthiness and payment history. Additional measures we use to
manage credit risk include efficient collection procedures and the use of commercial credit insurance.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

Due to our obligations under floating-rate debt instruments, such as the Schaeffler Group Revolving
Facility or the Schaeffler Group Term Loan Facility, we are, in principle, subject to an interest rate risk
relating to fluctuations in the EURIBOR. Our interest rate risk is presently not hedged with specific
instruments (e.g., interest rate swaps, caps and collars). Interest rate risk and the development of
interest rate markets are continually monitored and reported to our CFO.

**_Currency Risk_**

We are exposed to diverse foreign exchange risks due to our international presence. The focus on
hedging is on transaction risk, i.e., the impact from currency fluctuations on our future cash flow, and
financial risk, i.e., the impact from currency fluctuations on payments due under a portion of our
external financial debt denominated in a currency other than euro. The largest transaction foreign
currency risks result from exchange rate fluctuations of the U.S. dollar and Chinese renminbi.
Potential foreign currency fluctuations have an effect on revenue as well as on purchase costs.

### Critical Accounting Principles

In the preparation of financial statements in accordance with IFRS, management exercises judgment
in making appropriate estimates and assumptions affecting the application of accounting policies and
the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, income and expenses. Critical accounting principles are
those that (i) are relevant to the presentation of our financial condition and results of operations and
(ii) require management’s most difficult, subjective or complex judgments, often as a result of the
need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain. Actual amounts
may differ from these estimates.

As the number of variables and assumptions affecting the possible future resolution of the
uncertainties increase, those judgments become even more subjective and complex.

For a summary of factors affecting estimation uncertainty and management judgment, see note 1.2
and for a summary of our significant accounting policies see note 1.3 of the Audited Consolidated
Financial Statements 2022.

### Markets

We develop and manufacture high-precision components, systems and services for powertrains and
chassis, as well as rolling and plain bearing solutions for various industry applications. This includes
innovative and sustainable technologies for hybrid, electric and combustion-engine powered
vehicles. Our offering comprises solutions for automated and autonomous driving, components and
systems for rotary and linear motion, as well as services, maintenance products and monitoring
systems for a wide range of industrial applications. Our portfolio also includes OEM-quality repair
solutions and associated supporting services for the global automotive aftermarket.

### Automotive Technologies

We offer products to customers in the automotive sector. These customers include OEMs and their
suppliers (Tier 1 and Tier 2). Products range from E-Mobility solutions (such as electric motors,
electric axle transmissions, electric axle drives, power electronics, hybrid modules, electromechanical
and hydraulic actuators, components for fuel cells, and thermal management modules) to
components and systems for engines (such as valve-lash adjustment elements, variable valve train
systems, and camshaft phasing systems) to components and systems for transmissions (such as
solutions for double-clutch, manual, automated and automatic transmissions (for example, torque
converters, hybrid dampers and clutches)) to chassis components (such as wheel bearings and
mechatronic systems for active chassis, including for autonomous mobility) to bearings, which largely
powertrain agnostic and are utilized in many engine, transmission and chassis components and
systems, such as wheel bearings and needle rolling bearings.

**_Definition, Size and Structure_**

The global automotive OEM industry designs, develops, manufactures and sells light vehicles and
commercial vehicles. The light vehicle segment consists of passenger cars, vans and light trucks (all
weighing less than six tons), while the heavy and medium vehicle segment is generally defined as the
market for vehicles with a weight of more than six tons. In 2022, approximately 82 million light
vehicles were produced globally (Source: S&P Global Mobility © [S&P Global Mobility Light Vehicle
Production Forecast (Base), January 2023]).

The automotive production value chain is broken down into OEMs, such as Daimler AG, Ford Motor
Company, Toyota Motor Corporation, Zhejiang Geely Holding Group Co. Ltd and Volkswagen AG, and
automotive part suppliers, such as the Schaeffler Group, BorgWarner Inc., Continental AG, Vitesco
AG, Valeo S.A., and ZF Friedrichshafen AG. The automotive part supplier market is further segmented
into three different tiers. Tier 1 suppliers produce technologies, systems and solutions geared


-----

towards finished products and work directly with OEMs. Tier 2 suppliers produce specialized parts
and components and sell these products to Tier 1 suppliers, and Tier 3 suppliers provide raw
materials and other products. In general, suppliers develop components and systems on the basis of
agreements with OEMs to meet their technological and regulatory requirements.

**_Growth Drivers_**

In the OEM market, revenue of automotive suppliers is primarily driven by global light vehicle
production volume and the content per vehicle for the components and systems produced by such
suppliers. Although suppliers will have contracts for particular vehicle platforms, the actual
production volume is rarely fixed and may vary depending on macro and other contingent factors.
The economic environment is generally the most significant factor, regulations and government
policies (such as increasingly strict standards for CO2 emissions or buying incentives) increase
demand for products that help reduce pollutants and meet related standards. Other specific factors
that can influence automotive production include changing demographics (e.g., population growth,
increase of median age, urbanization), consumer preferences (e.g., low cost cars for basic
transportation), levels of disposable income, replacement rates of old vehicles and affordability of
new vehicles.

**_Key Trends_**

The automotive supply industry is influenced by a range of complementary trends, which together
influence the performance of the individual participants. The key trends are described below:

_Market Trends_

The automotive industry is currently impacted by a number of key market trends which are primarily
driven by regulations and technological developments, as well as changes in consumer demand.
These trends include:

  - **_Increased fuel efficiency, reduced CO2 emissions and E-Mobility: Tightening environmental_**
standards for vehicles globally are driving a need to develop more environmentally-friendly
technologies, aimed at lower fuel consumption and, consequently, at reduced CO2 emissions,
as well as lower tailpipe emissions (e.g. nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds and CO2).
This can generally be achieved by enhancing the efficiency, or reducing the weight, of existing
technologies or by developing new alternative technologies. Powertrain and transmission
related technologies are expected to be critical for OEMs’ ability to comply with stricter
standards. Moreover, the increasing use of hybrid, electric and hydrogen powertrains
represents a fundamental change to established vehicle technology and related purchase
incentives and an expanding charging infrastructure, could contribute to an increase in
demand for hybrid and electric powertrains. Given our general R&D activities to further
advance the powertrain of internal combustion engines as well as our wide-ranging and
growing competence in solutions for hybrid and full-electric powertrains, we are well
positioned to further drive and benefit from this trend. Our joint venture Innoplate, with
Symbio SAS, itself a joint venture of Faurecia and Michelin hydrogen company, to produce fuel
cell bipolar plates, a strategic fuel cell component, for global mobility and energy solutions and
our shared research program with Johnson Matthey, Bekaert and TNO, to accelerate proton
exchange membrane (“PEM”) electrolyzer technology development, by optimizing the most
important components of the electrolyzer stack, is expected to help us to continue to drive the
next generation of hydrogen technologies.

  - **_Enhanced comfort and convenience: OEMs are constantly looking for ways to enhance driving_**
experience, comfort and convenience through new technologies. Examples of this include the
significant increase in electronic components per vehicle, with many car functions now


-----

controlled electronically and solutions that improve driving experience, for example, through
noise and vibration control (e.g., dual mass flywheels, balancer shaft dampers and crankshaft
dampers).

  - **_Autonomous driving: An additional growing market will be autonomous driving, which, along_**
with increased driving comfort, will also improve road safety. Experts refer to five levels of
vehicle automation, beginning with level 0 with a “driver only” – the driver steers and drives
completely without support from driver assistance systems – through to level 5, in which the
vehicle is completely driverless, i.e. moves autonomously. Connectivity is also an important
aspect of autonomous driving. Sophisticated sensor, antenna and data connectivity
technologies work together to sense the environment, within and outside the vehicle, and
receive, act upon, and transmit data in real-time to devices throughout the vehicle and in the
physical world the vehicle navigates. Additionally, requirements for chassis applications are
evolving to match increased automation. We acquired Schaeffler ByWire, and its steer-by-wire
steering technology (“Space Drive”), a key technology for autonomous driving. Space Drive is
the only system of its kind to be licensed for on-road use in multiple countries worldwide.

  - **_Shared mobility and connectivity: Consumers, especially in urban centers, are increasingly_**
seeking alternative mobility concepts to vehicle ownership, such as, for example, mobility on
demand, mobility as a service or ride sharing. Such shared mobility concepts are linked, to a
certain degree, to the connectivity of vehicles. Connected cars are those that have access to
the internet and a variety of sensors, and that are able to send and receive signals, sense the
physical environment around them and interact with other vehicles or entities. Increasing
vehicle connectivity to smartphones, clouds, physical infrastructure and other vehicles, is
another market trend that affects both OEM and suppliers. A growing trend, for example,
involves the process of sending and installing software updates on passenger vehicles through
the internet (“over the air”).

  - **_Growth markets: The increase in disposable income, low existing vehicle penetration as well as_**
the development of efficient road infrastructure are driving demand for light vehicles in
growth markets. Due to high and rapidly growing local demand combined with low
manufacturing costs, global OEMs are expanding their production and sales networks in these
markets. At the same time, local vehicle manufacturers, particularly in China and India, are also
gaining significant scale. Large scale suppliers with strong OEM relationships and resources to
invest in their production footprint are well positioned to tap growth opportunities in these
markets, both with existing and new local OEM customers.

Suppliers that provide solutions that enable OEMs to address these trends and meet regulatory
standards are well positioned to experience above average growth and establish themselves as key
future technology partners for OEMs. For a long time, the Automotive Technologies Division has
primarily competed with other large automotive suppliers in the fields of drive technology and
chassis systems. In the future-oriented fields of electric mobility and autonomous driving, additional
competitors new to the industry are entering the market.

_OEM Trends_

Changes in the development, sourcing and production strategy of OEMs can also influence the
automotive supplier market. Over the past decade, OEMs have increasingly shifted to global vehicle
platforms with the aim of maximizing the commonality of components and systems and to derive
cost savings via economies of scale. Consequently, OEMs are looking for global suppliers that can
provide standardized components worldwide, at a competitive cost level and with close proximity to
OEM production sites. Typically, OEMs use two to three suppliers globally per component and
platform to ensure a degree of multiple sourcing and in order to avoid overdependence on a single
supplier, though some OEMs use a single supplier. This trend benefits suppliers, such as the


-----

Schaeffler Group, with global presence and scale, and the ability to deliver the same
technological/quality standard at competitive costs across regions. In addition, OEMs have increased
investments in the context of E-mobility, in particular in the field of battery capacity.

### Automotive Aftermarket 

We offer products and services to customers in the automotive aftermarket sector. Products and
services are sold via two primary distribution channels: the original equipment service (“OES”) and
the open (independent) spare parts market or independent aftermarket (“IAM”). The OES
distribution channel supplies original spare parts to automobile OEMs for their branded repair shops.
The IAM distribution channel supplies components and repair solutions and services to a global
network of independent parts distributors, which supply workshops that are not affiliated with any
particular automobile OEM. IAM differentiates between two types of business, a traditional
components business consisting of replacing parts and a business for the development and
distribution of custom assembled repair sets and kits to help make vehicle repairs simple, efficient
and professional.


-----

**_Definition, Size and Structure_**

The term “aftermarket” refers to the market of spare parts that are used in the maintenance and
repair of passenger cars and commercial vehicles. In addition to sales to OEMs for their own
production, many automotive suppliers sell directly to the aftermarket, representing a smaller but
typically more profitable and stable revenue source. The same products supplied to OEMs are
generally also distributed in the aftermarket sector.

**_Growth Drivers_**

In the aftermarket, the key drivers for growth are (i) continuing growth in the global vehicle
population, (ii) an overall increase in the average age of the vehicle population, and (iii) increasing
vehicle complexity. Especially in growth markets like China, there is significant potential for growth in
the automotive aftermarket business, given the increase in vehicle population over the past years
that is expected to continue and the number of vehicles in the seven to ten year age range is
expected to increase significantly and approach the level of Europe as early as by 2024 (Source: S&P
Global Mobility © [S&P Global Mobility Vehicle in Operation (VIO) Forecast, November 2022]). The
growth of the IAM business depends on a number of different factors, both in terms of demand (e.g.,
average age and composition of vehicles on the road, mileage and technological development of
vehicles) and in terms of the range of products and services offered. The Automotive Aftermarket
Division considers itself very well positioned within this market, as demonstrated by the numerous
awards and certifications our products and services have received, but at the same time, the
Automotive Aftermarket Division is preparing for future challenges, especially those arising from the
move toward new vehicle technologies and digitalization.

The Automotive Aftermarket believes its cross-selling activities, i.e. expanding the product portfolio
with existing customers, to hold potential for additional revenue. Together with industry partners,
the Division is also working to promote the issue of vehicle connectivity and non-discriminatory
access to data and is actively involved in the digital data marketplace CARUSO and related activities.

**_Key Trends_**

Increasingly complex vehicle applications, the large number of new vehicle models and the
emergence of next generation vehicle technology, such as powertrain electrification, autonomous
driving and connectivity, are constantly confronting repair shop staff with challenging repair
situations. Therefore, suppliers to the automotive aftermarket offer numerous services and repair
solutions. As hybrid and electric vehicles are increasingly in need of repairs, the Automotive
Aftermarket Division is focusing on developing intelligent repair solutions and services for electric
mobility. Service hotlines, training seminars as well as installation guides or videos, and tools tailormade for professional repairs support repair shops in their daily work. Digitalization is also playing an
increasingly important role in the ability of suppliers to meet customer needs. As a result, the
Automotive Aftermarket Division is continuing to develop its e-commerce activities and relies on the
close integration of marketing, distribution, and services. In addition, the automotive aftermarket
sector is experiencing a phase of consolidation at the wholesale level. At the same time, new market
participants and intermediaries such as insurers or vehicle fleet operators are entering the
aftermarket ecosystem.

The Automotive Aftermarket Division considers its commitment to customer service and operational
excellence important success factors. Therefore, in order to further expand its operational
excellence, the Automotive Aftermarket Division strives to make its deliveries to customers around
the world quick and reliable in order to raise the level of customer satisfaction and loyalty. The focus
here is on efficiently supplying customers with intelligent repair solutions, which is ensured by
employing state-of-the-art assembly and packaging centers known as aftermarket kitting operations.
Four assembly and packaging centers are in operation in Mexico City, Singapore, Shanghai and Halle.

### Industrial 

Our Industrial Division develops and manufactures precision components, both rotary and linear
bearing solutions, drive technology components and systems, as well as service solutions such as
sensor-based condition monitoring systems for a large number of industrial applications and for
customers in a variety of different industrial sectors.

Within the regions Europe, Americas, Greater China, and Asia/Pacific, the direct business with
customers is grouped into eight sector clusters within four market clusters: renewables (wind),
transportation and mobility (aerospace, rail, offroad, two-wheelers), machinery and materials (raw
materials, power transmission) and industrial automation (industrial automation). In addition, the
Industrial Distribution unit manages an industrial distribution business, which comprises the spare
parts and service business of the Industrial Division. Comprehensive services are concentrated in a
strategic business field, “Lifetime Solutions”, with global responsibility. The Industrial Division’s
product portfolio includes goods and services ranging from high-volume standard products to
individual specialized solutions and from mechanical components through to mechatronic systems,
digitalization products and services, including a wide range of rolling and plain bearings, linear and
direct drive technologies as well as services such as condition monitoring, expert services and
training, lubrication systems, maintenance tools, remanufacturing services, and spare parts.
Applications for the bearings manufactured by the Division include drive technology, production
machinery and wind turbines, as well as heavy industry. The Industrial Division is also developing new
products and solutions for the hydrogen economy.

**_Definition, Size and Structure_**

The world bearing market is generally defined as the supply of rolling bearings, comprising ball and
roller bearing assemblies of various designs including mounted bearing units, as well as plain
bearings. Bearings are used in multiple segments of the industrial sector which follow different
drivers and business cycles. Global industrial production is an indicator for the overall trend of the
market, as most of the end-markets are highly diversified.

The industrial bearings market is highly consolidated. We are one of the major global Tier 1 suppliers,
along with Hiwin Corporation, NSK Ltd., NTN Corp., SKF AB, The Timken Co. and THK Co. Ltd. All major
bearings producers supply bearings to OEMs and their suppliers in a broad range of end-markets. In
most applications, bearings are critical components for the functionality of the equipment. This is
reflected in significant aftermarket business opportunities, including the sale of replacement parts
and services. Companies in the industrial production market try to differentiate themselves by
offering readily available, high quality as well as complex mechanical and mechatronic systems and
digitalization products and services such as condition monitoring or predictive maintenance and
worldwide customer relations. Customers need intelligent solutions and cost savings throughout the
lifecycle of their systems, which opens up new growth areas for the Schaeffler Group.

**_Growth Drivers_**

The most important driver in the supply of bearings for industrial customers is the growth in global
industrial production volume that, in turn, is driven by key market trends, such as population growth
and increasing awareness of sustainability topics. The major factors that are growth drivers for us as
a supplier to the industrial sector, are product quality and availability, application know-how and
worldwide customer relations. In the industrial distribution sector, the total installed base of
products and applications that include bearings and the further development of this installed base
are the key growth drivers. Future growth of demand is driven by various factors, such as average
age and technological development of machinery, dimensions of bearings, services rendered and the
range of products offered.


-----

**_Key Trends_**

The main trends that are shaping the industrial sector:

_Key Technology Trends_

  - **_Digitalization: Digitalization includes all aspects of developing mechatronic products and_**
digitally enabled service solutions. Numerous digitalization products and solution packages in
various project stages are already in use by our customers today. These include, for instance,
rolling bearings equipped with sensors, cloud-based monitoring of accessory units such as
electric, complete solutions for monitoring and lubricating machines, as well as all-digital
services for predicting the service life of rolling bearings. In particular, in the wind sector, there
is a growing trend from the supply of components towards the supply of complete subsystems and modules.

  - **_Total cost of ownership: Customers require products that reduce downtime and operating,_**
servicing and maintenance costs. High-quality products and condition monitoring can reduce
maintenance expenses and improve operating lifetime in order to reduce downtime and the
cost of ownership.

  - **_Services, consultancy and training: We offer a wide range of services relevant to the lifecycle_**
of a rolling bearing (regardless of whether we manufactured the bearing arrangement) from
installation to maintenance and to the remanufacturing of rolling bearings. Companies that
wish to increase their knowledge in the areas of rolling bearings and condition monitoring can
also have access to our training and consultancy portfolio.

_Key Market Trends_

Certain regions and market segments are expected to grow at a faster pace than the overall industry.
The key trends include:

  - **_China driving global growth: Growth in industrial production is expected to be led by the_**
rapidly expanding market in Greater China, which has grown with a CAGR of 7.2% from 2011 to
2022 (Source: Oxford Economics, January 2023).

  - **_New applications: Examples of new applications are high-speed trains, condition monitoring_**
for various applications (such as railways, production machinery, wind turbines or power
transmission), robotics, intelligent bearings for agriculture machinery and transportation
industries.

  - **_Renewable energy and mobility infrastructure: Growth areas for rotary rolling bearings_**
include, for instance, the fields of renewable energies and mobility infrastructure, in which our
Industrial Division participates by manufacturing large-and mid-size rolling bearings.

  - **_Digitalization: Digital solutions, such as the development of e-commerce solutions, is playing_**
an increasingly important role in meeting customer needs, both new and existing, especially in
the industrial distribution business.

**_Historical and Forecast Development_**

In the period from 2011 to 2022, global industrial production grew by a CAGR of 3.0%. During this
period, industrial production in the Greater China region increased with a CAGR of 7.2%, industrial
production in the Asia/Pacific region grew by a CAGR of 1.8% and industrial production in Europe and
the Americas grew by CAGRs of 1.4% and 0.7%, respectively (Source: Oxford Economics, January
2023).

For the period from 2022 to 2027, taking into account Oxford Economics forecasts, we expect the
global industrial production to grow by a CAGR of 3.2% (Source: Oxford Economics, January 2023).
