### Our History

In 1946, brothers Dr. Wilhelm Schaeffler and Dr. Georg Schaeffler founded Industrie GmbH in
Herzogenaurach, Germany. Lamellen- und Kupplungsbau GmbH (“LuK”) was founded in 1965 in
Buehl, Germany (in cooperation with Industrie-Nadellager (“INA”)), and later managed as a 50/50
joint venture. After the death of the founders (Dr. Wilhelm Schaeffler died in 1981 and Dr. Georg
Schaeffler died in 1996), Maria-Elisabeth Schaeffler-Thumann, Dr. Georg Schaeffler’s widow, and her
son Georg F. W. Schaeffler took charge of the family business to continue their life’s work and began
a number of initiatives to grow the Schaeffler Group’s expertise and scope as a technology partner. In
1999, LuK was fully integrated into the Schaeffler Group when it acquired the remaining 50.0%
interest in LuK. In 2001, INA acquired FAG Kugelfischer Georg Schäfer AG (“FAG”), making the
Schaeffler Group the world’s second largest manufacturer of rolling bearings at that time. At the end
of 2002, INA, LuK, and FAG were combined to form the Schaeffler Group, under the motto “Together
we move the world.”

In July 2008, the Schaeffler Group initiated an acquisition of Continental AG via a public tender offer,
which was financed primarily by external debt. Following this acquisition, it focused on the gradual
improvement of its debt profile. In 2011, the Schaeffler Group took a key step in this direction, when
it significantly reduced its financial debt and achieved a considerable improvement of the terms and
conditions of its financing by selling part of its stake in Continental AG. In 2012, the Schaeffler Group
also debuted on the capital markets by completing its first ever bond offering. In 2014, the Schaeffler
Group and its shareholders completed the final stage of a multi-year corporate reorganization that
had been initiated in 2012 and was designed to establish a clean structure separating ownership of
Schaeffler Group from ownership in Continental AG.

In 2015, Schaeffler AG completed its initial public offering on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. Following
its capital markets debut, the Schaeffler Group has focused on its internal processes. It modernized
its leadership structure by implementing the multi-dimensional matrix organization that comprises
the Board of Managing Directors and the executive board as well as realigning its regions. The
Schaeffler Group also continuously and significantly reduced its indebtedness.

Schaeffler AG’s non-voting shares have been listed on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange since 2015 under
the ticker symbol SHA. The Issuer holds 75.1% of Schaeffler AG’s share capital (representing 100% of
its voting rights), with the remaining 24.9% (all non-voting shares) held by public investors.

### Our Divisions

We operate through three divisions, the Automotive Technologies Division, the Automotive
Aftermarket Division and the Industrial Division.

**_Automotive Technologies Division_**

Our Automotive Technologies Division partners with the global automotive industry in developing
and manufacturing components and system solutions for electric and hybrid powertrains and fuel cell
powertrains, as well as for internal combustion engines and chassis systems. The Division also offers
a wide range of rolling bearings that is largely powertrain-agnostic. Our Automotive Technologies
Division offers approximately 17,000 products and system solutions for E-Mobility, engines,
transmissions and chassis systems, as well as for hybrid and electric powertrain systems to customers
in the automotive sector. Alongside the increased development of technologies for low-emission and
emission-free powertrains, the Division also develops products for autonomous driving.

Our Automotive Technologies Division accounted for 60.1% of our consolidated revenue and 27.9%
of our Adjusted EBIT in 2022.


-----

_Customers_

As of December 31, 2022, we supplied our products and system solutions to all major global
automobile OEMs as well as approximately 1,100 automotive suppliers in the areas of passenger cars
as well as light, medium and heavy-duty trucks. In 2022, the Automotive Technologies Division’s
largest customer and its top ten customers represented 14.0% and 64.8% of its revenues,
respectively.

Customers are serviced and supplied by our worldwide sales organizations and production sites in all
regions.

_Products_

The Automotive Technologies Division comprises four business divisions (“BDs”), with a distinctive
product and service portfolio: (i) E-Mobility, (ii) Engine & Transmission Systems, (iii) Bearings, and
(iv) Chassis Systems, accounting for 14.2%, 54.2%, 27.6% and 3.9% of the Automotive Technologies
Division’s revenues during 2022. We changed the organizational structure of our Automotive
Technologies Division effective January 1, 2022 in order to more closely align the Division towards
future-oriented technologies and the transition in the automotive industry. Previously, the Division’s
four BDs were E-Mobility, Engine Systems, Transmission Systems and Chassis Systems. The
organizational change more clearly separates the powertrain-specific business from the powertrainagnostic business. The largely powertrain-agnostic range of rolling bearings applications and
products, that were previously part of the Transmissions Systems BD and the Chassis Systems BD, are
now part of the new Bearings BD. The change is intended to increase the visibility of the bearings
business as well as enhance it with a focus on applications and customers, realize synergies, drive
innovation and generate growth in new markets in a highly competitive environment. In addition, we
plan to grow on the E-Mobility and Chassis Systems BDs with a focus on their future core businesses.
For example, the Chassis Systems BD will concentrate on steering components, mechatronic chassis
systems, and technologies for autonomous driving and the E-Mobility BD established the “Project
House Thermal Management BEV,” in order to expand its market position in thermal management
for electric vehicles. We also combined the Engine and Transmission Systems BDs with the aim of
realizing additional synergies in the business with powertrains based on internal combustion engines,
in light of the long-term expectation of declining demand in this BD.

During 2022, our Automotive Technologies Division generated approximately 27.6% of its revenues
with bearings-related products, while 72.4% of its revenues were generated with non-bearingsrelated products.

E-Mobility

Through our “E-Mobility BD,” we develop and manufacture mechanical, mechatronic, and electric
components and systems across the full range of powertrain electrification, with options from 48-volt
mild hybrids and plug-in hybrids to all-electric vehicles for both passenger cars and commercial
vehicles. The product portfolio includes electric motors, electric axle transmissions, electric axle
drives, power electronics, hybrid modules, electromechanical and hydraulic actuators, key
components for fuel cells, as well as thermal management modules. The E-Mobility BD accounted for
14.2% of the Automotive Technologies Division’s revenues in 2022.

Engine & Transmission Systems

Our “Engine & **Transmission Systems BD” develops and provides innovative components and**
systems for engines and transmissions applications in passenger cars and commercial vehicles with
hybrid and conventional drives. The product portfolio comprises engine products such as valve-lash
adjustment elements, variable valve train systems, and camshaft phasing systems and transmission
products such as solutions for double-clutch, manual, automated and automatic transmissions (for


-----

example, torque converters, hybrid dampers and clutches). The products are designed to achieve
lower fuel consumption and to support our customers in complying with increasingly strict standards
for CO2 emissions. In addition, they are aimed at increasing driving comfort and dynamics and
extending maintenance intervals and service life. The Engine & Transmission Systems BD accounted
for 54.2% of the Automotive Technologies Division’s revenues in 2022.

Bearings

Our “Bearings BD” develops and provides bearings for the wide range of rolling bearing applications
and products. The broad product portfolio of our Bearings BD covers bearing solutions for all
applications and its core products include wheel bearings and needle rolling bearings. The bearings
are used for applications in motors, engines and transmissions, in the electrified electric axle system,
and in hybrid modules. Further, a broad range of the bearings portfolio is used in steering systems
and accessory units. We have particularly focused on realizing synergies, driving innovation and
generating growth in new markets in a highly competitive environment. In 2022, we introduced two
product innovations designed specifically for electric vehicles: the TriFinity triple-row bearing and the
high-efficiency ball bearing with centrifugal disc. The TriFinity triple-row bearing, designed for use in
electrified powertrains, offers significantly longer service life and improved rigidity and is able to
transfer greater axle loads than a standard two-row ball bearings. The high-efficiency ball bearings
with centrifugal disc is a high-performance, friction-optimized and sustainable product for E-mobility
applications and received the Magna Supplier Award and was nominated for the 2022 German
Innovation Award. The Bearings BD accounted for 27.6% of the Automotive Technologies Division’s
revenues in 2022.

Chassis Systems

Our “Chassis System BD” develops and manufacturers mechanical components and mechatronic
systems for steering and other chassis applications, including for autonomous mobility. The broad
product portfolio of our Chassis System BD covers bearing solutions for various chassis applications.
A mechatronic system unites the principles of mechanics, electronics and computing. Our chassis
products are aimed at higher safety and comfort, while at the same time meeting our customers’
expectations with regard to cost-efficiency, durability, design and fitting. The product portfolio
includes the steer-by-wire steering technology (“Space Drive”), a key technology for autonomous
driving, active roll control systems for increased safety, and rear-wheel steering systems that make
driving more comfortable. The Chassis System BD is also open to external partnerships, particularly in
the areas of automation and connectivity. For example, in 2021, the Chassis System BD entered into
a partnership with Mobileye B.V., a subsidiary of the Intel Group, to advance the industrialization of
autonomous vehicles. Our rolling chassis, a modular platform for mobility concepts, including
driverless mobility solutions for the transport of people or goods or for special applications such as
mobile charging solutions or pop-up stores on wheels, will be combined with the Mobileye Drive selfdriving system, with the goal to develop a new, flexible platform for self-driving shuttles and other
vehicle products at full automation and to offer customers worldwide solutions for Mobility-as-aService and Transportation-as-a-Service. The Chassis Systems BD accounted for 3.9% of the
Automotive Technologies Division’s revenues in 2022.

_Sales_

Our sales and marketing team plays a crucial role in growing and developing prospects, developing
brand awareness, creating a positive market image, coordinating sales and marketing messages and
developing a working business intelligence for better decision-making.

Our sales organization has a global footprint and is active in all key countries with local sales facilities.
Commercial and technical sales representatives are supported by engineering specialists from our
regional headquarters. Marketing tools, such as catalogues, technical software, fairs, symposiums


-----

and advertising in industry-specific magazines, support our sales initiatives and complement our
market approach.

OEM customers are mainly served directly. E-commerce solutions are used to streamline business
processes with our main customers. Sales conditions are predominantly open deliveries and
payments according to agreed contract conditions that can be framework agreements, single-year or
multi-year contracts. As we have business locations all over the world, sales channels, sales
conditions and terms of sales differ in each country, depending on the respective economic and
financial situation as well as national custom.

**_Automotive Aftermarket Division_**

Our Automotive Aftermarket Division complements the Automotive Technologies Division with an
extensive aftermarket offering and operates under the brands INA, FAG, LuK and REPXPERT. The
Division is continuing to evolve from a components supplier into a supplier of systems and integrated
solutions by adding data-based services and innovative plug-and-play repair solutions to its product
range. Products and repair solutions are distributed globally under these four product brands. The
product range covers applications in clutch and release systems, engine and transmission
applications and chassis applications. In addition, our Automotive Aftermarket Division offers a wide
variety of services, including, for example, various means of transferring knowledge, such as practiceoriented training courses, advice provided by our repair hotline or our online garage portal,
“REPXPERT,” and our product catalog and digital knowledge base, “medias,” as well as the
development of specialized tools for performing repairs such as “OneCode.” In September 2020, the
Automotive Aftermarket’s assembly and packaging center in Halle, Germany (the “AKO”)
commenced operations.

Our Automotive Aftermarket Division accounted for 12.9% of our consolidated revenue and 24.4% of
Adjusted EBIT in 2022.

The Automotive Aftermarket Division is primarily managed based on regions due to its broad
customer base and business structure. The Europe, Americas, Greater China and Asia/Pacific regions
operate as profit centers responsible for the Automotive Aftermarket business in their respective
markets.

In 2022, the Europe region accounted for 66.5%, the Americas region accounted for 21.3%, the
Greater China region accounted for 5.7% and the Asia/Pacific region accounted for 6.5% of the
Automotive Aftermarket Division’s revenues.

Among our regions, we expect the Greater China region to experience the largest increase in vehicle
population and demand for repairs until 2025, as China’s vehicle population is both growing and
aging. Therefore, we are aiming to grow our Automotive Aftermarket Division’s business in the highvolume market in the Greater China region. To expand our presence in the Greater China region, we
are opening or expanding local plants and started our ETC Platform China to connect manufacturers,
dealers, and resellers of vehicle parts with each other, and, additionally to offer a comprehensive
range of parts for engines, transmissions and chassis. We aim to create and expand our product
portfolio of intelligently packaged repair solutions, products and services that are tailored to the
specific needs of the Greater China market.

_Customers and Sales_

As of December 31, 2022, we supplied our aftermarket products and system solutions to
approximately 2,100 customers globally. In 2022, the Automotive Aftermarket Division’s top ten
customers represented 29.5% of its revenues. The Automotive Aftermarket Division uses two primary
distribution channels within each of the four regions: the original equipment service (“OES”), which
accounted for approximately 20% of the Automotive Aftermarket Division’s revenues in 2022, and
the open (independent) spare parts market or independent aftermarket (“IAM”), which accounted


-----

for the remaining 80% of the Automotive Aftermarket Division’s revenues in 2022. The OES
distribution channel supplies original spare parts to automobile OEMs for their branded repair shops.
The IAM distribution channel supplies components and repair solutions and services to a global
network of independent parts distributors, which supply workshops that are not affiliated with any
particular automobile OEM. IAM differentiates between two types of business, a traditional
components business consisting of replacing parts and a business for the development and
distribution of custom assembled repair sets and kits to help make vehicle repairs simple, efficient
and professional. The Automotive Aftermarket Division operates through a global network of
distributors, many of whom are organized in trade cooperatives, and it utilizes tools such as a global
product and service platform and a returns portal. It is also continuing to develop its e-commerce
activities and relies on the close integration of marketing, distribution and services as online sales
evolve into an additional distribution channel for the Division. Also, in addition to its own services,
the Automotive Aftermarket Division has co-founded important service initiatives with industry
partners, a significant contribution to keeping repair shops and distributors well informed digitally.

The Automotive Aftermarket Division identified three fields of action to realize future growth: (i)
realizing potential in the core business, (ii) intensifying digitalization, and (iii) developing new
business.

Growth opportunities for the core business, particularly for expanding the share of portfolio with
existing customers (“Share of Wallet”), captures our view that the foundation for realizing
opportunities for growth, is to continually improve the customer experience and collaboration with
customers and partners and to ensure that interactions with our customers are as convenient for our
customers as possible.

Digitalization is also key to improving the customer experience across the entire sales process using
advanced digital services. For example, we developed the “OneCode” service solution that supports
repair shops throughout Europe to perform vehicle repairs by allowing them to scan a quick response
(QR) code placed on the packing of our products to receive information about repair solutions and
services and about the product itself, including its authenticity. In addition to on-site training, we also
began piloting REPXPERT Remote Support in Europe in 2021, enabling repair shops to obtain
assistance during complex repairs, including via smartphones or tablets, by sending images and
sound in real time and providing explanations of repairs via mixed reality. We also developed the ETC
Platform China, which is a trading platform in the independent spare parts market that is operated by
a supplier and links upstream and downstream sections of the supply chain and it allows us to
participate more in the expected growth in the Chinese aftermarket.

Developing new business focuses, in particular, on strengthening sustainability across the value
chain. This includes developing intelligent repair solutions and services for E-mobility, which will
enable the Division to capitalize on the growing need for repair solutions for hybrid and electric
vehicles. For example, in 2022, the Division launched the first electric axel repair solution “E-Axle
RepSystem-G.” The system is scalable and the Division is developing additional repair solutions based
on the system, for example, for electric motors. The Automotive Aftermarket will also focus on
services and solutions for the circular economy and remanufacturing. The Division will also consider
entering into partnerships and in the automotive ecosystem as it endeavors to provide added value
to repair shops. For example, we are actively involved in the digital market place “CARUSO”, a central
platform providing harmonized vehicle data to the automotive aftermarket and linking data suppliers
with data users.

_Products_

The comprehensive product range of our Automotive Aftermarket Division includes components and
comprehensive repair solutions in OEM quality for engine, transmission, and chassis applications in
the passenger car and light commercial vehicles, trucks and buses, and offroad customer sectors. All


-----

components are optimally tuned to work together and allow for fast and professional replacement.
Product lifetimes vary significantly from product to product. In addition to the traditional component
business consisting of replacement parts, the Automotive Aftermarket Division develops and
distributes custom repair sets and kits to help make vehicle repairs simple, efficient and professional.
For example, in 2022, the Automotive Aftermarket Division launched the first electric axel repair
solution “E-Axle RepSystem-G.” The system is scalable and the Division is developing additional repair
solutions based on the system, for example, for electric motors. The Automotive Aftermarket
Division is largely supplied by the plants of the Automotive Technologies Division. Our products and
repair solutions are distributed using the three product brands (i) LuK, (ii) INA and (iii) FAG and the
service brand, REPXPERT. Under the LuK brand, we provide intelligent repair solutions for
powertrains, including clutches, vibration damping or transmission components. Under the INA
brand, we offer a broad spectrum of products for key engine systems, including for the valve train,
timing drive, front end auxiliary drive and cooling systems. Under the FAG brand we offer chassis
technology in the spare parts market for every aspect of the wheel drive, axle and wheel suspension,
stabilizers, steering systems and engine and transmission mounts. Under the service brand
REPXPERT, we offer numerous services covering every aspect of our products and repair solutions to
help repair shop staff to handle increasingly complex vehicle applications and the large number of
new vehicle models. These services include service hotlines, training seminars as well as installation
guides or videos and tools tailor-made for professional repair. During 2022, our Automotive
Aftermarket Division generated approximately 13% of its revenues with bearings-related products,
while 87% of its revenues were generated with non-bearings-related products.

**_Industrial Division_**

The Industrial Division develops and manufactures precision components, both rotary and linear
bearing solutions, drive technology components and systems, as well as service solutions such as
sensor-based condition monitoring systems for a large number of industrial applications and for
customers in a variety of different industrial sectors. In addition, the Division is working intensively to
develop components and services for the hydrogen economy in its strategic hydrogen business area.
The Division is focused on components for hydrogen production using electrolyzers, such as bipolar
plates as well as integrated solutions such as cell kits and intelligent stack systems with
complementary digital service offerings. As of December 31, 2022, the Industrial Division offered
approximately 59,200 components and system solutions under the INA and FAG brands.

The Industrial Division offers goods and services ranging from high-volume standard products to
individual specialized solutions and from mechanical components through to mechatronic systems,
digitalization products, hydrogen technology solutions and digital services, including a wide range of
rolling and plain bearing, linear and direct drive technologies as well as services such as condition
monitoring, expert services and training, lubrication systems, maintenance tools, reconditioning
bearings, and spare parts. The common denominator of these products and services is the
technological expertise and the know-how covering the customer’s entire system. During 2022, our
Industrial Division generated approximately 89% of its revenues with bearings-related products,
while 11% of its revenues were generated with non-bearings-related products.

The Industrial Division accounted for 27.0% of our consolidated revenue and 47.7% of our Adjusted
EBIT in 2022.

Since January 1, 2016, the Industrial Division has been primarily managed based on regions due to its
broad customer base and business structure. The Europe, Americas, Greater China and Asia/Pacific
regions operate as profit centers responsible for the Industrial business in their respective markets.

The Europe region accounted for 41.3% of the Industrial Division’s revenues during 2022. The
Americas region accounted for 17.2% of the Industrial Division’s revenues during 2022. The Greater


-----

China region accounted for 27.1% of the Industrial Division’s revenues during 2022. The Asia/Pacific
region accounted for 14.4% of the Industrial Division’s revenues during 2022.

**Acquisition”), a manufacturer of innovative linear motion and actuation solutions used in assembly**
automation, medical applications and mobile machinery. The Ewellix Group’s six manufacturing and

expertise in manufacturing, customer-centric applications engineering and digitalization to the

characterized by low friction, reduced wear, and particularly high accuracy and precision and are

_Industrial Customers and Sectors_

Our Industrial Division’s customers include, among others, OEMs in the area of power transmission,
production and heavy industries machinery and equipment, and wind power turbines as well as
airline manufacturers and aerospace customers.

Within the regions, the Industrial business is grouped into eight sector clusters within four market
clusters: renewables (wind), transportation and mobility (aerospace, rail, offroad and two-wheelers),
machinery and materials (raw materials and power transmission) and industrial automation
(industrial automation), which are assigned to four market clusters, renewables, transportation and
mobility, machinery and materials, and industrial automation. The alignment along sectors has
proven invaluable for the Industrial Division’s customers. The structure of the Industrial Division
allows it to utilize targeted responses for its customers, many of whom have a regional focus and
specific local needs, and it also fosters customer loyalty. Our industrial distribution business, which
comprises the spare parts and service business of the Industrial Division, complements the sector
clusters. We also have a global key account management function for key customers with operations
in more than one region aimed at ensuring those customers receive consistent quality and service
globally.

Renewables

The Wind sector provides bearing supports for wind turbines along with condition monitoring
systems, lubricants, a fitting service and maintenance tools. The comprehensive product range for
wind turbines offers bearing solutions for rotor shafts, gearboxes, generators and wind tracking and
blade adjustment arrangements.

Transportation and Mobility

The Aerospace sector develops and manufactures rolling bearing systems with integrated
components for aircraft and spacecraft construction. The product range comprises high-precision


-----

bearing components for aircraft and spacecraft construction along with condition monitoring
systems.

The Rail sector provides solutions along with condition monitoring systems for bearing applications in
rail vehicles. The product portfolio includes wheel set bearings, including housings as well as bearings
and components for traction motors and gearboxes, wagon joints and tilting mechanisms for doors
and numerous other applications.

The Offroad sector develops products for use in construction and agricultural machinery. Bearings in
modern construction machinery, for example, must be designed for high shock loads and very high
acceleration and speeds in the smallest possible design envelope. Dust, moisture and heavy soils
place high demands on mobile agricultural machinery, such as seeding machines and our sensors and
mechatronics can help to avoid seed waste.

The Two-Wheelers sector provides several motorcycle OEMs with needle bearings, ball bearings and
engine systems for both the premium and low-cost segments within the special and leisure
equipment industries. This sector emphasizes splitting customized product engineering between
premium and affordable market segments.

Machinery and Materials

The Raw Materials sector provides solutions along with condition monitoring systems for normally
“heavy duty” rolling bearing applications in the mining, metals, oil and gas, raw material extraction,
preparation and processing, steel and non-ferrous metals, and cellulose and paper industries. Our
rolling bearing and service concepts extend the lifecycle of machines and reduce the lifecycle costs.

The Power Transmission sector develops products for use in industrial gearboxes, fluid and conveying
technologies, buildings and structures, including electric motors, hydraulics equipment and
pneumatics. Most of our power transmission products are designed to meet our customers’
requirements for a long product life with low maintenance costs.

Industrial Automation

The Industrial Automation sector provides solutions along with condition monitoring systems for
bearings that are used in mechanical engineering, such as the classical areas of the textile, printing,
food processing and packaging industries and new growth industries, including the robotics and
medical industries. The product portfolio includes rotary table bearings, screw drive bearings, linear
guidance systems and high-precision bearings for main spindles.

_Industrial Distribution Business_

Our industrial distribution business is responsible for the spare parts and service business with end
customers and distributors in all significant industrial sectors. Our focus is on ensuring the supply of
high-quality products, application solutions and services to the Industrial Division’s customers. In
addition, we offer systems for condition monitoring of plants and we perform remote monitoring for
our customers, effectively increasing customers’ system availability.

_Strategic Business Areas_

Lifetime Solutions

The Industrial Division’s service business is combined in the strategic business area “Lifetime
Solutions.”

Our Lifetime Solutions business develops and offers a comprehensive product and services portfolio
along the entire product life cycle, from conditioning monitoring, expert services and training, and
lubrication systems through to maintenance tools, reconditioning bearings, and spare parts. We also


-----

strive to continually enhance the portfolio. The skills at the core of these offerings are our mechanical
expertise and systems know-how that are used to develop models and interpret operating data in
order to generate essential added value for the customer. Our systems and components are located
within machines exactly where important data are generated and captured using intelligent sensors.

Our condition-monitoring solutions and digital services offerings focus on preventative and intelligent
maintenance to provide our customers with information about the condition of their machines and
plants on a continuous basis. Our concepts enable the comprehensive digitalization and optimization
of customer applications. Processes are improved and machines and plants are made more efficient
by gathering important process parameters and condition-related information using interconnected
Schaeffler products and services. For instance, we have developed a complete platform solution for
monitoring and lubricating machines to form application-specific solution packages for use in the
paper, cement, steel, food and other industries. In addition, our digital service for automated bearing
diagnostics has been integrated into a Siemens AG industrial internet of things (“IoT”) platform since
2021. We are also developing systems for the more efficient operation of machines via increased
productivity or performance, such as the comprehensive and automated condition monitoring
solution “OPTIME,” which makes condition monitoring efficient, easy to use and cost-effective.
OPTIME provides several weeks’ early warning of damage to machine components and of
imbalances, misalignments and knocking. Since its introduction, OPTIME has been implemented in
more than 170 customer plants and 37 of our own plants. OPTIME also provides access to new
customers and presents cross-selling opportunities for the entire portfolio.

In addition, in relation to reconditioning bearings, we offer mounting and dismounting services for
rolling bearings in the form of a variety of expert services and specialized tools. The reconditioning of
rolling bearings provides additional potential for growth and contributes to sustainability.

Hydrogen

The Industrial Division’s hydrogen activities are focused on stack solutions and services for
electrolyzers. We believe this business area offers significant growth potential. Along with
components for hydrogen production using electrolyzers, such as bipolar plates, it also includes
integrated solutions, such as fuel cell kits and intelligent stack systems with matching digital service
concepts. The Industrial Division is also cooperating with other companies in the industry to
accelerate progress in hydrogen technology and applications.

### Our Functions

**_Research and Development_**

_Global R&D Program “6+2”_

We consider the challenges brought by the transformation in mobility and motion to be an
opportunity for actively helping to shape that transformation. With the aim of identifying
opportunities in our dynamic and complex market environment early on in order to ensure profitable
long-term growth with sustainable products, we defined our “Innovation-to-business” strategy. The
strategy consists of three phases. The first phase is the innovation strategy, which includes a global
R&D program, “6+2.” The 6+2 program defines six product innovation clusters, Energy Solutions,
Material Solutions, eDrive Solutions, Mobility Solutions, Robotics Solutions and Digital Solutions, and
two production innovations clusters Advanced Manufacturing and New Productions Concepts,
integrated into the Innovation & Technology cross-divisional subprogram of the Roadmap 2025. The
clusters promote a clear focus on the early identification and evaluation of innovative product ideas
and their market potential. The second phase involves organizing those product ideas into a global
project house. The third phase involves industrialization of those product ideas in accordance with
customer and market requirements.

Energy Solutions

Our Energy Solutions innovation cluster explores the potential of new technologies for a sustainable
energy supply and researches new technologies for generating, processing, and storing energy for
automotive and industrial applications. As an automotive and industrial supplier, we are considering
the full range of possible applications of hydrogen, including hydrogen production from electrolysis,
hydrogen fuel cells, and hydrogen-based steel production.

Our energy solutions focused R&D activities in 2022 included, among other things, entering into
research program, to accelerate the technological development of proton exchange membrane
(“PEM”) electrolyzers, by optimizing the most important components of the electrolyzer stack. For
hydrogen production technology, we developed new approaches for fuel cell stack components as
well as for increasing the efficiency of membrane electrode assemblies using new coatings. For
hydrogen storage technology, we demonstrated the ability of our fuel cell components to be used in
liquid organic hydrogen carriers and investigated potential for further improvement. For hydrogen
fuel cell technology, we developed our Enertect PC+ coating, which is a thin, carbon-based, and highperformance coating for metal bipolar plates in PEM fuel cells. Enertect PC+ allows PEMs to be
manufactured more efficiently, cost-effectively and sustainably. As a result of this innovation, we
were a finalist for the European Association of Automotive Supplier’s (CLEPA) Innovation Award in
the category “Clean and Sustainable Mobility.” In 2021 our activities included, among other things,
the enhancement of metallic bipolar plates, a key component for fuel cell stacks and we began
establishing a pilot plant for production of metallic bipolar pIates that started production of
prototypes in 2022. In addition, we are the project coordinator for the sub-project “Stack Scale up—
Industrializing PEM Electrolysis” of H2Giga, a hydrogen project involving over 130 companies and
research institutions that has received approximately €500 million of funding from Germany’s
Federal Ministry of Education and Research. The sub-project is comprised of nine partners from
industry and research and aims to promote the development of fuel cell stack technology to, among
other things, improve the efficiency of the technology, decrease production costs and further
develop the technology towards large-scale series production.


-----

Material Solutions

Our Material Solutions innovation cluster develops surfaces and coatings that represent key
technologies for numerous new and existing applications. As we seek to improve our CO2 footprint,
material solutions will play an essential role when it comes to sustainability. Significant contributions
to the improvement of our CO2 footprint can be made by careful conscientious selection of raw
materials such as alternative materials, composite materials, multi-material designs and coatings,
including, for example, green steel and alternate plastic. Coating technologies contribute to more
sustainable solutions by enabling the fulfillment of locally specific product requirements with minimal
use of materials. Additionally, modification of material characteristics through, for example heat
treatment, or improvement of materials through hardening can also improve our CO2 footprint. In
2021, we commissioned a plant in Nanjing, China to produce coatings to protect against a hydrogeninduced premature failure, which affects, for example, large-size wind power bearings.

eDrive Solutions

Our eDrive Solutions innovation cluster develops electric drive system and their core components,
electric motors, power electronics, and software as well as the related mechanic transmission and
bearing components for the next generation of electric drives and actuators. By bundling
competencies, we have expanded from a supplier of components and subsystems to a supplier of
complex system solutions for electric drives including software. For example, we developed a 4-in-1
electric axle, which combines the electric motor, transmission, power electronics with a thermal
management module that allows for direct cooling of the stator windings. We also developed a series
of new electric drives that combine high power density with improved overall system efficiency,
including through the use of friction-improved bearing systems. In 2021, we introduced an 800-volt
power electronic system for electric axle application in high-performance vehicles and also
developed a chainless electric drive system for the rapidly growing e-bike market and our focus for
further developing this focus on increasing the power density, reducing the carbon footprint and
increasing system efficiency.

Mobility Solutions

Our Mobility Solutions innovation cluster focuses on the effective implementation of electric drive
systems and automated driving as well as on developing fundamentally new mobility concepts. We
focus on new concepts such as autonomous people and logistics movers. Our steer-by-wire system
technology (“Space Drive”) is a key technology for autonomous driving. Space Drive is also a key part
of a more comprehensive drive-by-wire system that electronically controls not only the vehicle’s
steering system, but also its brakes and transmission. In 2022, in cooperation with REFIRE; a leading
global supplier of commercial hydrogen fuel cell technology, we developed the electric axel, fuel cell
stack, system controls and energy management system for an electric van concept powered by a 3in-1 electric axel in conjunction with a battery that is combined with a fuel cell system.

Robotics Solutions

Our Robotics Solutions innovation cluster develops highly integrated and intelligent system solutions
for the growing robotics market. With a portfolio of rolling bearings and system components such as
precision gearboxes and highly integrated torque sensor technology through to complete “smart”
systems for robotic joints, we are positioning ourselves as a partner for the dynamically growing
robotics industry. In 2022, we developed new products including bearings, gear units and a fully
integrated torque sensor system. These systems solutions can be used, for example, to enable
“cobots” (collaborative robots) to move faster, more precisely and more flexibly. We also expanded
our product portfolio to include ultra-precise planetary gears, which are also used in robots with
higher payloads of up to approximately 100 kilograms with the acquisition of Schaeffler Ultra
Precision Drives. In addition, we entered into a collaboration with the German Aerospace Center’s


-----

Institute of Robotics and Mechatronics, to accelerate the development of application-oriented
solutions in robotics. In 2021, we developed a new generation of axial flux motors and new
transmissions with integrated torque sensors. The motors feature a printed circuit board that leads
to significantly higher power density than conventional direct current motors as well as increased
flexibility in design and production. The transmissions were also coated with Schaeffler Sensotect
PVD, which allows for real time measurement of stress in places where conventional sensors are not
an option, such as within robotics joints.

Digital Solutions

Our Digital Solutions innovation cluster combines our R&D activities aimed at developing digital
products with our product components. In 2022, our focus was on product related AI applications, for
instance for recording torques in robots and for sensor fusion in electric motors. In 2021, we joined
with 11 other partners to establish an incorporated society, KI Park e.V., in Berlin, Germany, to foster
real-life AI applications and to develop the associated ethical and regulatory frameworks for
Germany and Europe. We also worked with the Technical University of Berlin on an automated
electric vehicle based on steer-by-wire technology as part of the partnership with the Center for
Tangible Artificial Intelligence and Digitization e.V. (ZE-KI e.V.). In addition, in 2022, as part of the
Schaeffler Hub for Advanced Research program (“SHARE”), the autonomous mobile robot platform
DEX was designed for the Industrial Division in order to promote new production and service
concepts based on intelligent technologies with a high degree of digitization and automation.

Advanced Manufacturing

Our Advanced Manufacturing innovation cluster develops new processes for industrialization of a
product while the product is still in development. For example, the development of an additive
process for the production of hydrodynamic plain bearings for gearboxes in wind turbines, the
development of manufacturing processes that make more efficient use of materials and enhance
sustainability, as well as the development of improved soft machining processes for gear
components. Through collaboration with our external networks, universities and the startup
community, among others, we identify disruptive innovations and then evaluate their ability to meet
the requirements of our Divisions in order to focus on the further development of production
technologies in a targeted and needs-oriented manner.

New Production Concepts

Our New Production Concepts innovation cluster focuses on the development of modular and
flexible production concepts in order to be able to react efficiently to dynamic product requirements
and volume scenarios. Through a high level of standardization and modularity, we aim to ensure that
a wide range of process modules can be reused in a sustainable manner. In addition, we aim to make
production processes more autonomous using AI and digital twins to sustainably reduce production
costs, which includes the use of flexible and collaborative robots (“cobots”) for assembly and
handling tasks and on implementing driver-less transport systems. We also aim to develop solutions
with low-code or no-code approaches to ensure their quick and easy integration.

_Collaborative R&D_

Part of our R&D efforts is also our collaboration with a global innovation network of universities,
companies, research institutions, and start-ups under our open innovation strategy, which focuses in
particular on the development of future-oriented technologies, such as hydrogen, E-Mobility,
automated driving and digitalization. We have formed collaborations with universities in the form of
our initiative “Schaeffler Hub for Advanced Research” or “SHARE” under the unique “Company on
Campus” concept to help to ensure the consistent development of future-oriented technologies. For
example, in Germany, at the Karlsruhe Institute for Technology, Germany (SHARE at KIT), the


-----

collaboration concentrates on E-mobility and automated mobility and at the Friedrich-AlexanderUniversity Erlangen-Nuremberg, the research focus is on AI integrated into physical products and for
cloud-based solutions. In the Asia Pacific region, at the Nanyang Technological University in
Singapore, the research focus is on robotics and digitalization and at the Southwest Jiatong University
in Chengdu, China the research focus is on components and systems for high-speed trains. In the
America, at Ohio State University, the research focus is on solid state batteries.

In conjunction with our open innovation strategy, we have adopted a long-term corporate venturing
approach, where we act as a technology accelerator. In our innovation clusters, we review future
oriented technologies and innovative business models and work on pilot projects with startups and
small and medium sized businesses on the development of these future oriented technologies and
innovative business models. This approach enables successful long-term strategic cooperation and
the possibility of R&D partnerships, supplier relationships or future customer relationships. For
example, in 2021, we became a new anchor partner to STARTUP AUTOBAHN, which brings together
more than 30 partners and 30,000 start-ups with the objective of developing new technologies to
marketability.

_R&D Facilities_

As of December 31, 2022, we employed, on average, approximately 7,400 R&D staff in 20 R&D
centers and additional R&D locations in a total of 25 countries.

The R&D centers work in close cooperation with customers of the automotive industry, mechanical
engineering and aerospace in all key areas of product development. We use tools, such as simulation
and rapid prototyping, to develop increasingly complex products that involve mechatronics. From
individual bearing systems to complete vehicles and machine systems, all necessary tests can be
carried out at testing facilities. This increases the operating safety of our products and provides us
with valuable insights that allow us to further develop and improve our products. By using coatings
developed in-house, the operating life of engine components and bearings can be increased
considerably. In addition, by integrating sensor technology, drives and controls and software
programs that are developed in-house, our engineers are able to design and develop complete
powertrain systems.

We spent 5% of our consolidated revenue in R&D on average over 2020, 2021 and 2022 to
strengthen the foundation for promising innovations and our long-term competitive position further.
See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of the
_Schaeffler Group—Key Factors affecting Results of Operations—Operating Expenses—Research and_
_Development (“R&D”) Expenses.”_

_Intellectual Property_

We have obtained many patents and licenses to cover our products, their design and our
manufacturing processes, and we are continuously seeking to secure further patents on our
developments.

In 2022, we registered 1,266 new patents, placing us fourth among Germany’s most innovative
companies according to the German Patent and Trademark Office (Deutsches Patent- und
_Markenamt, DPMA)._

We consider our intellectual property a competitive advantage of our business. Hence, we devote
significant resources to the filing and monitoring of our patents and other intellectual property rights,
to the prosecution of infringements thereof and to the protection of our proprietary information. For
example, we conduct intensive market studies regarding product counterfeits and, consequently,
enforce our claims by legal action. In addition, we monitor patent studies with regards to the
competitive situation of our developments.

**_Quality_**

Our product expertise and comprehensive quality management enable us to consistently ensure a
very high level of quality. We have received numerous awards from customers and maintain
internationally recognized certifications. As of December 31, 2022, nearly all of our plants are
certified under globally recognized quality standards such as IATF 16949:2016 (automotive industry
standard), ISO/TS 22163 (with specific requirements for the application of ISO 9001:2015 for the rail
sector), SEA AS 9100D:2016-09-20 (requirements for aerospace and defense organizations), and ISO
9001:2015 (industrial sector standard).

We use a variety of methods to ensure and improve the quality of our products and processes. We
have continued to develop and reinforce the interaction of error prevention and error detection
activities and have implemented a systematic approach to achieving the highest quality with the
objective of “zero defects.” “Zero defects” stands for process stabilization and continuous
improvement and facilitates the early detection and elimination of weaknesses. The program defines
policies and rules of conduct for the day-to-day work of all employees. It provides guidance and
orientation on how to prevent errors to begin with or how to permanently eliminate them. In
addition, in 2022, we launched our comprehensive quality program “SHAPE,” to address the quality
aspects of the transformation in mobility and motion. SHAPE focuses on four elements: (i) technical
expertise and reputation, (ii) agile processes and methods, (iii) quality principles and mindset, and (iv)
sustainable quality and performance.

Our comprehensive quality management system is based on a central management handbook
containing regulations and prescribed processes applicable group-wide and comprehensive quality
training schemes that have been implemented worldwide. Compliance with and monitoring of these
requirements are subject to regular audits and reviews, which are designed to ensure a uniform
global level of quality. In addition, each business unit has managers specifically responsible for quality
or other quality experts working closely with the relevant management in order to ensure that the
quality management system in the manufacturing facilities and locations is continuously improved.

**_Production Technologies_**

We are among the leaders in the fields of cold forming technology, forging, machining, heat
treatment, plating technology and assembly. Deep drawing, a process in the field of cold forming, is
one of our core technologies. Our expertise in metal forming of precision products enables us to
manufacture solutions tailored to our customers in high-volume production at an outstanding costperformance ratio. All work related to quality, such as grinding (e.g., precision grinding) and honing
the inner and outer rings of rolling bearings, is carried out in-house.

Assembly is carried out primarily on linked and automated manufacturing lines, ensuring high
standards of quality for our products. Our in-house special machine and tool manufacturing
department develops processing solutions that are specially adapted to the needs of the production
process of individual products, enabling us to manufacture our products flexibly and cost-effectively.

We are taking a comprehensive approach to digitalizing our production technologies to increase their
efficiency. We are refining our production processes to be sensor driven, interconnected and data
based, to utilize artificial intelligence, as applicable, and to reduce and simplify manual interfaces by
providing individual and tailored information to our employees for a special production step.

**_Property, Plant and Equipment_**

As of December 31, 2022, we operated 76 plants in 22 countries worldwide, the vast majority of
which are owned by us; 52 plants are producing for the Automotive Technologies Division and 23
plants are producing for the Industrial Division. Large plants that produce for both divisions are
aggregated in “campus locations,” which we established effective January 1, 2020. A key feature of
these campus locations is the existence of several plants at one location with shared use of support
functions such as human resources, logistics, or location planning functions. The Automotive
Aftermarket Division is largely supplied by the Automotive Technologies Division’s production and
manufacturing locations.

In September 2020, the Automotive Aftermarket Division’s assembly and packaging center in Halle,
Germany (the “AKO”) commenced operations (in addition to the existing centers in Mexico City,
Singapore and Shanghai). The AKO is operated by a third-party operator. As a result of delivery delays
and quality issues at the AKO, which resulted in customer claims and a loss of some business for the
Automotive Aftermarket Division, we terminated the former third-party operator’s contract effective
as of February 1, 2022 and a new third-party operator took over operation of the AKO on August 1,
2022. While we were able to reach a settlement for damages with the former third-party operator,
we were not able to recover the full amount of our losses. See also “—Risk Factors—Our future
_business success depends on our ability to maintain the high quality of our products and the punctual_
_delivery of ordered goods.”_

In 2021, we opened our new E-mobility plant in Szombathely, Hungary. The plant was designed with
high sustainability standards and is a center for excellence for components and systems for
electrified powertrains. It is also our first production plant worldwide dedicated to electric mobility
and created 150 jobs in this area. We also expanded the Industrial Division’s pant in Nanjing, China,
and it is now the largest production location for wind power bearings within the Schaeffler Group.
We also opened a large size bearing refurbishment center in India.

In 2022, we established a technology and innovation center in Erlangen-Frauenaurach designed to
increase flexibility in developing new production technologies to the point of series production. We
also began the expansion of our e-mobility development and manufacturing campus in Buehl,
Germany, to add a new building complex that will serve as a new center of excellence for E-mobility.
At our Bussmatten site, we are converting a production hall previously used to manufacture
transmission components into a production plant for electric motors that will be known as the
UltraELab. This global flagship plant is being built in accordance with the principles of the “ultraefficient factory” concept developed by the federal state of Baden-Württemberg in partnership with
Schaeffler and others. This innovative manufacturing concept is being developed under the
AgiloDrive2 project led by Schaeffler alongside 17 other consortium partners with funding support
from Germany’s Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Climate Action (BMWK). In India, we
inaugurated our new center of competence in software and electronics development in Pune as well
as a consolidation and distribution center in Hosur, India. In America, we are building an additional
production plant for hybrid modules. In addition, on December 29, 2022, we acquired 100% of the
shares of SPV Solarpark, which operates a solar energy farm in Kammerstein, Germany, with a total
area of just over 26 acres and an installed peak capacity of almost 10 MW, which is enough to supply
about 2% of our electricity requirements in Germany. In addition, as part of the Ewellix Acquisition in
January 2023, we acquired six additional manufacturing and customization sites in Europe, the U.S.
and Asia (please note that the Ewellix Group sites and employees are not consolidated with the
Schaeffler Group plants and employees for purposes of the discussions of the latter in this Offering
Memorandum).

In recognition of changing technological, regulatory and customer requirements, we continuously
evaluate and adjust our production footprint to streamline structures and align them more closely
with the requirements of our Divisions. In 2020, we sold our shares in Schaeffler Bio-Hybrid GmbH. In


-----

July 2022, we sold the global chain drive business of the Automotive Technologies Division and we
also sold our Clausthal-Zellerfeld site. In addition, we intend to sell our sites in Russia.

In September 2020, as part of our restructuring measures, we announced that we will gradually close
our production plants in Eltmann, Wuppertal, and Luckenwalde, Germany, and relocate their
activities. Operations at the Wuppertal, Germany plant were discontinued in 2022. In November
2022, we initiated further restructuring measures, which will include reducing our headcount by
1,300 positions worldwide. Within Germany, mainly the Herzogenaurach, Buehl and Homburg
locations will be affected. In Herzogenaurach and Buehl, we plan to adapt our internal structures to
new market conditions and future technologies, such as E-mobility and hydrogen. In Homburg, we
plan to increase automation and develop more efficient internal structures. In addition, Ingolstadt
and Morbach will be affected and strategies for these locations, which produce components solely
for combustion engine vehicles, are currently being developed in consultation with employee
representatives for those locations.

In addition to consolidating locations, we are also strengthening local capabilities in individual
locations, particularly in Germany, by clustering and consolidating local technology and production
capabilities in Herzogenaurach, Hoechstadt, Buehl and Schweinfurt. In Herzogenaurach, we are
focusing on establishing a cross-divisional central laboratory facility, which is expected to be
completed in 2023, as well as a cross-divisional center of excellence for the production of hydrogen
technology, a technology which we believe offers extensive opportunities for both the Industrial and
the Automotive Technology Divisions. In Hoechstadt, we opened an innovative tool technology
center in May 2022 and, in Buehl, where the Automotive Technologies Division is headquartered, we
are expanding our location into a center for excellence for E-mobility and electric-motor mass
production. We are also focusing on strengthening the contribution of our Schweinfurt location, the
headquarters of the Industrial Division, to industrial automation, robotics, as well as our traditional
bearing business by consolidating and clustering its production processes for classic mid- and largediameter bearings products. We also moved the Automotive Aftermarket Division’s headquarters
from Langen to Frankfurt in July 2022, to strengthen the headquarters and offer room for agile,
flexible and digital collaboration. We will also transfer the Gunzenhausen plant from the Automotive
Technologies Division to the Automotive Aftermarket Division, which will become the Automotive
Aftermarkets Division’s first plant.

Our headquarters are located in Herzogenaurach, Germany. We own the area and the building.

**_Purchasing of Raw Materials and Energy Resources_**

Steel is the principal raw material used in many of our products. We also use other alloys, aluminum,
zinc, copper and other non-ferrous metals as well as plastics and lubricants. We purchase raw
materials from global suppliers with whom we work closely to assure steel quality. Other important
production materials include castings, turned parts and forgings. We obtain raw materials from a
variety of sources and in general from more than one supplier. Our top five and top 100 suppliers
accounted for approximately 8% and approximately 49%, respectively, of total purchases in 2022.

Prices of raw materials and energy resources are subject to change or curtailment due to, among
other things, new laws or regulations, changes in demand levels, suppliers’ allocations to other
purchasers, interruptions in production by supplier or in transport, changes in exchange rates and
prevailing price levels. Since mid-2021 and in particular since the beginning of the war in Ukraine in
February 2022, we have experienced significant increases in the prices of many of our raw materials
and energy.

In 2022, we entered into short-, medium-, and long-term price and supply agreements to mitigate
the risk of rising energy prices, because this risk increased in 2022 as compared to prior years. As in
prior years, we generally enter into long-term purchasing contracts relating to raw materials and
preliminary products. Prices for long products, such as bars, wires, tubes and rings produced thereof
are generally fixed with an annual base price, monthly scrap and alloy surcharges. Prices for flat
products, such as hot-rolled and cold-rolled strip, are generally fixed for shorter periods.

For a description of the risk associated with raw materials and energy supply, see “Risk Factors—
_Risks related to our Business Operations and the Markets in which we operate—We depend on a_
_limited number of key suppliers for certain products_ _and inability to source products from these_
_suppliers, particularly due to supply interruptions, could adversely affect our operations” and “Risk_
_Factors—Risks related to our Business Operations and the Markets in which we operate—Prices of_
_many of our raw materials and energy have increased significantly and may rise further, which may_
_lead to higher production and manufacturing costs.”_

Since 2009, we have cooperated with Continental AG with respect to purchasing. In 2022, we entered
into a purchasing cooperation agreement with Vitesco Technologies GmbH, a subsidiary of Vitesco
AG and into a triparty purchasing cooperation agreement with Continental AG and Vitesco
Technologies GmbH, a subsidiary of Vitesco AG. In 2023, we entered into a triparty procurement
agreement for non-production material with Continental AG and Vitesco Technologies GmbH, a
subsidiary of Vitesco AG. The goal of these cooperations is to strengthen the market and negotiation
position of the respective parties under the relevant agreement by cumulating their respective
purchasing volumes, allowing them to jointly negotiate lower prices and to achieve advantageous
conditions, including procuring higher quality and higher performance from suppliers. However, the
actual purchase of the mutually sourced products is conducted independently by each party and for
the respective party’s own account. The individual purchasing cooperations agreements with
Continental AG and Vitesco Technologies GmbH remain applicable for purchases outside the scope of
the triparty purchasing agreements. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—
_Transactions of the Schaeffler Group—Cooperation Agreements.”_

**_Information Technology Systems_**

The Schaeffler Group’s information technology infrastructure is characterized by a high level of
standardization. Our information technology systems and application landscapes rely heavily on SAP
software. Our applications are unified for our Divisions.

### Our Regions 

Our business activities are divided into four regions: Europe (Germany, Western Europe, Middle East
& Africa, Central & Eastern Europe), the Americas (the United States & Canada, South America,
Mexico), Greater China (including Mainland China, and also Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao) and
Asia/Pacific (South Korea, Japan, Southeast Asia and India). In 2022, we generated 41.5% of our
consolidated revenue in Europe, 22.3% in the Americas, 22.8% in Greater China and 13.4% in
Asia/Pacific. We have built a global manufacturing footprint with each of our plants having a strong
regional foothold. As of December 31, 2022, we operated 44 plants in Europe, 13 in the Americas,
ten in Greater China and nine in Asia/Pacific. In addition, as part of the Ewellix Acquisition in January
2023, we acquired six additional manufacturing and customization sites in Europe, the U.S. and Asia
and 1,196 employees (please note that the Ewellix Group sites and employees are not consolidated
with the Schaeffler Group plants and employees for purposes of the discussions of the latter in this
Offering Memorandum).

**_Relationships with Unions and Works Councils_**

A significant number of our employees in Germany are represented by unions, along with many of
the employees in other countries. Furthermore, our employees in Germany are represented by
employee representative bodies such as works councils (Betriebsräte).

In Germany, we are a member of several regional employers’ associations (Arbeitgeberverbände)
(pertaining to the metal and electrical industry). We are therefore subject to various collective
bargaining agreements of these associations. Furthermore, we are subject to collective bargaining
agreements in various other countries (e.g., China, South Korea and Slovakia).

In accordance with German law, our German employees established a group works council
(Konzernbetriebsrat) at the level of Schaeffler AG for all employees of our German Schaeffler Group
companies, some central works councils (Gesamtbetriebsräte) at the level of individual Schaeffler
Group companies, for example, there is a central works council for Schaeffler Technologies AG & Co.
KG, and separate local works councils (Betriebsräte) for each German plant. Further, the employees
of Schaeffler Group companies in Europe are represented by a European works council (Europäischer
_Betriebsrat) at the level of Schaeffler AG._

Schaeffler AG entered into a framework social plan (Rahmensozialplan) in 2018 with its central works
council which could apply to future personnel measures for operational reasons at certain German
entities of the Schaeffler Group in Germany. The applicability of the framework social plan at other
German entities of the Schaeffler Group, depends on negotiations with the competent local works
council for the individual German entity of the Schaeffler Group concerned. Employees affected by
such measures would be entitled to certain benefits (e.g., severance payments, wage protection in
the event of relocations or qualification measures). The framework social plan may be terminated
with three months’ notice before the end of each half-year without any consequences.

We have a close and constructive relationship with the representative bodies of our employees and
the competent unions.

On April 16, 2018, the Board of Managing Directors, the Schaeffler Group works council, Schaeffler
Technologies AG & Co. KG central works council and the IG Metall trade union signed a future accord
(the “Future Accord”) with the intention of managing and driving the on-going development and
transformation of the Schaeffler Group and its response to key future trends, with particular regard
to E-Mobility and digitalization, jointly and collaboratively, in the best interests of the Schaeffler
Group and the employees. Under the Future Accord, a joint steering committee was established and
consists of equal numbers of representatives from the parties to the Future Accord and functions as a


-----

coordinating and information sharing body with a view towards reaching agreement on relevant key
issues. A core objective of the Future Accord is employee up-skilling and on-going training and
professional development, for example, the Schaeffler Academy offers target group-oriented
programs for new and additional qualifications for our employees globally, across all work areas and
hierarchy levels, as well as strengthening the commercial viability of our European locations.

In principle, the Future Accord prohibits layoffs. When facing organizational changes, the steering
committee may only consider layoffs after it determines that all measures to avoid layoffs have been
exhausted. The Future Accord also provides that we work with IG Metall to ensure that all employees
that are not currently covered by the collective bargaining agreement with IG Metall enjoy working
conditions comparable to those who are covered. Under the Future Accord, we have also agreed to
make a €50 million investment fund available over a 5 year period. The purpose of the fund is to
foster innovation and actively harness the innovative capacity of our employees, achieve sustainable
value creation, strengthen our locations in Germany and safeguard jobs over the long term. See “Risk
_Factors—Risks related to our Business Operations and the Markets in which we operate—Our_
_business could be adversely impacted by strikes and other labor disputes.”_

**_Pensions_**

The Schaeffler Group has defined benefit and defined contribution pension plans for its employees.

We provide defined benefit pension plans in Germany, the United States, the United Kingdom and
certain other countries. As of December 31, 2022, our total pension obligations (defined benefit
obligation) amounted to €2,287 million. As of December 31, 2022, our net pension obligations for
defined benefit pension plans (defined benefit obligation less pension plan assets, funded status)
amounted to €1,515 million.

Most of our defined benefit pension plans in Germany are not externally funded due to the
applicable insolvency law protection system under German law (section 7 et seq. of the German
Company Pensions Act (Betriebsrentengesetz)). Our externally invested pension plan assets are
funded through externally managed investment funds. While we prescribe the general investment
strategies applied by these funds, we do not determine their individual investment alternatives. The
pension plan assets are invested in different asset classes including equity, fixed-income securities
and real estate.

For further information on our pension obligations, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of
_Financial Condition and Results of Operations of the Schaeffler Group—Contractual and Other_
_Obligations—Pension Obligations.”_

### Environment, Social and Governance 

**_Sustainability Strategy and Management_**

Sustainability is a matter of overarching importance that influences and sets the tone across our
business. We have an established focus on sustainability that meets customer, social and
environmental needs while also serving the needs of our stakeholders and society. As part of our
Roadmap 2025 strategy, in addition to our Sustainability Strategy, we formulated a “Sustainability &
Engagement” subprogram that embeds environmental and social responsibility in our value chain as
a central success factor for a sustainable business operation. The United Nations’ 17 Sustainable
Development Goals (“SDGs”) form the foundation of our sustainability guidelines and we contribute
to thirteen SDGs (good health and wellbeing, quality education, gender equality, clean water and
sanitation, affordable and clean energy, decent work and economic growth, industry, innovation and
infrastructure, reduced inequalities, sustainable cities and communities, responsible consumption
and production, climate action, peace, justice and strong institutions and partnerships for the goals).
We are also a signatory and supporter of the United Nations’ Global Compact and committed to its


-----

ten principles, the 1.5-degree target of the Paris Agreement, and the EU Sustainable Finance Action
Plan. In addition, we are a member of the German Action Plan on Business and Human Rights and the
Value Balancing Alliance through which we work with other companies to develop a consistent
standard for measurement and monetary assessment of the environmental and social impact of
companies. We are part of “econsense,” an association of global companies and organizations active
in the German economy with the goal of promoting sustainable economic development. We are also
committed to diversity within the Schaeffler Group and are a signatory to the “Charta der Vielfalt”
and are committed to its standards for a corporate culture based on integration and mutual respect.

In 2021, the United Nations selected the Schaeffler Group as one of its “50 Sustainability & Climate
Leaders” and we represent the automotive and industrial supplier section in the DACH region
(Germany, Austria, and Switzerland). In 2021, on the occasion of our 75th anniversary, the Issuer and
the Schaeffler Group established the Schaeffler Foundation to emphasize the commitment of the
Schaeffler Group and the Schaeffler Family to social responsibility. The Schaeffler Foundation
operates worldwide and focuses on climate and environmental protection, research and science, and
education, qualification and equal opportunity. In 2022, the global non-profit CDP, which is a leading
environmental disclosure database and sets the standard for corporate environmental disclosure
transparency, awarded us the highest rating of “A” in the categories of climate change and water
security, recognizing our leadership in disclosure and performance in those categories.

In 2022, we transferred the overall responsibility for sustainability to our Chief Executive Officer. We
also adopted a more decentralized decision-making approach for sustainability issues and established
a dedicated sustainability network across all Divisions, functions and regions. As an integral part of
our Sustainability Strategy, we organize our sustainability efforts into ten action fields related to each
of the ESG dimensions. The action fields related to environment include, (1) climate neutrality, (2)
circularity, (3) resource efficiency and environmental protection, and (4) green products. The action
fields related to social include, (5) diversity, employees and people development, (6) occupational
health and safety, (7) responsibility in society and the supply chain, and (8) product safety and
integrity. The action fields related to governance include, (9) corporate governance and (10) business
integrity.

Our long-term sustainability goals are designed to help us achieve our aim of becoming a climateneutral company by 2040, including goals for reducing the emissions generated by us and in our
supply chain and for purchasing electricity from renewable sources. The Science Based Targets
Initiative (“SBTi”), which creates criteria and recommendations for companies to define emission
reduction goals to fulfill the goals of the Paris Agreement. SBTi approved our Scope 1+2 2030
Performance Goal and Scope 3 2030 Performance Goal and considered these goals compliant with
the criteria and recommendations of the SBTi and thus the latest climate science for fulfilling the
Paris Agreement.


-----

In addition, we have defined eight sustainability goals based on the ten action fields, which we
formulated in compliance with the United Nations’ 17 Sustainable Development Goals. The table
below sets out our sustainability goals.
