**_Employee Health and Safety_**

Under national and international provisions, in most jurisdictions we are obliged to take measures
related to health and safety at work. In general, compliance with employment safety regulations is
subject to regulatory supervision.

**_Road Safety and Technical Standards_**

Our products for the automotive sector have to comply with road safety and technical standards and
requirements.

For the purpose of (passenger) safety and to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market of
the EU, vehicle components and technical units have to comply with various requirements stipulated
in a large number of European legal acts. Regulation (EU) 2018/858 of the EU Parliament and of the
EU Council of May 30, 2018, which was most recently amended by Delegated Regulation (EU)
2022/2236 of June 20, 2022) establishes a framework for the approval and market surveillance of
motor vehicles and their trailers, and of systems, components and separate technical units intended
for such vehicles. The regulation became mandatory in all EU Member States on July 6, 2022. Its aim
is to achieve a high level of safety and environmental performance of vehicles. In this context, the
recitals of Regulation (EU) 2018/858 also stress measures relevant with respect to the operators in
the supply chain. In order to ensure that all vehicles, systems, components and separate technical
units placed on the market offer a high level of safety and of environmental protection, the
manufacturer or any other economic operator in the supply chain should take appropriate corrective
measures where they present a serious risk to users or the environment. Such corrective measures
explicitly include recalling vehicles.

In the course of the third mobility package “Europe on the move,” launched by the EU Commission,
the EU Parliament and the EU Council adopted Regulation (EU) 2019/2144 of November 27, 2019
(last amended by Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/1398 of June 8, 2022) amending Regulation (EU)
2018/858. The regulation entered into force on January 5, 2020 and applied from July 6, 2022. It
stipulates type-approval requirements for motor vehicles and their trailers as regards their general
safety and the protection of vehicle occupants and vulnerable road users. Following a fixed timetable
scheme, all new cars put on the EU market must be equipped with advanced safety systems to
ensure general safety, especially with regard to the protection of vehicle occupants and vulnerable
road users. Inter alia, it provides (i) for all motor vehicles to be equipped with accurate tire pressure
monitoring systems and safety features, (ii) for all passenger cars and light commercial vehicles to be
equipped with automatic emergency braking systems (“AEBS”), a lane keeping system, event
(accident) data recorder, and an enlarged head impact protection zone, and (iii) for all buses and
trucks to be equipped with a lane departure warning system and AEBS. From July 6, 2022, EU typeapprovals will be denied for passenger cars and light vehicles that do not have these safety features
and from July 7, 2024, it will be prohibited to register vehicles or place them on the EU market
without AEBS. The necessary detailed technical requirements for individual safety measures are
being developed at EU and UNECE levels. It is expected that some of the existing security measures
will be enhanced and additional new security measures will be introduced.

In view of Brexit, on June 4, 2018, the EU Commission presented a proposal for a regulation on typeapproval legislation in the context of the United Kingdom’s withdrawal from the EU. The Regulation
(EU) 2019/26 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of January 8, 2019 complementing Union
type-approval legislation with regard to the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the Union
entered into force on the third day following its publication in the EU’s Official Journal on January 8,
2019. The regulation enables manufacturers of motor vehicles, systems, components and separate
technical units holding a UK type-approval to obtain a EU type-approval (i.e., a type-approval granted
by an approval authority of one of the EU member states), provided that the application for the EU
type-approval is made before the UK’s withdrawal from the EU. The draft regulation sets out the


-----

conditions for obtaining a EU type-approval and its effects on the placing in the EU market,
registration or entry into service of such vehicles, systems, components and separate technical units.
It also states that the authority issuing the EU type-approval will assume responsibility for in-service
conformity, repair and maintenance information and potential recalls also for vehicles, systems,
components and separate technical units put in the EU market on the basis of the UK type-approval.

In 2017, the EU Commission adopted Regulations (EU) No 2017/1151 (last amended by EU
Commission Regulation (EU) 2020/49 of January 21, 2020), (EU) No 2017/1154 and (EU) No
2017/1347 of July 13, 2017 amending former Directive 2007/46/EC concerning type-approval of
motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 5 and
Euro 6) and on access to vehicle repair and maintenance information. The regulations ensure that,
since September 1, 2017, new vehicle type approvals pass new and more reliable emissions (RealDriving-Emissions – “RDE”) tests under real driving conditions. Until September 2017, emissions were
measured in a laboratory test during the registration process that takes place before the passenger
car is placed on the market. In view of the fact that the air pollutant emissions measured under real
conditions or on the road significantly exceeded the emissions measured in the laboratory test, the
EU Commission strengthened the emission testing procedure, among other things, by introducing the
RDE test, which checks emissions in real driving conditions. The EU Commission Regulation (EU)
2017/2400 of December 12, 2017 (last amended by EU Commission Regulation (EU) 2022/1379 of
July 5, 2022) defines the determination of the CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of heavy-duty
vehicles.

The provisions of Regulation (EU) No 168/2013 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of
January 15, 2013 (last amended by EU Regulation (EU) 2020/1694 of the EU Parliament and of the EU
Council of November 11, 2020) establishing approval and market surveillance requirements for
motorbikes/mopeds and squads in the EU entered into force on January 1, 2016. They aim to
upgrade EU’s functional safety and environmental requirements for L-category vehicles as a
prerequisite for vehicle registration.

In its Annex II, Part II, the Regulation (EU) 2018/858 refers to the United Nations Economic
Commission for Europe (“UNECE”) Regulations, which apply on a compulsory basis for the purpose of
EC type-approval of various categories of vehicles. The UNECE regulations listed in Annex IV are
based on the obligations of the “Agreement concerning the adoption of uniform technical
prescriptions for wheeled vehicles, equipment and parts which can be fitted and/or be used on
wheeled vehicles and the conditions for reciprocal recognition of approvals granted on the bases of
these prescriptions” of March 20, 1958 (“1958 Agreement”), as amended on March 6, 2020
(C.N.235.2019.TREATIES-XI.B.16). The EU became party to the 1958 Agreement on March 24, 1998.
The 1958 Agreement allows the Contracting Parties (“CPs”) to adopt uniform technical prescriptions
for the approvals of vehicles, parts and equipment that can be fitted and/or used on vehicles and to
reciprocally recognize approvals granted on the basis of these prescriptions. The 1958 Agreement
currently has 64 parties and 164 UNECE regulations annexed to it. Neither the United States nor
China are CPs to the 1958 Agreement.

Most UNECE regulations annexed to the 1958 Agreement cover parts and items of equipment of
motor vehicles that are relevant for granting of type approval for a category of vehicle in each of the
CPs (e.g., lamps, advanced emergency braking system, CO2 emission and fuel consumption). Most of
these UNECE regulations were adopted by a large majority of the CPs and integrated into their
national legislation.

In order to achieve a wider acceptance and application of these international vehicle regulations, the
World Forum for Harmonization of Vehicle Regulations (“WP.29”) adopted in its 169th session from
June 21, 2016 to June 24, 2016 the Revision 3 of the 1958 Agreement. The overall objective of this
reform is to accommodate the needs of countries with emerging automotive industries and markets
and to promote the principle of mutual recognition of certificates (“tested once, accepted


-----

everywhere”), while at the same time ensuring and maintaining the highest levels of safety and
environmental performance. The WP.29 invited the representative of EU to proceed with the
notification process.

Additionally, the WP.29 agreed in the mentioned session, inter alia, on the revision of a broad range
of UNECE regulations, in order to reflect the experiences and technical developments of the past
years. In view of laying down uniform provisions concerning the approval of brake assist systems,
electronic stability control, tire pressure monitoring systems and tire installation, the WP.29 adopted
four new UNECE regulations.

On January 22, 2020, UN Regulation No. 152 entered into force as an annex to the 1958 Agreement
(last amended on February 2, 2021). It imposes internationally harmonized requirements for the use
of Advanced Emergency Braking Systems (“AEBS”) at low speeds, even in complex and unpredictable
situations such as traffic in urban areas. Such systems employ sensors to monitor the proximity of the
vehicle or pedestrian in front and detect situations where the relative speed and distance between
the two vehicles or between the vehicle and pedestrian suggest that a collision is imminent. The
Regulation sets out test requirements for the deployment of AEBS at a range of different speeds,
from 0-60 km/h. In addition to cars, the Regulation will be applicable to all light commercial vehicles
(vans and minibuses with less than 9 passengers). The regulation was implemented into EU law via
Regulation (EU) 2019/2144 that entered into force on January 5, 2020.

An impact of our daily business is given with the UN Regulation No. 154 (last amended on August 18,
2021) which describes the uniform provisions concerning the approval of light duty passenger and
commercial vehicles with regards to criteria emissions, emissions of carbon dioxide and fuel
consumption and/or the measurement of electric energy consumption and electric range. The
intention of this Regulation is to establish uniform provisions concerning the approval of motor
vehicles with regard to the emissions of light-duty vehicles based on the new World harmonized Light
vehicle Test Procedure (WLTP) included in UN GTR No. 15 and the updated Evaporative Emissions
test procedure (Type 4 test) which has been developed in UN GTR No. 19. It will enable CPs to issue
and accept approvals based on these new type approval tests. The WLTP testing requirements are
reflected in the Annexes to EU Commission Regulation (EU) 2017/1151 of June 1, 2017 (last amended
by EU Commission Regulation (EU) 2020/49 of January 21, 2020). On July 5, 2022, EU Member States
adopted an amendment to the type-approval test procedure regulation for light-duty vehicles, (EU)
2017/1151 (referred to as EURO 6e Emission Standard), containing also a revision of the WLTP. It will
apply from September 1, 2023, but manufacturers are given the flexibility to begin type-approve
vehicles under the amended regulation from March 1, 2023, onwards. The Euro 6e amendments
reflect the adaptation to technical progress achieved in the WP.29 on the UN Regulation No. 154 for
the WLTP and in the draft UN Regulation on RDE and, moreover, refer directly to UN Regulation No.
154.

Even more relevant for our new business is the UN Regulation No. 155 related to uniform provisions
concerning the approval of vehicles with regards to cyber security and cyber security management
system. This regulation is in force since January 22, 2021. The regulation in particular requires vehicle
manufacturers to set up a Cyber Security Management System. However, it indirectly imposes
obligations on suppliers, as the manufacturer must demonstrate that supplier-related risks are
identified and managed and how dependencies with suppliers are managed. The regulation is
without prejudice to other UN Regulations, national or regional legislation governing the
development and installation/system integration of replacement parts and components, physical and
digital, with regards to cybersecurity. For instance, in Germany the Act on Autonomous Vehicles
(Gesetz zum autonomen Fahren) entered into force on 28 July 2021 and requires manufacturers of
autonomous vehicles over the entire period of development and operation to evidence vis-à-vis the
competent authority that electrical and electronic systems of the vehicles are protected against
cyber-attacks.


-----

The UNECE regulation No. 155 came hand in hand with the UN Regulation No. 156 which describes
uniform provisions concerning the approval of vehicles with regards to software update and software
updates management systems. This regulation came in force in as well on January 22, 2021. The
vehicle manufacturers are required to implement a Software Update Management System, which has
to be compliant with the standards set up by the UN, including detailed documentation
requirements. The regulation requires suppliers who bring specific software know-how to the
product to provide sufficient information so that the controls referred to in this regulation can be
properly carried out. Both, UN Regulation No. 155 and 156 have been implemented into EU law via
Regulation (EU) 2018/858 and via Regulation (EU) 2019/2144 that entered into force on January 5,
2020 and applied beginning on July 6, 2022. Both play an important role in practice and are affecting
us with considerable efforts and expenses. They will do so even more in our future day-to-day
business.

In addition, further UN Regulations have entered into force. In particular, under UN Regulation
No. 160, provisions concerning the approval of motor vehicles with regard to the Event Data
Recorder (“EDR”) were set out in order to ensure that EDRs record in a readily usable manner, data
valuable for effective crash investigations and for analysis of safety equipment performance. To
implement this, the EU Commission adopted the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/545 on
January 26, 2022 supplementing Regulation (EU) 2019/2144 and applying since July 6, 2022.

On September 30, 2021, UN Regulation No. 163 entered into force as an annex to the 1958
Agreement. It imposes internationally harmonized requirements concerning the approval of vehicle
alarm systems (“VAS”) and approval of a vehicle with regard to its VAS. The regulation is applicable to
passenger cars and light weight vehicles with a maximum weight of not more than 2 tons. It sets out
the requirements under which an approval will be necessary and the technical requirements for the
VAS.

The “Agreement concerning the establishing of global technical regulations for wheeled vehicles,
equipment and parts which can be fitted and/or be used on wheeled vehicles of June 25, 1998”
(“1998 Agreement”), last amended on June 14, 2022, applies in parallel to the 1958 Agreement. The
purpose of the 1998 Agreement is to further improve the process of international harmonization
through the development of UN global technical regulations (“GTRs”). The main difference compared
to the 1958 Agreement is that the 1998 Agreement does not provide for the mutual recognition of
approvals granted on the basis of global technical regulations. The 1998 Agreement stipulates that
contracting parties will establish, by consensus vote, UN GTRs in a UN Global Register. The UN GTR
contains globally harmonized performance requirements and test procedures. The 1998 Agreement
currently has 38 parties and 23 UN GTRs that have been entered into the Global UN Registry. For
instance, current GTRs include UN GTR No. 2 “Measurement procedure for two-wheeled motorcycles
equipped with a positive or compression ignition engine with regard to the emission of gaseous
pollutants, CO2 emissions and fuel consumption,” UN GTR No. 8 “Electronic stability control systems”
and GTR No. 20 “Electric Vehicle Safety (EVS).”

Furthermore, there is a list of candidates for harmonization or adoption as GTRs, inter alia, heavyduty engine and vehicle standards and highway diesel fuel sulfur control requirements. Moreover,
the WP.29 may submit proposals to develop and harmonize the vehicle regulations, for example, the
“Proposal for an Electric Vehicle Regulatory Reference Guide” submitted by the working party on
pollution and energy that was adopted in November 2014.

**_Emissions from Vehicles_**

Regulatory requirements related to emissions and noise from all vehicles required to be registered,
including two-wheelers, are relevant to our business as set out below. We continuously develop our
products in accordance with the regulatory requirements applicable to noise and pollutants
emissions.


-----

_Noise Emissions_

Noise emissions are regulated by the EU Council Directive 70/157/EEC of February 6, 1970 as last
amended by EU Council Directive 2013/15/EU of May 13, 2013. This directive lays down limits for the
noise level of the mechanical parts and exhaust systems of the vehicles concerned. The limits range
from 74 dB(A) for motor cars to 82 dB(A) for high-powered goods vehicles. This Directive will be
repealed with effect from July 1, 2027 by the Regulation (EU) No 540/2014 of the EU Parliament and
of the EU Council of April 16, 2014 (last amended by EU Commission Delegated Regulation (EU)
2019/839 of March 7, 2019) (“Regulation (EU) No 540/2014”) which also amends Directive
2007/46/EC. The Regulation (EU) No 540/2014 establishes the administrative and technical
requirements for the EU type-approval of new vehicles of specific categories with regard to their
sound level and of replacement silencing systems and components. The amendments implemented
by EU Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/1576 of June 26, 2017, were intended to improve
the accuracy of acoustic vehicle alerting system (“AVAS”) requirements on type and volume of
emitted sound, sound generation method, pause switch and stationary sound. By way of the most
recent amendment implemented under Regulation (EU) 2019/839, measures concerning the AVAS
for hybrid electric and pure electric vehicles have been set out.

Furthermore, under Regulation (EU) No 540/2014 the test method for vehicle noise emissions
established under Directive 70/157/EEC will be replaced by a new test method recognized
internationally and better reflecting present driving behavior. It was developed under the auspice of
the UNECE.

_Pollutant Emissions_

Carbon Dioxide (“CO2”)

With regard to carbon dioxide emissions of new passenger cars, initially Regulation (EC) No 443/2009
of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of April 23, 2009, as last amended by EU Commission
Delegated Regulation (EU) 2018/649 of January 23, 2018 (“Regulation 443/2009”) limited the
average carbon dioxide emissions of the new car fleet in the EU by setting a target of 95 grams of
carbon dioxide per kilometer from 2020 onwards. With regard to carbon dioxide emissions of light
commercial vehicles (class N1), Regulation (EU) No 510/2011 of the EU Parliament and of the EU
Council of May 11, 2011, as last amended by EU Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2019/986 of
March 7, 2019 (“Regulation 510/2011”), limited the average emissions of new light commercial
vehicles registered in the EU to 147 grams of carbon dioxide per kilometer from 2020 onwards.

Both regulations, i.e. Regulation 443/2009 and Regulation (EU) No 510/2011, were repealed with
effect from January 1, 2020 by Regulation (EU) 2019/631 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council
of April 17, 2019, as last amended by EU Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/1961 of August
5, 2021 (“Regulation 2019/631”), setting CO2 emission performance standards for both, new
passenger and new light commercial vehicles (produced by manufacturers inside or outside the EU)
and, in particular, changing the test procedure which is basis for the calculation of fleet limits from
the “New European Driving Cycle” (the “NEDC”) to the new “Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles
Test Procedure” (the “WLTP”). As did previous Regulations, Regulation 2019/631 stipulates fleetwide targets, i.e. each manufacturer (inside or outside the EU) has to fulfill an individual emissions
target calculated on the basis of the individual manufacturer’s fleet. The emission limits are
calculated as a function of their mass. Manufacturers may form a pool in order to meet their targets.
Where two or more manufacturers form a pool, the pool will be treated as if it were one
manufacturer for the purposes of determining its compliance with the targets. If a manufacturer
exceeds the fleet limit, it has to pay €95 per gram of excess per number of newly registered vehicles.

From 2020 onwards, a target of 95 grams of carbon dioxide per kilometer for 95% of the
manufacturer’s new passenger car fleet applies, i.e. 5% of the fleet with the highest emissions are not


-----

taken into account. With respect to new light commercial vehicles, a target of 147 grams of carbon
dioxide per kilometer for 95% of the manufacturer’s new light commercial vehicle car fleet applies.
However, in 2020, all fleet limits were still being calculated on the basis of the NEDC, which was the
prescribed test procedure for determining CO2 and pollutant emissions from 1992 to 2018.

From 2021 until 2024, for both new passenger and light commercial vehicles, the aforementioned
targets shall apply to 100% of the manufacturer’s fleet. Also from 2021, for both new passenger and
new light commercial vehicles, the fleet limits are calculated on the basis of the WLTP replacing the
former NEDC, which no longer adequately reflects current driving conditions and vehicle
technologies. As a result of the change of the specification to the new WLTP test procedure, it is
expected that the nominal consumption value will increase by an average of around 20%.

Moreover, Regulation 2019/631 stipulates that from January 2025, for the average emissions of both
the new passenger car fleet and the new light commercial vehicles fleet, an EU fleet-wide target
equal to a 15% reduction of the 2021 target will apply. From January 2030, for the average emissions
of the new passenger car fleet an equal to a 37.5% reduction of the 2021 target will apply and for the
average emissions of the new light commercial vehicles fleet, an EU fleet-wide target equal to a 31%
reduction of the 2021 target will apply.

On July 14, 2021, as part of the so-called “Fit for 55” legislative package, the EU Commission
presented a proposal for a regulation amending Regulation (EU) 2019/631 to strengthen the CO2
emission performance standards for new passenger cars and new light commercial vehicles in line
with the EU’s increased climate ambition in order to help accelerate the transition to low- and zero
emission vehicles. The proposal aims to accelerate the transition by requiring average CO2 emissions
of new passenger cars and light commercial vehicles to be reduced by 55% by 2030 and 100% by
2035, each as compared to 2021 levels. This would also mean that all new vehicles registered on or
after January 1, 2035 would be required to have zero CO2 emissions and incentives for zero and lowemission vehicles would no longer apply from 2030. The EU Parliament and the EU Council adopted
their positions in June 2022; a trilogue agreement on the proposal was reached on October 27, 2022.
The agreed text was formally adopted by the EU Parliament on February 14, 2023 and needs to be
formally adopted by the EU Council before publication in the EU’s Official Journal.

On February 14, 2023, the EU Commission presented a proposal for a regulation amending
Regulation (EU) 2019/1242 to strengthen the CO2 emission performance standards for new heavyduty vehicles and integrating reporting obligations to reduce CO2 emissions in the transport sector.
The proposal includes requiring average CO2 emissions of most new heavy duty vehicles to be
reduced by 45% by 2030, 65% by 2035 and 90% by 2040, each as compared to 2019 levels. In
addition, to accelerate the deployment of zero-emission buses in cities, the proposal would also
require all new city buses to have zero CO2 emissions as of 2030. Before the proposed regulation is
published in the EU’s Official Journal, it will need to be formally adopted by the EU Parliament and
the EU Council.

The WLTP was introduced by EU Commission Regulation (EU) 2017/1151 of June 1, 2017 (last
amended by EU Commission Regulation (EU) 2020/49 of January 21, 2020). The WLTP was developed
with the aim of being used as a global test cycle across different world regions, so pollutant and CO2
emissions as well as fuel consumption values would be comparable worldwide. However, while the
WLTP has a common global ‘core’, the EU and other regions will apply the test in different ways
depending on their road traffic laws and needs. It is carried out on the chassis dyno test bench and
replaced the former NEDC. Since September 1, 2017, new car models have to pass the WLTP before
they can be driven on European roads. On September 1, 2018, the test became mandatory for all
new cars and all light duty vehicles sold after this date. Shortly after the introduction of the WLTP,
the EU Commission Regulation (EU) 2017/1151 was amended by EU Commission Regulation (EU)
2018/1832 of November 5, 2018 (“WLTP 2nd Act”) for the purpose of improving the emission type
approval tests and procedures for light passenger and commercial vehicles. Since January 1, 2019,


-----

new measurements have to be carried out in accordance with the provisions of this regulation. Inter
alia, all new passenger and light commercial vehicles must be fitted with an On-board Fuel and/or
Energy Consumption Monitoring Device (“OBFCM”) from January 1, 2020. This software records the
fuel consumption of vehicles and the energy consumption of electric or plug-in hybrid cars. However,
the WLTP 2nd Act only contains the requirement to install an OBFCM device. How the CO2 values are
recorded and evaluated must still be specified by the legislator. This was subject of the work being
carried out by the “Obm Task Force,” which the EU Commission mandated to develop a technical
solution by the end of 2020. With the WLTP 2nd Act, the EU Commission adopted all changes to the
global WLTP framework that have been decided upon at the United Nations level by way of the
Global Technical Regulation No. 15 Amendment 6 and, moreover, added several provisions valid only
in Europe. All vehicles newly approved in the EU must fulfill the requirements of the new procedure
by September 2019.

With respect to carbon dioxide emissions from heavy-duty vehicles and trucks, Regulation (EU)
2019/1242 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of June 20, 2019 (“Regulation 2019/1242”)
limits the carbon dioxide emissions from trucks and buses. It applies to new heavy-duty vehicles of
categories N2 and N3. Compared to the EU average in the reference period (July 1, 2019 to June 30,
2020) emissions shall be reduced by 15% from 2025 onwards and by 30% from 2030 onwards. The
2025 target can be achieved using technologies that are already available on the market. The 2030
target will be assessed in 2022 as part of the review of the Regulation. Regulation 2019/1242 applies
to four categories of large trucks, which together account for 65 to 70% of emissions from heavyduty vehicles. The EU Commission proposed to review the legislation in 2022 to fix the target for
2030 and extend its application to smaller trucks, buses, coaches and trailers. By 2023, the EU
Commission shall evaluate the possibility of developing a common methodology for the assessment
and reporting of the full life-cycle CO2 emissions of heavy-duty vehicles. On December 20, 2021, the
EU Commission opened public consultation on the revision of Regulation 2019/1242, which ended on
March 14, 2022. The EU Commission adopted the proposal on the revision of the CO2 standards for
heavy duty vehicles on February 14, 2023.

Furthermore, Regulation (EU) No 168/2013 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of January 15,
2013 (last amended by Regulation (EU) 2020/1694 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of
November 11, 2020) includes specific emission thresholds for two- and three-wheelers and
quadricycles. In case of powered cycles, mopeds and light quadricycles, these thresholds apply as of
January 1, 2017, for new vehicles and as of January 1, 2018, for existing vehicles. In case of
motorcycles, tricycles and heavy quadri-mobiles, these thresholds apply as of January 1, 2016, for
new vehicles and as of January 1, 2017, for existing vehicles.

Air pollution

On November 10, 2022, the EU Commission presented a proposal to reduce air pollution from new
motor vehicles sold in the EU to meet the European Green Deal’s zero-pollution ambition (Proposal
COM (2022) 586 final). The Euro 7 emission standards are needed to set more ambitious limits for air
pollutants and will ensure that cars, vans, lorries and buses are much cleaner, in real driving
conditions that better reflect the situation in cities where air pollution problems are largest, and for a
much longer period than under current rules. The proposal tackles emissions from tailpipes as well as
from brakes and tires.

The proposal replaces and simplifies previously separate emission rules for cars and vans (Euro 6) and
lorries and buses (Euro VI) by implementing emission limits for all motor vehicles, i.e., cars, vans,
buses and lorries under a single set of rules. The new emission standards are fuel- and technologyneutral, placing the same limits regardless of whether the vehicle uses petrol, diesel, electric drivetrains or alternative fuels. They will also set emission limits for previously unregulated pollutants,
such as nitrous oxide emissions from heavy-duty vehicles. Moreover, Euro 7 emission standards will
be the first worldwide emission standards to move beyond regulating exhaust pipe emissions and set


-----

additional limits for particulate emissions from brakes and rules on micro plastic emissions from tires.
Currently, Euro 6 standard cars must comply with the emission requirements only up to 100,000
kilometers or 5 years of use. To better reflect the lifecycle of vehicles, the Euro 7 emission standards
will need to be respected up to 200,000 kilometers and 10 years of use. Both light- and heavy-duty
vehicles will need to be equipped with on-board emissions monitoring systems (OBM). The Euro 7
emission standards do not address CO2 emissions from road vehicles. These are the subject of
separate EU regulations for light- and heavy-duty vehicles.

According to the EU Commission’s proposal, the date for the entry into force of the new regulation
will be July 1, 2025 for new light-duty vehicles (cars and vans), and July 1, 2027 for new heavy-duty
vehicles (lorries and buses). Limited exceptions apply to vehicles constructed by small volume
manufacturers in light of specific technology constraints. The EU Commission’s proposal will be
submitted to the EU Parliament and the EU Council in view of its adoption by the co-legislators.

Greenhouse Gases

Moreover, the EU aims to promote the use of biofuels as a replacement for diesel or gas in order to
reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Former Directive 2009/28/EC of the EU Parliament and of the EU
Council of April 23, 2009 on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources was
repealed with effect from July 1, 2021 by the Directive (EU) 2018/2001 of the EU Parliament and of
the EU Council of December 11, 2018 on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources
as last amended by the EU Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/759 of December 14, 2021
(“RED II”), which entered into force on December 22, 2018. Accordingly, EU member states shall
collectively ensure that the share of energy from renewable sources in the EU’s gross final
consumption of energy in 2030 is at least 32%, including a transportation-specific sub target of at
least 14% of all energy in road and rail transport fuels. In 2021, the EU Commission proposed
amendments to RED II as a part of the “Fit for 55” Legislative package. Inter alia, the proposal seeks
to convert the 14% target for renewable energy in transport to a greenhouse gas intensity reduction
target of 13%, better aligning it with the EU’s 2030 climate goals. This would allow for fuels to instead
be counted towards the 13% reduction target, based on their greenhouse gas saving.

**_Disposal, Reuse, Recycling and Recovery of Motor Vehicles_**

Regulatory requirements related to disposal, reuse, recycling and recovery of motor vehicles as set
out below apply to our customers in the automotive industry. Furthermore, we are legally obliged to
support our customers in fulfilling such requirements. We therefore assist our customers by
continuously developing our products in accordance with the regulatory requirements applicable to
the products of our customers.

Directive 2000/53/EC of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of September 18, 2000 on end-of
life vehicles, last amended by EU Commission Delegated Directive (EU) 2020/363 of December 17,
2019 (“ELV Directive”), stipulates measures to prevent waste arising from end-of-life vehicles and to
promote the collection, reuse and recycling of vehicle components. Waste prevention is the priority
objective of the ELV Directive. To this end, it stipulates that vehicle manufacturers supported by
material and equipment manufacturers like us must: (i) endeavor to reduce the use of hazardous
substances when designing vehicles; (ii) design and produce vehicles which facilitate the dismantling,
reuse, recovery and recycling of end-of-life vehicles; (iii) increase the use of recycled materials in
vehicle manufacture; and (iv) ensure that components of vehicles placed on the market after July 1,
2003, do not contain mercury, hexavalent chromium, cadmium or lead, except for the cases listed in
Annex II of the ELV Directive and under the conditions specified therein. Most spare parts that are
put on the market after July 1, 2003 and used for vehicles put on the market before July 1, 2003 are
excluded.


-----

The EU Commission carried out an evaluation of the ELV Directive to identify good and bad practices
in its implementation and assess whether it has met its objectives. Currently, the EU Commission is
reviewing it in light of the Circular Economy Action Plan 2020. The revision seeks to promote more
circularity by linking design issues to end-of-life treatment, considering rules on mandatory recycled
content for certain materials of components and improving recycling efficiency. The EU Commission
envisages to merge Directive 2000/53/EC and Directive 2005/64/EC of October 26, 2005 on the type
approval of motor vehicles with regard to their reusability, recyclability and recoverability into a
single instrument, covering the whole life cycle of the automotive sector. The legislative proposal, to
be accompanied by an impact assessment, was expected in the fourth quarter of 2022, but has not
yet been published. On December 16, 2022, a legislative proposal was published in regards to the
exemptions for the use of lead in aluminum alloys for machining purposes, in copper alloys and in
certain batteries.

**_Product Safety and Liability_**

_Product Safety_

We have to comply with requirements for product safety as well as specific applicable provisions
(e.g., standards for automotive products).

Directive 2001/95/EC of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of December 3, 2001 (last amended
by Regulation (EC) No 596/2009 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of June 18, 2009) on
general product safety (the “General Product Safety Directive”) applies in the absence of specific
provisions among the EU regulations governing the safety of products concerned, or if sectorial
legislation is insufficient. Under this Directive, manufacturers must put on the market only products
which comply with the general safety requirement.

A safe product is one which poses no threat or only a reduced threat in accordance with the nature
of its use and which is acceptable in view of maintaining a high level of protection for the health and
safety of persons. In addition to compliance with the safety requirement, manufacturers must
provide consumers with the necessary information in order to assess a product’s inherent threat,
particularly when this is not directly obvious, and take the necessary measures to avoid such threats
(for example, withdraw products from the market, inform consumers, recall products which have
already been supplied to consumers etc.). In accordance with Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 on market
surveillance and compliance of products (the “Market Surveillance Regulation”), each economic
operator is also obliged to supply products that comply with the general safety requirement, to
monitor the safety of products on the market and to provide the necessary documents ensuring that
the products can be traced. If any economic operator discovers that a product is dangerous, they
must notify the competent authorities and, if necessary, cooperate with them. The Market
Surveillance Regulation prohibits the placing on the market of certain goods unless an economic
operator established in the EU is identified as responsible for ensuring the availability of the
conformity documentation, cooperating with market surveillance authorities and informing
authorities when they have reasons to believe that a product presents a risk. Appointed national
authorities are responsible for market surveillance. They check whether products available on the
market are safe, ensure product safety legislation and rules are applied by manufacturers and
business chains and apply sanctions when necessary. Moreover, national authorities notify the EU
Commission by using RAPEX, an information system for the rapid exchange of information between
the EU member states and the EU Commission on measures and action taken in relation to products
posing a serious risk to the health and safety of consumers.

In a resolution of November 25, 2020 (2019/2190(INI)) the EU Parliament called for a revision of the
General Product Safety Directive and urged the EU Commission to update and establish aligned
market surveillance rules for both harmonized and non-harmonized products placed on the market
offline or online, and to make them fit for purpose in the digital age in order to ensure a level playing


-----

field and improve product safety. In June 2021, the EU Commission adopted a proposal for a new
general product safety regulation (COM(2021) 346 final). The proposal mainly contains regulations
with regard to the responsibility for products placed on the market, improved recall rules and
consumer remedies in case of a recall. Both the EU Parliament as well as the EU Council are currently
working on the proposal.

_Product Liability_

We are subject to product liability regulations and may therefore be held liable for damages caused
by a defective or nonperforming product manufactured by us. Liability for defective or
nonperforming products may in particular be based on the provisions of civil and tort law of the
individual EU Member States, but also on criminal law.

On the EU level, EU Council Directive 85/374/EEC of July 25, 1985, as amended by Directive
1999/34/EC of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of May 10, 1999 (the “Product Liability
**Directive”), introduced a system of objective liability, i.e., liability without fault of the producer, in**
cases of damage caused by a defective product. The Product Liability Directive applies to movables
which have been industrially produced, whether or not incorporated into another movable or into an
immovable. “Producer” means the manufacturer of a finished product, the producer of any raw
material or the manufacturer of a component part and any person who, by putting his name,
trademark or other distinguishing feature on the product presents himself as its producer. Any
person who imports into the EU a product for sale, hire, leasing or any form of distribution in the
course of his business shall be deemed to be a producer. Where the producer of the product cannot
be identified, each supplier of the product is treated as its producer unless he informs the injured
person of the identity of the producer or of the person who supplied him with the product. The same
applies in the case of an imported product, if this product does not indicate the identity of the
importer.

“Defectiveness” means lack of the safety which the general public is entitled to expect given, inter
_alia, the presentation of the product and the use to which it could reasonably be put._

Producers can be cleared of liability under certain conditions, notably, if they prove that they did not
put the product into circulation, the defect was due to the compliance of the product with
mandatory regulations issued by public authorities or the state of scientific or technical knowledge at
the time the product was put into circulation could not detect the defect.

The Product Liability Directive applies to damage caused by death or by personal injuries and damage
to an item of property intended for private use or consumption other than the defective product,
with a lower threshold of a €500 damage caused by defective products. It sets out a time limit of
3 years for the recovery of damages and forbids clauses limiting or excluding the liability of the
producer. The Product Liability Directive does not restrict compensation for non-material damage
under national legislation.

Starting in 2019, the EU Commission was carrying out a formal evaluation of the Product Liability
Directive due to an increasing need for updating the existing product liability rules to make them fit
for the digital age and the circular economy, including for the ‘new’ types of goods that to a greater
extent come to shape the future economy of Europe. The EU Commission intended to produce
guidance to address the way in which the Product Liability Directive applies to artificial intelligence,
robotics and the Internet of Things and on its broader implications.

In October 2021, the EU Commission launched a public consultation on the revision of the Product
Liability Directive with a focus on liability rules in the digital age and artificial intelligence. On
September 28, 2022, the EU Commission published its proposal for revising the Product Liability
Directive. The proposed revision of the Directive is intended to modernize and reinforce the current
well-established rules, based on the strict liability of manufacturers, for the compensation of


-----

personal injury, damage to property and data loss caused by unsafe products. Under current
legislation, companies are obliged to compensate people injured by defective products. According to
the proposal, the Product Liability Directive will require companies to also disclose evidence that a
claimant would need to prove their case in court. In addition, the EU Commission’s proposal, once it
has entered into force, would introduce provisions ensuring that there should always be a business
or legal representative based in the EU that can be held liable for defective products bought directly
from manufacturers outside the EU. In order to become law, the EU Commission’s proposal will need
to be adopted by the EU Parliament and the EU Council.

**_Energy Efficiency_**

Directive 2012/27/EU of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of October 25, 2012 (last amended
by Directive (EU) 2019/944 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of June 5, 2019) (“EED
**Directive”), requires all enterprises except for small or medium-sized enterprises to carry out energy**
audits.

The revised EED Directive establishes a binding EU target of at least 32.5% efficiency improvements
for 2030. With the exception of certain provisions, the revised EED Directive was to be transposed
into national legislation by June 25, 2020. The EU Commission is required to evaluate the functioning
of the revised EED Directive by 2023, and could accompany this review with a legislative proposal
that raises the headline target.

On July 14, 2021, the EU Commission published a proposal for recasting the EED Directive, forming
part of the EU Commission package of proposals “Delivering on the European Green Deal.” It seeks to
introduce a higher target for reducing primary (39%) and final (36%) energy consumption by 2030
that is binding at the EU level, an increase from the current target of 32.5%. In addition, the proposed
directive introduces a benchmarking system for EU member states to set their national indicative
contributions to the binding EU target. The new directive also proposes to nearly double EU member
states annual end use energy savings obligations. To stimulate this acceleration, the proposal focuses
on sectors with high energy-savings potential, notably heating and cooling, industry and energy
services. In May 2022, the EU Commission updated the proposed target for overall energy savings,
raising it from 9% to 13% and began discussions for a much more ambitious target of 14.5%.

In Germany, the EED Directive has been implemented by a Federal law on energy services (Gesetz
_über Energiedienstleistungen und andere Energieeffizienzmaßnahmen). Accordingly, energy audits_
are, as a rule, mandatory on a four-year basis. On November 26, 2019, the amended Federal law on
energy services implementing the revised EED Directive into German law entered into force. Inter
alia, companies subject to energy audits are now required to submit an online energy audit
declaration to the Federal Office for Export and Economic Control (Bundesamt für Wirtschaft und
_Ausfuhrkontrolle,_ _BAFA)._

**_Regulations on Aeronautical Products, Parts and Appliances_**

As we manufacture aeronautical products, parts and appliances, we have to comply with the
following regulatory requirements:

The design, production and maintenance of aeronautical products, parts and appliances was initially
regulated by Regulation (EC) No 216/2008 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of February 20,
2008, as last amended by EU Commission Regulation (EU) 4/2016 of January 5, 2016, as a basic
regulation. As of September 11, 2018, this regulation was repealed by Regulation (EU) 2018/1139 of
the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of July 4, 2018 (last amended by EU Commission Regulation
(EU) 2021/1087 of April 7, 2021) on common rules in the field of civil aviation and establishing a
European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA). The principal objective of this regulation is to
establish and maintain a high uniform level of civil aviation safety across Europe. Inter alia, the new
regulation includes essential requirements for the design, production, maintenance, the noise and


-----

emission requirements and operation of unmanned aircraft and, thus, aims to ensure the safe use of
unmanned aerial systems. Accordingly, unmanned aircraft systems need to be designed and used in a
way that they do not put people at risk.

Moreover, detailed requirements for the design and production of aeronautical products are
provided by EU Commission Regulation (EU) No 748/2012 of August 3, 2012, as last amended by EU
Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2022/203 of February 14, 2022 (“Regulation 748/2012”).
Furthermore, detailed requirements for the maintenance of aeronautical products are included in EU
Commission Regulation (EU) No 1321/2014 of November 26, 2014, as last amended by EU
Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2022/410 of March 10, 2022.

Under Regulation 748/2012, an organization responsible for the design of products, parts and
appliances related to aircraft requires a design organization approval (“DOA”) according to Annex I to
Regulation 748/2012 (so-called “Part 21”), Subpart J. The holder of DOA is entitled to perform design
activities under Part 21 within the scope approved in DOA. Furthermore, the EASA will accept specific
compliance documents submitted by the holder of the DOA without further verification.

The production of several products, parts and appliances related to aircraft requires a production
organization approval (“POA”) according to Part 21, Subpart G. The POA demonstrates conformity of
the manufactured products, parts and appliances with their applicable design data.

In addition, organizations involved in the maintenance of large aircrafts and related components
require a maintenance organization approval (“MOA”) according to Annex II to EU Commission
Regulation (EU) No 1321/2014. The holder of a MOA is entitled to, for example, maintain any aircraft
or component at the sites for which the holder is approved according to the MOA and the
maintenance organization exposition relating to the MOA.

EU Commission Regulation (EU) 2018/1142 amended Regulation (EU) No 1321/2014 by introducing
additional categories of Aircraft Maintenance Licenses, modifying the acceptance procedure of
components from external suppliers and by modifying the maintenance training organizations’
privileges. It is, too, to ensure a high and uniform level of aviation safety at Union level and to reduce
potential safety risks that may arise from a shortage of qualified personnel.

**_Regulations on Artificial Intelligence_**

The EU Parliament and the EU Council set out a proposal for a regulation of laying down harmonized
rules on artificial intelligence (“Artificial Intelligence Act”) of April 21, 2021 (COM(2021)206 final). It
intends to regulate the use of artificial intelligence, but not the technology itself, and prohibits the
use of artificial intelligence systems in certain application scenarios or makes their use dependent on
technical and organizational requirements. The Artificial Intelligence Act would apply to providers
placing on the market or putting into service AI systems, such as robotics specialists, in the EU and to
AI users. In December 2022, the EU Council of the EU approved a compromised version of the
proposed Artificial Intelligence Act. In order to become law, it will next have to be adopted by the EU
Parliament.

**_Regulations on Products for Rail Vehicles_**

As we manufacture products for rail vehicles we have to comply, inter alia, with the following
regulatory requirements:

Products for rail vehicles are subject to several regulations on EU level. With effect from June 16,
2020, Directive (EU) No 2016/797 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of May 11, 2016 on the
interoperability of the rail system within the EU (last amended by Directive (EU) No 2020/700 of the
EU Parliament and of the EU Council of 25 May 2020 as regards the extension of the transposition
periods) came into force. Moreover, Directive 2004/49/EC was repealed by Directive (EU) No
2016/798 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of May 11, 2016 (last amended by Regulation
(EU) 2020/1530 of October 21, 2020) on railway safety with effect from June 16, 2020. Both


-----

Directives have been adopted in the course of the “Fourth Railway Package,” its purpose being to
eliminate the national administrative and technical barriers between the different EU member states,
which are considered to be a hindrance to the interoperability and to reduce costs of railways in
order to increase the competitiveness of the railway sector. These directives were supplemented by
Regulation (EU) 2016/796 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of May 11, 2016 on the
European Union Agency for Railways. In particular, these regulations concern the design,
construction, placing in service, upgrading, renewal, operation and maintenance of the parts of this
system and are further specified by technical specifications for interoperability (“TSI”). The TSIs are
drafted for both the high speed as well as the conventional railway system.

Directive 2016/797 provides for the drafting and revision of the TSIs. It has been supplemented by
the EU Commission Delegated Decision (EU) No 2017/1474 of June 8, 2017 defining more specifically
the objectives of each TSI in order to improve interoperability and facilitate the development and
improvement of rail services with third countries. Moreover, on April 4, 2018, the EU Commission
Implementing Regulation (EU) 2018/545 (last amended by Commission Regulation (EU) 2020/781 of
June 12, 2020) establishing practical arrangements for the railway vehicle authorization and railway
vehicle type authorization process pursuant to Directive (EU) No 2016/797 has been adopted. With
respect to the Fourth Railway Package, implementing regulations are issued to make sure that
national legislation is consistent across all EU member states. This regulation governs the
authorization of railway vehicles throughout Europe and aims to further speed up, simplify and
reduce the cost of the approval procedure for rolling stock.

Directive (EU) No 2016/798 (last amended by Regulation (EU) No 2020/1530 of the EU Parliament
and of the EU Council of October 21, 2020) provides for the drafting and revision of common safety
methods (“CSMs”), common safety targets and common safety indicators. Inter alia, since February
2018, the EU Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2018/761 (last amended by Commission
Regulation (EU) 2020/782 of June 12, 2020), which is based on Directive (EU) 2016/798, establishes
CSMs for supervision by national safety authorities following the issue of a uniform safety certificate
or a safety authorization for conformity assessment and surveillance. The CSMs shall be regularly
revised in order to maintain and continuously improve safety, taking into account the general
development of railway safety.

EU member states had to transpose Directive 2008/57/EC by July 19, 2010. Its proper
implementation remained obligatory under the Fourth Railway Package. They had time until
June 16, 2019 to transpose the interoperability and safety directives into national law. With respect
to Germany, an infringement proceeding had been opened in February 2016 after Germany had
failed to implement Directive 2008/57/EC. On August 11, 2018, the German Railway Commissioning
Approval Regulation (Eisenbahn-Inbetriebnahmegenehmigungsverordnung) entered into force
transposing EU law on rail interoperability. However, since Directive 2008/57/EC had been repealed
by Directive (EU) 2016/797 with effect from June 16, 2020, member states also have to transpose the
new Directive into national law. In Germany, the Directive has been implemented by regulations
implementing the 4th railway package of the European Union of March 16, 2020, e.g. by way of
amendments to the German Railway Act (Allgemeines Eisenbahngesetz) and the German Federal
Railway Traffic Administration Act (Bundeseisenbahnverkehrsverwaltungsgesetz). However, on May
14, 2020, the EU Commission requested that Germany make further amendments, and, in particular,
referred to the German provisions concerning the requirements for braking systems of freight
wagons not being in line with EU law and, thus, hampering efforts towards interoperability. On
January 26, 2023, the Commission sent letters of formal notice to Germany to implement correctly
the rail interoperability and safety rules of Directive (EU) 2016/797 and Directive (EU) 2016/798. This
procedure is still pending.

As regards the high-speed railway system, TSI for the rolling stock subsystem were adopted on
May 30, 2002 (EU Commission Decision No 2002/735/EC), and revised by EU Commission Decision No
2008/232/EC of February 21, 2008, which has been repealed by EU Commission Regulation (EU) No


-----

1302/2014 of November 18, 2014, last amended by the EU Commission Implementing Regulation
(EU) 2020/387 of March 9, 2020.

Concerning the conventional railway system, TSI relating to locomotives and passenger rolling stock
were adopted by EU Commission Decision No 2011/291/EU on April 26, 2011, as amended by
Commission Decision 2012/464/EU of July 23, 2012 which has been, too, repealed by EU Commission
Regulation (EU) No 1302/2014 of November 18, 2014. In addition, TSI on freight wagons have been
established by Commission Regulation (EU) No 321/2013 of March 13, 2013, last amended by EU
Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2020/387 of March 9, 2020. TSI concerning noise have
been issued by EU Commission Decision 2011/229/EU of April 4, 2011 which has been repealed by EU
Commission Regulation (EU) No 1304/2014 of November 26, 2014, last amended by EU Commission
Implementing Regulation (EU) 2019/774 of May 16, 2019.

Applicable technical standards for the TSI are published by the European Railways Agency on a
regular basis.

Directive 2004/49/EC on Safety of the Community’s railways was amended by EU Commission
Directive 2014/88/EU of July 9, 2014 in respect of common safety indicators and common methods
of calculating accident costs. Furthermore, Directive 2004/49/EC was subject to a recast by the
Directive (EU) 2016/798 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of May 11, 2016, last amended
by Directive (EU) 2020/1530 of the EU Parliament and of the EU Council of October 21, 2020. The
intent of this recast was to improve the railway safety and oblige manufacturers of products for
railway vehicles to carry out risk control measures and to report known risks to other actors of the
rail system.

**_Regulations on Medical Devices_**

We manufacture accessories for medical devices (e.g., bearing support systems for computer
tomography) and are therefore obliged to comply with several requirements of the European
Medical Device Regulation (EU) 2017/745 (last amended by Regulation (EU) 2020/561 of the EU
Parliament and of the EU Council of April 23, 2020) (the “Medical Device Regulation”), which has
been applicable since May 26, 2021. The Medical Device Regulation repealed EU Council Directive
93/42/EEC to ensure that only one set of rules applies to the placing of medical devices on the
market and the related aspects covered by this Regulation. It aims to enhance patient safety and
modernize public health by introducing an enhanced governance framework around the definition,
supervision, traceability and risk-based classification system for medical device equipment.

Moreover, in 2017, the EU Commission issued the EU Commission Implementing Regulation (EU)
2017/2185 of November 23, 2017 on the list of codes and corresponding types of devices for the
purpose of specifying the scope of the designation as notified bodies in the field of medical devices.

### Regulatory Framework for our Products in the United States

There are numerous regulations that govern the automotive, aviation and railway sectors in the
United States. Vehicles, aircraft, rail cars and their components have to comply with numerous
standards that were enacted for safety and environmental reasons. Many of our products must
conform to these standards and regulations. Changes in regulations and standards could result in
increased costs for our business.

Federal, state, and municipal governments all enforce a variety of regulations addressing
environmental, health, and safety concerns. At the federal level, those laws include (but are not
limited to): the Clean Air Act (“CAA”), which regulates air emissions from mobile and stationary
sources; the Clean Water Act, which regulates discharges with the potential to impact certain bodies
of water; the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (“CERCLA”),
which provides that owners and operators of contaminated sites face joint and several liability


-----

regardless of fault for investigating and remediating such sites; and the Resource Conservation and
Recovery Act, which governs the cradle-to-grave management and disposal of a variety of solid and
hazardous substances. There are a wide variety of additional federal laws which impose obligations
on manufacturers to reduce pollution in the environment. Moreover, US states and many US
municipalities have analogous laws regulating these same sectors that apply to our operations in the
United States.

**_Vehicle emissions and fuel economy_**

The CAA grants the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (“EPA”) the authority to impose and
enforce air quality standards, including vehicle emissions requirements for passenger vehicles, lightduty trucks, and heavy-duty vehicles.

In March 2014, the EPA finalized the Tier 3 Vehicle Emission and Fuel Standards Program which
regulates vehicle emission and evaporative standards for passenger vehicles, light-duty trucks, and
certain heavy-duty vehicles, and sets standards for the release of volatile organic compounds, carbon
monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and particulate matters, as well as standards governing a vehicle’s
guaranteed useful life and other matters.

Under the Federal Motor Vehicle Information and Cost Savings Act, automobile manufacturers are
required to comply with the Corporate Average Fuel Economy (“CAFE”) standards, which are
enforced by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (“NHTSA”), and apply to passenger
vehicles and light-duty trucks. The CAFE regulations were enacted in 1975 and were first used to set
fuel economy standards in 1978. The CAFE fuel economy standards, which take into account
technological feasibility, economic practicality, the effect of other standards on fuel economy and the
need of the nation to conserve energy, are set years in advance of production to allow manufacturers
time to comply with the standards. The standards apply to the average of a manufacturer’s fleet of
vehicles, rather than to each individual vehicle.

Fuel economy standards were dramatically impacted by the Energy Independence and Security Act of
2007, which amended the Energy Policy and Conservation Act. The Energy Independence and
Security Act initially set a goal for national fuel economy of 35 miles per gallon for both cars and light
trucks by 2020, and NHTSA has had to periodically raise CAFE standards to meet this goal.

In October 2016, EPA and NHTSA finalized CAFE and greenhouse gas emissions (“GHG”) standards for
medium- and heavy-duty trucks from 2018 through model year 2027, which vary by the type and
weight of the vehicle.

In April 2020, EPA and NHTSA issued the Safer Affordable Fuel Efficient Vehicles Rule (the “SAFE
**Rule”), a two-part regulation. Part One broadly allowed NHTSA to preempt state and local laws**
related to fuel economy standards. In particular, Part One revoked a federal waiver, issued by the
EPA in 2013, authorizing the California Air Resource Board (“CARB”) to adopt and enforce stricter
emissions standards than those required under federal law. The SAFE Rule also challenged
California’s Low Emission Vehicle (“LEV III”) program, which sets standards for guaranteed useful life
and evaporative emissions, and reduces emissions of smog pollutants (including carbon monoxide,
nitrogen oxides, and particular matter) and GHGs for passenger vehicles and light-duty trucks for
model years 2015 to 2025. A number of states have adopted regulations substantially similar to
California’s ZEV and LEV III programs.

Part Two of the regulation amended CAFE and GHG emissions standards for passenger vehicles and
light-duty trucks for model years 2021 through 2026, and set a new, less stringent fuel economy
target of 40 miles per gallon by 2026. In December 2021, NHTSA repealed “Part One” of the SAFE
Rule, eliminating the preemption of state and local laws. NHTSA has also proposed a repeal of “Part
Two” of the SAFE Rule. If and when such repeal occurs, it may or may not be replaced by more
stringent fuel-economy standards. In December 2021, EPA issued its own rule establishing revised,


-----

more stringent national GHG emissions standards for passenger cars and light trucks for model years
2023 to 2026.

Recent regulatory developments also indicate future changes to standards applicable to the heavyduty truck and engine sector. In January 2020, EPA issued an Advance Notice of Proposed Rule
(“ANPR”) requesting comments on new rules based on EPA’s 2018 Cleaner Trucks Initiative, which
would establish, among other things, new emission standards for nitrogen oxides (“NOx”) and other
pollutants for heavy-duty engines. Pursuant to that initiative, in August 2021 EPA announced plans to
address GHG and other emissions from heavy-duty trucks through a series of rulemakings over the
next three years. The first proposed rule, announced March 7, 2022, sets standards to reduce NOx
emissions. EPA issued a related final rule in December 2022, effective March 27, 2023, that imposes
more stringent emissions standards covering a wider range of heavy-duty engine operating
conditions compared to previous standards. The final rule is a part of the comprehensive “Clean
Trucks Plan” and will apply to heavy-duty vehicles and engines starting with model year 2027. EPA is
expected to release proposals in 2023 for two remaining steps to the Clean Trucks Plan, including
proposals for a heavy-duty GHG standards “Phase 3” rule for model years 2027 and later, and a
multipollutant standards proposal for light and medium-duty vehicles for model years 2027 and later.
In August 2020, CARB also adopted a Heavy-Duty Low NOx Omnibus Regulation requiring
manufacturers to comply with more stringent emissions standards. Specifically, the proposed HeavyDuty Low NOx Omnibus Regulation would revise exhaust emission standards, cutting NOx standards
to 75% below current standards beginning in 2024, and 90% below current standards in 2027, and
change testing programs and procedures. Other states have followed suit, as Oregon has also
approved the Heavy-Duty Low NOx Omnibus Regulation, and several others have approved similar
rules requiring the production and sale of successively cleaner trucks over time.

**_Road Safety and Technical Standards_**

NHTSA issues Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards (“FMVSS”) to which manufacturers of vehicle
equipment must conform. The first standard became effective on March 1, 1967, and NHTSA has
issued new standards and amended existing standards on a regular basis. Currently, up to 67 FMVSSs
must be considered in a self-certification process before a vehicle may be released into the U.S.
market.

The NHTSA regulations relate primarily to crash avoidance and crashworthiness and cover a wide
variety of automotive products and systems, including windshield wipers, brakes, hydraulic systems,
tires, mirrors, seat belts, head restraints and fuel systems. In general, the regulations are written in
terms of minimum safety performance requirements for motor vehicles or items of motor vehicle
equipment. These requirements are specified in such a manner that the public is protected against
unreasonable risk of crashes occurring as a result of the design, construction or performance of
motor vehicles and is also protected against unreasonable risk of death or injury in the event crashes
do occur.

In 2016, NHTSA secured a voluntary commitment from 20 automakers representing over 99% of U.S.
market share to equip future vehicles with automatic electronic braking systems (“AEBS”). AEBS will
become standard on almost all light-duty cars and trucks with a GVW of 8,500 pounds or less
beginning no later than September 1, 2022 and on almost all trucks with GVW between 8,501 pounds
and 10,000 pounds beginning no later than September 1, 2025. These requirements will impose
significant new costs on manufacturers.

NHTSA also responds to legislative mandates. In 2000, the U.S. Congress passed the Transportation
Recall Enhancement, Accountability, and Documentation Act (“TREAD Act”) that directed NHTSA to
adopt a new regulation requiring: (i) manufacturers who sell more than 500 vehicles annually in the
United States; (ii) manufacturers of child restraint systems; and (iii) tire manufacturers (“Group 1”) to
provide, among other reporting obligations, quarterly reports to NHTSA of death and injury claims


-----

and notices and the numbers of warranty claims, consumer complaints, property damage claims and
field reports received by those manufacturers about all motor vehicles and tires sold by them in the
ten years prior to the report. NHTSA requires manufacturers who sell less than 500 vehicles annually
in the United States as well as all vehicle equipment manufacturers other than of tires and child
restraint systems (“Group 2”), including us, to comply with more limited reporting obligations,
including a requirement (i) to report all fatal accidents occurring inside the United States where the
fatal consequences have been caused by the manufacturer’s vehicle parts or components and (ii) to
report all fatal accidents outside the United States where the fatal consequences have been caused
by the manufacturer’s vehicle parts or components and these vehicle parts or components, or vehicle
parts or components with equivalent technical content, have been marketed inside the United
States. These rules were adopted in 2002. With the recent passage of the Bipartisan Infrastructure
Law (Public Law 117-58), Section 30118 of 49 U.S. Code has been amended to include two new
reporting requirements. Quarterly completion reports are now required for eight consecutive
quarters instead of the previous requirement of six quarters. Also, annual completion reports are
now required for each of the three years beginning after the date of completion of the eighth
quarterly report.

The TREAD Act also required NHTSA to adopt new standards improving the safety performance of
passenger vehicle tires in several critical areas. As a result of this latter mandate, in 2003, NHTSA
issued a final rule to improve tire safety, concentrating particularly on tire endurance and speed
performance to reduce failure. The TREAD Act also required NHTSA to adopt new standards related
to tire pressure monitoring systems, which has been accomplished. All new light duty vehicles sold in
the United States must be equipped with tire pressure monitoring systems that comply with the new
NHTSA standard.

In 2018, the SELF DRIVE Act was passed in the U.S. House of Representatives to encourage testing
and implementation of “highly automated vehicles” (“HAVs”) and vehicles equipped with automated
driving systems (“ADS”), and a similar bill was introduced in the U.S. Senate. This proposed legislation
would have directed federal rulemaking requiring manufacturers introducing HAV or ADS-equipped
vehicles to provide the U.S. Department of Transportation with a safety evaluation report describing
manufacturer efforts to comply with vehicle safety requirements. While the SELF DRIVE Act did not
become law, it has been reintroduced into the current Congress as recently as September 2020, and
a majority of states have enacted autonomous vehicle legislation and/or adopted executive orders on
self-driving vehicles.

In 2018, NHTSA updated guidelines for the testing and deployment of ADS, providing additional
clarity and alignment with OEM requests, including the announcement of a possible pilot program to
encourage public road testing of vehicles equipped with ADS.

In December 2016, NHTSA published FMVSS No. 141, which requires hybrid and electric vehicles to
meet minimum sound standards to make pedestrians more aware of approaching vehicles. Among
NHTSA’s other stated vehicle safety objectives for the near future from its June 2015 Priority Plan for
Vehicle Safety and Fuel Economy are research and potential rule-making on advanced technologies
for fuel economy, collision avoidance, automatic braking, vehicle communications, lane departure
prevention, blind spot and pedestrian detection, as well as additional occupant protection measures.

There are also U.S. state laws dealing with product safety and liability that apply to vehicles and
vehicle parts. The exact standards can differ across state jurisdictions.

Finally, in recent years NHTSA has approached the issue of cybersecurity with respect to over-the-air
software updates (“OTAs”) with increased scrutiny. Though there are currently no regulations in
place controlling their use or imposing vehicle standards, NHTSA has published guidance related to
best practices in automotive cybersecurity, and recently criticized one manufacturer for failing to
notify NHTSA of a safety issue when it issued an OTA to rectify a design flaw. Thus it is possible
NHTSA will consider imposing restrictions or rules on OTA cybersecurity in the near future.
