**_Aviation Equipment Standards_**

The Federal Aviation Administration (“FAA”) issues and enforces regulations and minimum standards
covering manufacturing, operating and maintaining aircraft. Among other key roles with respect to
regulating civil, commercial and military aviation, the FAA is charged with ensuring the safety and
environmental acceptability of U.S.-registered civil aircraft operating in air commerce as well as
airworthiness certification or acceptance of civil aeronautical products imported into the United
States.

The FAA prescribes and periodically revises minimum standards of safety for appliances and for the
design, material, construction, quality of work, and performance of aircraft, aircraft engines and
propellers.

We currently maintain Air Agency Certificates issued by the FAA for operation of approved repair
stations, pursuant to Part 145 of Title 14 of the Code of Federal Regulations (“CFR”), a Parts
Manufacturer Approval issued by the FAA pursuant to Part 21.303 of Title 14 of the CFR, and a
Bilateral Aviation Safety Agreement between the United States and the European Community on
Cooperation in the Regulation of Civil Aviation Safety.

### Regulatory Framework for our Products in China 

**_Product Safety and Liability_**

_General Rules on Product Safety and Liability_

We have to comply with requirements on product safety stipulated in the Product Quality Law of
China and Law of Protection of Consumer Rights and Interests, promulgated by the Standing
Committee of the National People’s Congress of China on July 8, 2000 (latest amended on December
29, 2018) and October 25, 2013, respectively, and the Civil Code of China promulgated by the
National People’s Congress of China on May 28, 2020, respectively.

Under the said laws, the quality of a product shall: (i) be free from unreasonable dangers to the
personal or property safety, and conform to the national or sector standards for safeguarding the
health and personal or property safety if such standards are available; (ii) possess the properties and
functions for use that they ought to possess, except for those with directions stating the defects in
the functions of the product; and (iii) conform to the product standards marked on the product or on
the package thereof, and to the quality conditions indicated by way of product directions and
physical sample.

If the defect of a product causes personal injury or damage to another’s property, then the victim
may hold either the seller or the producer liable for such damage, although the party that pays a
claim for liability may ultimately seek indemnification from the other party, depending on who is
found to be at fault. In addition, any producer or seller of products not up to the relevant standards
for ensuring human health, personal safety and safety of property will be subject to fines of a
maximum amount of three times the value of the products illegally produced and other punitive
measures.

_Recall of Defective Automobile Products_

The State Council of China released the Administrative Regulations for Recalls of Defective
Automobile Products (the “Chinese **Recall Regulation”) on October 22, 2012, (amended on March 2,**
2019) which requires us to recall any defective products as defined by the administrative rules and
regulations. The Chinese Recall Regulation covers the initiation, implementation and reporting
procedures for recalls of the defective product. On January 17, 2013, the State Administration of
Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine (the “AQSIQ”), a predecessor of the State


-----

Administration for Market Regulation (“SAMR”), issued the Opinions on General Administration of
Quality Supervision, Inspection and Quarantine Regarding Several Issues Concerning Implementation
of Chinese Recall Regulations (the “AQSIQ Opinion”). The AQSIQ Opinion elaborates that the defects
that subject the products to recall procedure are those resulting from design, manufacturing, labeling
or other reasons, common to the same batch, model or type of automobiles, and posing risks to
personal or property safety.

As soon as a defect is confirmed, the producer of the product in question must cease production,
distribution, sale and/or import and export of the defective products and must recall those that are
in the market. If a producer fails to do so, the product quality control administration of the State
Council of China has the power to order the producer who fails to comply with the recall procedure
to carry out the recall. Upon receiving such order, the producer must take immediate measures
including correction or supplementation of marks, repair, replacement, or return of products towards
eliminating all defects. The producer must also bear all expenses incurred in eliminating the defects
and in shipping/delivering the defective products. If a producer of defective products remains not to
comply with the Chinese Recall Regulations, the producer is subject to administrative fines of a
maximum amount of Chinese renminbi 1 million or 10% of the total value of defective products. In
addition, the Producer may face punitive administrative actions including forfeiture of illegal
proceeds (if any) and revoking its regulatory permits and business licenses.

AQSIQ promulgated the Measures for Implementing the Chinese Recall Regulations (the “Chinese
**Implementing Measures”) on November 27, 2015 (amended on October 23, 2020), which imposes**
explicit responsibilities on the producers of automotive parts and components, including notifying
China authorities and relevant car makers in case of potential safety defects on products. In the
event of any administrative investigation against defective products, SAMR has the power to enter
the premises of any automotive parts and components producers, automobile producers and
operators, to conduct onsite searches, to review and duplicate relevant materials and records, and to
question any entity or individual about possible defects of automobiles. Automotive parts and
component producers who do not cooperate in these procedures are subject to administrative fines
of a maximum amount of Chinese renminbi 30,000.

In addition, if the administrative authority suspects that a perpetrator who violates the Chinese
Recall Regulation or the Chinese Implementing Measures may have committed crime, the authority
may report the case to criminal prosecution in accordance with the criminal law.

On July 1, 2021, the GB/T 39603-2020 was introduced based on the rules given in GB/T 1.1-2009. This
standard was proposed and governed by the National Standardization Technical Committee for
Product Defects and Safety Management (SAC/TC 463) and describes the guidelines for the recall
effectiveness evaluation of defective motor vehicle products.

SAMR promulgated the Notice on Further Strengthening Supervision of Automobile Remote Upgrade
(OTA) Technology Recall (the “OTA Recall Notice”) on November 23, 2020 (supplemented on June 4,
2021). Under the OTA Recall Notice, if an auto parts or components manufacturer is aware of any
automobile producer who uses OTA to conceal vehicle defects and to avoid its recall responsibilities,
the auto parts or components manufacturer may directly report to SAMR.

SAMR and the Ministry of Ecological Environment promulgated the Administrative Provisions on
Emissions-related Recalls of Motor Vehicles (the “Provisions”) on April 27, 2021. Under the
Provisions, if there is prevailing non-compliance with the national standards for the emission of air
pollutants in the same batch, model or category of motor vehicles due to defects in design or
production or non-compliance with specific requirements for durability in environmental protection,
the manufacturer shall recall the vehicle, and a failure to do so will be subject to a fine of no more
than Chinese renminbi 30,000.


-----

_Chinese Three Guarantees of Automobiles and Related Parts_

On July 22, 2021, SAMR promulgated the Regulations on Liability for Repair, Replacement and Return
of Household Automotive Products (the “China Household Automobile Guarantee Regulations”).

Under the China Household Automobile Guarantee Regulations, consumers are entitled to request
for repair, replacement and return (“Chinese Three Guarantees”) of automobiles and their related
parts within certain periods. The sellers of automobiles must assume liability for the Chinese Three
Guarantees. If the liability is attributable to the producer or other business operators, the sellers are
entitled to reimbursement by the latter.

If within the earlier of (i) 60 days after the sale and delivery (whichever is later) of an automobile or
(ii) 3,000 kilometer of traveled mileage of an automobile, it is determined that a major part of the
engine, gearbox, power storage battery or driving motor has quality problems, then the consumer
may choose to replace the engine, gearbox, power storage battery or driving motor for free based on
the Three-Guarantees certificate. In the event that the consumable spare parts of the household
vehicle products are found to have defects within the quality assurance period, the interested
consumers may choose to replace such spare parts for free. Categories of the consumable spare
parts and their quality assurance periods shall be explicitly indicated by the manufacturer in a
Chinese Three Guarantees certificate.

Any party who breaches the China Household Automobile Guarantee Regulations could be subject to
fines of a maximum amount of Chinese renminbi 30,000.

_Remanufacturing of Automobile Parts_

On April 14, 2021, National Development and Reform Commission and other ministries of China
promulgated Interim Measures for Standardized Administration of the Remanufacturing of
Automobile Parts and Components (the “Measures for Remanufacturing”) to promote sustainable
economy. “Remanufacturing” as mentioned in Measures for Remanufacturing refers to the process
of professionally repairing or upgrading the used automobile parts and components that are no
longer used due to functional damage or technical obsolescence to make their quality characteristic,
safety and environmental performance not lower than that of new prototype products.
Remanufacturing enterprises are the subjects responsible for quality of remanufactured products
and shall formulate perfect rules and regulations on remanufacturing quality control and quality
inspection. For the remanufactured products, the quality shall meet the quality standards for new
original products, the safety standards shall not be lower than national requirements for new original
products of motor vehicle components and parts, and the environmental protection performance
shall meet the requirements of relevant national standards.

**_Technical Standards_**

_Compulsory Product Certification and Vehicle Conformity Certification_

According to Provisions on the Administration of Compulsory Product Certification (the “Chinese
**Provisions”) promulgated by the AQSIQ on July 3, 2009 and amended by SAMR on September 29,**
2022, products listed in the official catalog, to be updated from time to time, must pass the
certification process and be affixed with a China Compulsory Certificate (the “CCC”) before delivered
from factories, marketed, imported or used in any commercial activities.

Products with CCC must comply with recall rules as required under the Chinese Provisions where any
producer or seller of a CCC product discovers any potential safety danger in the product produced or
sold, which poses harm to human health or safety.

On August 21, 2014, the Certification and Accreditation Administration (the “Chinese CAA”)
promulgated the Implementation Rules of Compulsory Product Certification (automobile) (amended


-----

and restated on April 16, 2020), under which producers must provide Vehicle Conformity Certificates
for each automobile to prove that it has passed the certification process. On December 16, 2014, the
Chinese CAA promulgated the Catalogue Description and Definition for Compulsory Product
Certification (amended and restated on April 21, 2020), under which automobile as a whole and
several types of automotive components are listed and are therefore required to pass the
certification process to receive a CCC.

A further standard was proposed by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology of the
People’s Republic of China for introduction in 2022 and concerns the technical requirements for the
cyber security of remote maintenance and management systems for electric vehicles. Among other
requirements, this standard requires an on-board unit installed in a vehicle to collect and store
important status parameters of the vehicle and system parts and send them to the platform defined
in GB/T32960.1-2016.

_Cyber Security_

On November 7, 2016, the Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress of China
promulgated the Cyber Security Law (“CSL”). Under the CSL, (i) cyber operators must not collect or
use personal information unless such collection or use are lawful, reasonable and necessary; (ii) cyber
operators must disclose its rules of collection and use of personal information, and the purpose, type
and scope of collection and use of personal information; (iii) cyber operators must obtain the
individual’s consent before the collection and use of such individual’s personal information; (iv) cyber
operators must not collect personal information which has no relation to the service provided by
such cyber operator; (v) cyber operators must not disclose any individual’s personal information to
any third party without such individual’s prior consent.

_Data Security_

On June 10, 2021, the Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress of China promulgated
the Data Security Law (“DSL”). Under the DSL, a data processor (i) has the duty to ensure data
security, (ii) must carry out a risk assessment and file a risk report when processing important data,
and (iii) must not collect information unless through a legitimate and reasonable way.

_Automotive Data Security Management_

On August 16, 2021, the Cyberspace Administration of China (the “CAC”) and other ministries
promulgated the Provisions on Automotive Data Security Management (for Trial Implementation)
(the “ADSM Provisions”), which requires entities (including auto parts and software suppliers) that
carry out automotive data processing businesses (the “Automotive Data Processors”) to comply with
certain rules during the processing of automotive data. Under the ADSM Provisions, (i) processing of
automotive data by Automotive Data Processors must be carried out in a lawful, reasonable, specific
and clear way, and in a way directly related to the design, production, sale, use, operation and
maintenance of automobiles; (ii) the Automotive Data Processor must inform, in a manifest way, the
individual of the matters that require the processing of such individual’s personal information
(including but not limited to the type of the processed information, the information selection method
and the purpose of the processing) in advance; (iii) before processing any personal information, the
Automotive Data Processor must obtain consent of the individual; (iv) processing of any sensitive
personal information (including but not limited to videos, pictures, tracks and biometrics) must
comply with stricter rules; (v) the Automotive Data Processor must conduct a risk assessment and file
a risk assessment report when processing important data that may endanger national security, public
interests or personal legitimate interests (the “Important Data”); (vi) Important Data must be stored
within the territory of China and must not be provided overseas before passing a mandatory security
assessment organized by CAC; and (vii) if the Automotive Data Processor processes any Important
Data, it must report on the status of its security management of the automotive data to the relevant
authority before December 15th on an annual basis.


-----

Violation of the CSL, DSL or ADSM Provisions will subject the perpetrator processor to fines of a
maximum amount of ten times the value of the unlawful gains or Chinese renminbi 1,000,000 (if no
unlawful gains), and the key personnel will be subject to fines of a maximum amount of Chinese
renminbi 100,000. In the event of serious violation, the perpetrator processor will be subject to
suspension of business or cancellation of business license.

**_Environment Protection_**

_Combustion Fuel Consumption Rate Evaluation and Measuring Method_

Under the Law of Prevention and Control of Atmospheric Pollution, promulgated by Standing
Committee of the National People’s Congress of China on August 29, 2015 (amended on October
26, 2018), no vehicles shall be permitted to discharge atmospheric pollutants in excess of the
prescribed discharge standards. No business entity or individual may manufacture, sell or import
vehicles that discharge pollutants in excess of the prescribed standards. China’s Ministry of Ecology
and Environment (the “Chinese MEE”) has the authority to apply automobile fuel economy level
certificate to automobiles which satisfy different national fuel economy standards. Accordingly,
China’s Ministry of Environmental Protection, the predecessor of Chinese MEE promulgated national
fuel economy standards including Limits and Measurement Methods of Light Vehicle Emission (China
Stage VI) (GB18352.6-2016), Limits and Measurement Methods of Light Vehicle Emission (China Stage
V) (GB18352.5-2013), Limits and Measurement Methods of Light Vehicle Emission (China Stage III/IV)
(GB18352.3-2005), Limits and Measurement Methods of Engine (Automotive Compression Ignition
Style and Fuel Gas Spark Ignition Style), Automobile Pollutant Emission (China Stage III/IV/V)
(GB17691-2005). Under the standard Limits and Measurement Methods of Light Vehicle Emission
(China Stage VI) (GB18352.6-2016), a valid and applicable standard in China, (i) all light-duty vehicles
sold and registered for road operation from July 1, 2020 must comply with the requirements of
(GB18352.6-2016), and the type I test must comply with the requirements of stage 6a limits; (ii) all
light-duty vehicles sold and registered for road operation from July 1, 2023, must comply with the
requirements of (GB18352.6-2016), and the type I test must comply with the requirements of stage
6b limits, which are stricter than those of the 6a limits.

Automobile OEMs and importers are required to disclose to the public (including but not limited to
uploading information to a website of Chinese MEE) the environmental information regarding the
relevant vehicles manufactured or imported by them, such as emission testing information and
pollution control technical information.

**_Industry Development Planning for “Green Vehicles”_**

In recent years, the development of “green vehicles” (i.e., energy-efficient and new-energy vehicles)
is strongly promoted in China. According to the Industry Development Planning for Energy-efficient
and New-energy Vehicle (2021-2035) (Guo Fa 2020 No.39), promulgated by the State Council of
China on October 20, 2020, the government promotes the high-quality development of new energy
automobile industry and accelerates the development of China into a powerful automobile country.

_New-energy Vehicles_

Under the Provisions for the Administration of Entry of New-energy vehicle Manufacturers and Their
Products, promulgated by China’s Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (the “Chinese
**MIIT”) on January 6, 2017 (amended and restated on July 24, 2020), “new-energy vehicle” means**
vehicles using new types of power systems, entirely or mainly relying on new-energy as their driving
force, including plug-in hybrid (including extended-range) vehicles, pure electric vehicles, and fuel cell
vehicles.

According to Guiding Opinions of the General Office of the State Council of China on Accelerating the
Popularization and Application of Alternative Fuel Vehicles promulgated by General Office of the


-----

State Council of China on July 14, 2014, the government will establish policy regimes including
government subsidies, preferential tax treatment etc. to support and promote the development of
alternative fuel vehicles.

_Corporate Average Fuel Consumption (the “CAFC”) credits (the “CAFC Credits”) and New-energy_
_Vehicles credits (the “NEV Credits”)_

In order to further promote the development of energy-efficient and new-energy vehicles, the
Chinese MIIT promulgated the Parallel Management Method of Corporate Average Fuel
Consumption and New-energy Vehicles Credits of Passenger Car Enterprises on September 27, 2017,
and the Decision of Revising Chinese CAFC and NEV Credit Management Method on June 15, 2020
(collectively, the “CAFC and NEV Credit Requirements”), which set out the requirements of CAFC
Credits and NEV Credits for passenger car enterprises.

According to the CAFC and NEV Credit Requirements, the required target CAFC Credits of a passenger
car enterprise refers to the target value of the CAFC and the CAFC requirement of the enterprise in
an accounting year in question.

The target value of the CAFC and the relevant value of CAFC requirements are set out in Fuel
Consumption Evaluation Methods and Targets for Passenger Cars (GB 27999–2019), promulgated by
SAMR and effective from January 1, 2021. The required target NEV Credits of a passenger car
enterprise refers to the production or importation volume of traditional energy passenger vehicles
and the proportion requirements of new-energy vehicles of the enterprise in an accounting year. For
passenger car enterprises whose annual production or importation volume of traditional energy
passenger vehicles is more than 30,000 vehicles, the proportion requirement of NEV Credits for 2019,
2020, 2021, 2022 and 2023 is 10%, 12%, 14%, 16% and 18%, respectively.

Any passenger car enterprise that does not comply with the Chinese CAFC and NEV Credit
Requirements may not be listed in Announcement of Road Motor Vehicle Manufacturers and
Products (published by Chinese MIIT) or obtain CCCs and may be subject to penalties.

### Export Control Regulations and Economic Sanctions 

We manufacture products (e.g., bearings and power transmission) which may be subject to
restrictions under EU, U.S. and other applicable export control regulations. In addition, applicable
economic sanctions regulations may generally restrict us from engaging in business in or with
designated countries, entities or individuals.

In terms of export controls, we manufacture, to a limited extent, products subject to dual-use
controls (e.g., EU Dual-Use, U.S. Export Administration Regulations). Regulation (EU) 2021/821 of
May 21, 2021 (the “Dual Use Regulation”) entered into force on September 9, 2021 and repealed
Council Regulation (EU) 428/2009 of May 5, 2009 (last amended by Regulation (EU) 2021/821 of June
8, 2021). The Dual Use Regulation sets forth an EU-wide regime for the control of exports and
transfer, brokering and transit of dual-use items. Annex I of this Regulation includes a comprehensive
list of dual-use goods which contain, for example, specific bearings and production machines. The
export of such items to destinations outside the EU requires a license. The competent national
authority may exercise a certain degree of discretion as regards the granting of such license.

In addition, some of our products are destined for military applications subject to national military
goods controls (e.g., Munitions List of the Export List of the German Foreign Trade and Payments
Ordinance (Außenwirtschaftsverordnung), United States Munitions List of the International Traffic in
Arms (ITAR) regulations). We therefore have to observe the applicable export control regulations of
the relevant country of development and manufacturing and the relevant country of dispatch. Such
deliveries also require licenses for exports to destinations within and outside the EU. Applicable


-----

export control regulations may limit or prohibit the export of such products if specific countries,
entities, individuals or end-users are the destination of such shipments or other transfers.

Furthermore, export control regulations and economic sanctions of specific countries may have an
impact on our customer or supplier relationships even if these relationships do not relate directly to
such countries. These regulations and economic sanctions may apply to any of our products that are
exported, re-exported or made available in a country where such regulations apply, or to our
operations in countries where such economic sanctions are applicable.

We have an Export Compliance Management system with procedures, systems and other measures
(e.g. an automated IT-based monitoring system) in place to ensure compliance with applicable export
control laws and regulations and economic sanctions. Relevant transactions are generally reviewed
and authorized or denied, as the case may be, in line with applicable regulations. If required,
necessary licenses are obtained before conducting such transactions.

Due to the Cuban Asset Control Regulations (CACR) and a change in the Iran Transaction Sanction
Regulation (ITSR) in 2012, we are subject to the prohibitions of so-called primary economic sanctions
pursuant to the CACR and the ITSR as a result our ownership structure. In 2015, we discovered that
some of our subsidiaries had made some limited sales into Iran and some of our distributors may
have supplied Schaeffler products to Cuba, which may not have been in full compliance with
sanctions administered by the U.S. Department of the Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control
(“OFAC”). Upon discovery of these potential violations, we undertook remedial actions to help
ensure compliance with applicable sanctions laws, including discontinuing all sales into Iran, and
voluntarily reported these incidents to OFAC. OFAC closed the matter with no enforcement actions
by issuing a Cautionary Letter only. Following the lifting of a number of economic sanctions and
export controls targeting Iran in January 2016, we recommenced limited sales into Iran in compliance
with applicable economic sanctions programs (e.g. General License H), taking into account the U.S.
ownership of the Schaeffler Group. As of November 5, 2018, a broad range of U.S. economic
sanctions and export controls targeting Iran have been re-imposed by the United States. Thus, we
discontinued our activities in Iran again as of November 5, 2018. In 2019, shortly after we completed
an acquisition, we discovered that the acquired entity may not have been in full compliance with
certain Iran-related sanctions administered by OFAC. Upon discovery of these potential violations, we
undertook remedial actions to help ensure compliance with applicable sanctions laws and voluntarily
reported these incidents to OFAC. OFAC closed the matter with no enforcement actions by issuing a
Cautionary Letter only. See “Risk Factors—Legal, Regulatory and Tax Risks—Our compliance
_management system may fail to prevent or detect corruption, fraud, money laundering, other_
_criminal or unauthorized behavior or violations of trade and economic sanctions rules.”_

In 2022 and 2023, in response to the war in Ukraine the EU, the U.S. and the UK, among others, have
adopted a series of economic sanctions and export controls, which restrict, in particular, a wide range
of trade and financial dealings with Russia and certain Russian persons, some of which have been
extended to Belarus, and could be extended to additional countries and persons. In addition, Russia
has adopted countermeasures and countersanctions and could adopt additional countermeasures, as
could other countries such as Belarus. We generated (i) 0.9%, 0.9% and 0.2% of our revenues in
Russia in 2020, 2021 and 2022, respectively, (ii) 0.1%, 0.1% and 0.01% of our revenues in Belarus in
2020, 2021 and 2022, respectively, and (iii) 0.2%, 0.2% and 0.1% of our revenues in Ukraine in 2020,
2021 and 2022, respectively. We reduced production at our plant in Ulyanovsk, Russia (98 employees
in Russia) to the minimum possible in order to continue to meet our contractual delivery obligations,
and ceased the operations of our Automotive Aftermarket and Industrial Divisions in Russia. We had
also sourced certain raw materials, such as steel, from sources in Russia, which we discontinued after
the outbreak of the war, and had utilized shipping routes between Europe and China that crossed
through Russia, which we have re-routed. In addition, we entered into an agreement for the sale of
our two Russian subsidiaries, which is subject to approval by the Russian authorities. In Ukraine,
though our sales office in Kyiv (six employees in Ukraine) was initially closed, our operations in


-----

Ukraine have resumed. These economic sanctions and export controls (including the
countermeasures and countersanctions) are rapidly evolving and increasingly severe. We have
procedures, systems, and other measures in place to ensure compliance and we are monitoring the
developments closely, with particular attention to additional economic sanctions. If we identify a
business partner is subject to sanctions prohibitions, we will stop any restricted activities
immediately. See “Risk Factors—Legal, Regulatory and Tax Risks—Our compliance management
_system may fail to prevent or detect corruption, fraud, money laundering, other criminal or_
_unauthorized behavior or violations of trade and economic sanctions rules.”_

### Laws on State Aid 

Within the EU, state aid may be granted by the EU, the EU member states or through state resources
in various forms, including subsidies, loans or guarantees at favorable conditions, or infrastructure
measures realized specifically for one company. Pursuant to Article 107 of the Treaty on the
Functioning of the EU (“TFEU”), aid granted by a member state or aid granted through state
resources, in any form whatsoever, that distorts or threatens to distort competition by favoring
certain businesses or manufacturing sectors, is incompatible with the internal market of the EU
insofar as it affects trade between member states save as otherwise provided in the TFEU.

The EU Commission verifies on an ongoing basis whether EU member states are in compliance with
the existing rules on state aid (e.g., on the basis of notifications required by Article 108 of the TFEU
prior to granting state aid). If the EU Commission classifies a state aid scheme or single state aid
measure as prohibited aid, it may order that various measures be taken by the EU member state
concerned. In particular, the EU Commission could require the aid to be clawed back. In this case, the
aid beneficiary will be obliged to return or refund any payments received to the institution that
granted the aid. If the prohibited aid was granted under ongoing contracts, the beneficiary will have
to repay the subsidy equivalent (i.e., the difference between the fair market price of the performance
and the aid granted) or, in certain circumstances, the respective contracts will have to be rescinded.
Rescission could entail the premature termination of important contracts. Depending on the law of
the relevant EU member state (e.g., Germany), if the EU Commission has not been notified in
advance regarding a contract that entails state aid, such contract may be considered, in a worst case
scenario, null and void.

A part of our investment requirements for developing and expanding our production capacity is
covered by state aid, such as subsidies, loans at favorable conditions or tax reductions or exemptions.
The respective decisions on granting public aid received by us contain various ancillary provisions,
_e.g., regarding the creation of jobs or specific R&D activities. Concerning R&D activities, the EU_
Commission has published a Communication (Communication from the EU Commission, OJ 2014 C
198/1, June 27, 2014), generally lowering barriers for the public support of such activities. In case of a
breach of the ancillary provisions set out in the decision of the institution granting the state aid, the
aid may be clawed back by the institution that granted the aid.

### Management of Schaeffler AG

Schaeffler AG’s governing bodies are the Board of Managing Directors, the Supervisory Board and the
annual general meeting of shareholders. The powers and responsibilities of these governing bodies
are governed by the German Stock Corporation Act (Aktiengesetz), the Articles of Association and the
bylaws of the Board of Managing Directors and the Supervisory Board.


-----

**_Board of Managing Directors_**

The Board of Managing Directors manages Schaeffler AG’s business in accordance with the law, the
Articles of Association and the bylaws of the Board of Managing Directors and the Supervisory Board,
taking into account the resolutions of the shareholders’ meeting. The Board of Managing Directors
represents Schaeffler AG in its dealings with third parties. The Board of Managing Directors is
required to implement and maintain appropriate risk management and risk controlling measures,
including setting up a monitoring system in order to ensure that any developments that could
potentially endanger the continued existence of Schaeffler AG can be identified early. In addition, the
Board of Managing Directors must report regularly to the Supervisory Board on the performance and
the operations of Schaeffler AG. The Board of Managing Directors is also required to present to the
Supervisory Board for its approval, no later than at the last Supervisory Board meeting of each fiscal
year, certain business planning matters (including financial investment and personnel planning) for
the following fiscal year.

The Supervisory Board advises the Board of Managing Directors in the management of Schaeffler AG
and monitors its management activities. The Board of Managing Directors may not transfer
management tasks to the Supervisory Board. However, pursuant to the Articles of Association in
combination with the bylaws of the Supervisory Board, the Board of Managing Directors must obtain
the consent of the Supervisory Board for certain transactions or actions, including transactions or
actions that involve fundamental changes to Schaeffler AG’s net assets, financial position or results
from operation.

The Supervisory Board appoints the members of the Board of Managing Directors and has the right
to remove them for good cause. Simultaneous membership on the Board of Managing Directors and
the Supervisory Board is prohibited.

The members of the Board of Managing Directors and the Supervisory Board owe duties of loyalty
and due care to Schaeffler AG. In discharging these duties, the members of the governing bodies are
required to take into account a broad range of interests, including those of Schaeffler AG, its
shareholders, its employees and its creditors. The Board of Managing Directors must also take into
account the rights of shareholders to equal treatment and equal information. If the members of the
Board of Managing Directors or the Supervisory Board fail to discharge their duties, they are jointly
and severally liable to Schaeffler AG for damages.

A D&O insurance policy, which provides for a deductible for the members of the Board of Managing
Directors and the Supervisory Board, protects the members of the Board of Managing Directors and
Supervisory Board against claims for damages.

The Board of Managing Directors consists of Schaeffler AG’s CEO and the officers heading Schaeffler
AG’s divisions and functions. The Board of Managing Directors is directly responsible for managing
Schaeffler AG, setting objectives and the strategic direction, and managing the implementation of the
strategy.

_Remuneration of the Board of Managing Directors_

Total remuneration of the Board of Managing Directors for 2022, as reported in accordance with IAS
24, amounted to €16 million, including €11 million in short-term benefits, €2 million in postemployment benefits, €1 million in termination benefits and €3 million in share-based payments.

The annual general meeting of Schaeffler AG approved a new compensation system for the members
of the Board of Managing Directors in April 2021 with retroactive effect from January 1, 2021, which
was subsequently adjusted by the annual general meeting in April 2022 with retroactive effect from
January 1, 2022. The remuneration system applies to all members of the Board of Managing
Directors, as well as to new or renewed service contracts with members of the Board of Managing
Directors and reappointments. Compensation paid to the members of the Board of Managing
Directors includes both non-performance-based fixed and performance-based variable components.
The non-performance-related compensation comprises the fixed base salary along with other
remuneration such as retirement benefits and fringe benefits. The performance-based compensation
consists of short-term variable remuneration and long-term variable remuneration based on certain
key performance indicators and performance and strategic targets, in particular, sustainability
targets. The Supervisory Board is also entitled to grant a payment or other benefit to new members
of the Board of Managing Directors in the year of they take office and/or the second year of
appointment. Such payments or other benefits may, for example, compensate for financial
disadvantages suffered by a member of the Board of Managing Directors as a result of moving to
Schaeffler AG from a previous service/employer, for instance, due to forfeited variable remuneration
or disadvantages in connection with a change of location. In addition, in 2020, the members of the
Board of Managing Directors received a one-time payment as part of their variable remuneration to
compensate for the reduction in their retirement benefits resulting from the adoption of the new
compensation system.

**_Supervisory Board_**

Pursuant to the Articles of Association, the German Stock Corporation Act (Aktiengesetz) and the
German Co-Determination Act (Mitbestimmungsgesetz), the Supervisory Board consists of 20
members. Given the number of employees employed by Schaeffler AG and the Schaeffler Group,
Schaeffler AG is subject to statutory co-determination law. In accordance with the German CoDetermination Act (Mitbestimmungsgesetz), ten members are elected by the shareholders and ten
members are elected by the employees. The terms of office of the shareholder representatives and
the employee representatives ends at the conclusion of the annual general meetings in 2024 and
2025, respectively.

The Supervisory Board reaches a quorum if ten members are present. Resolutions of the Supervisory
Board are passed with simple majority, unless otherwise mandated by law. In case of a tied vote, the
chairman of the Supervisory Board shall have the casting vote. This also applies to elections. If the
chairman of the Supervisory Board has not been elected or if he abstains from voting, a tied vote is
deemed to be a rejection of the resolution.

Section 100(5) of the German Stock Corporation Act (Aktiengesetz) requires the Supervisory Board to
have at least one member with expertise in the field of auditing and at least one other member with
expertise in financial reporting. Members of the Supervisory Board are considered to be independent
if such members have no business or personal relations with Schaeffler AG, its Board of Managing
Directors, controlling shareholders or related parties which could cause a substantial and not merely
temporary conflict of interest. As concerns the Supervisory Board, both Robin Stalker and Dr. Holger
Engelmann are considered to possess the required expertise and independence.

_Remuneration of the Supervisory Board_

Remuneration paid to members of the Supervisory Board amounted to €1.8 million during 2022.
There were no provisions for pensions and similar obligations for these persons as of December 31,
2022.

The annual general meeting of Schaeffler AG approved a new compensation system for the members
of the Supervisory Board in April 2021 with retroactive effect from January 1, 2021. The members of
the Supervisory Board receive fixed annual compensation, attendance fees, and reimbursement of
expenses. In addition to the fixed annual compensation, the Chairman and Vice Chairman of the
Supervisory Board as well as the chairmen and members of committees receive additional fixed
annual compensation to reflect the higher time commitment required for those roles.

**_Supervisory Board Committees_**

The Supervisory Board may form committees from among its members and charge them with the
performance of specific tasks. The committees’ tasks, authorizations and processes are determined
by the Supervisory Board. Where permissible by law, important powers of the Supervisory Board may
also be transferred to the committees. The Supervisory Board has established and currently
maintains an executive committee, an audit committee, a mediation committee, a nomination
committee and a technology committee.

_Executive Committee (Präsidialausschuss)_

The executive committee is responsible for preparing the Supervisory Board meetings and decisions
of the Supervisory Board regarding matters relating to the Board of Managing Directors. The
executive committee gives recommendations for the appointment and dismissal of members of the
Board of Managing Directors. Furthermore, its approval is required for the conclusion, amendment or
termination of the employment contracts of members of the Board of Managing Directors. Thus, the
executive committee also acts as Schaeffler AG’s remuneration committee.


-----

The current members of the Supervisory Board’s executive committee are Georg F.W. Schaeffler
(Chairman), Maria-Elisabeth Schaeffler-Thumann, Barbara Resch, Salvatore Vicari, Jürgen Wechsler
and Prof. KR Ing. Siegfried Wolf.

_Audit Committee (Prüfungsausschuss)_

The audit committee’s tasks relate to accounting, the audit of the financial statements, and
compliance. In particular, the committee performs a preliminary examination of the annual financial
statements and makes its recommendation to the plenary session of the Supervisory Board, which
then passes resolutions pursuant to Section 171(1) of the German Stock Corporation Act
(Aktiengesetz). Furthermore, the committee discusses draft condensed financial reports and is
responsible for assuring the necessary independence of auditors, for engaging the auditors, for
determining the focus of the audit as required, and for negotiating the fee.

The current members of the Supervisory Board’s audit committee are Robin Stalker (Chairman),
Georg F.W. Schaeffler, Dr. Holger Engelmann, Andrea Grimm, Thomas Höhn and Jürgen Wechsler.

_Mediation Committee (Vermittlungsausschuss)_

The mediation committee’s task pursuant to the German Co-Determination Act
(Mitbestimmungsgesetz) is to nominate candidates for the Board of Managing Directors in case the
required majority is not reached in the first round of voting. The mediation committee consists of the
chairman of the Supervisory Board and his deputy, as well as one member elected by the
shareholders’ representatives and one member elected by the employees’ representatives.

The current members of the Supervisory Board’s mediation committee are Georg F.W. Schaeffler
(Chairman), Maria-Elisabeth Schaeffler-Thumann, Salvatore Vicari and Jürgen Wechsler.

_Nomination Committee (Nominierungsausschuss)_

The nomination committee, established within the meaning of Section D.5. of the German Corporate
Governance Code, is responsible for proposing suitable candidates to Schaeffler AG’s shareholders’
meeting for election to the Supervisory Board. The nomination committee consists of the chairman
of the Supervisory Board along with three other members of the Supervisory Board. These members
are also shareholder representatives as stipulated by Section D.5. of the German Corporate
Governance Code.

The current members of the Supervisory Board’s nomination committee are Georg F.W. Schaeffler
(Chairman), Maria-Elisabeth Schaeffler-Thumann, Dr. Holger Engelmann and Prof. Dr. Bernd
Gottschalk.

_Technology Committee (Technologieausschuss)_

The Supervisory Board has established a technology committee, which is made up of equal numbers
of employee and shareholder representatives. The technology committee is responsible for the
regular exchange of information between the Supervisory Board and the Board of Managing
Directors on technological developments and for joint deliberations on technology projects.

The current members of the Supervisory Board’s technology committee are Prof. Dr. Hans-Jörg
Bullinger (Chairman), Georg F.W. Schaeffler, Salvatore Vicari, Prof. KR Ing. Siegfried Wolf, Prof. Dr.Ing Tong Zhang, Jürgen Schenk, Jürgen Wechsler and Markus Zirkel.


-----

## Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions 

### Transactions of the Issuer

**_Upstream Loans_**

In September 2016, the Issuer on-lent part of the net proceeds from the issuance of debt securities
(including certain of the Existing Issuer Notes) to IHO Beteiligung under a notes proceeds loan in the
amount of €880 million (as amended from time to time, the “Notes Proceeds Loan”). In March 2020,
the Issuer set-off the obligations of IHO Beteiligung under the Notes Proceeds Loan against a
dividend-in-kind declared by the Issuer for that purpose.

**_Subordinated Shareholder Loan_**

On July 13, 2021, IHO Beteiligung granted a subordinated shareholder loan in the principal amount of
€550 million to the Issuer. The loan matures in May 2030 and accrues interest at a rate of 1% per
annum. At the Issuer’s sole discretion, interest is either payable in cash or capitalized (by increasing
the principal amount of the loan) during the term of the loan. In 2022, the Issuer paid €5 million in
cash interest on the subordinated shareholder loan. As of December 31, 2022, €3 million in interest
had accrued on the subordinated shareholder loan and the Issuer currently expects to pay the
accrued interest in cash on the next interest payment date in May 2023.

**_Atesteo Loan_**

Pursuant to a loan agreement dated February 14, 2018, between the Issuer and Atesteo, the Issuer
has granted the right to Atesteo GmbH & Co. KG, a wholly-owned subsidiary of IHO Holding GmbH &
Co. KG, an indirect shareholder of the Issuer (formerly, Atesteo GmbH, “Atesteo”), a subsidiary of
IHO Holding GmbH & Co. KG, an indirect shareholder of the Issuer, to make drawings on behalf and
for the account of the Issuer of up to €50 million under ancillary facilities to the Issuer’s Revolving
Facility consisting of one or more credit facilities of up to €45 million and, in addition, a surety for a
certain €5 million bilateral credit facility (the “Atesteo Loan”). While the Issuer remains the primary
obligor under such ancillary facilities in respect of any such drawings made by Atesteo, Atesteo
operates the ancillary facilities on behalf and for the account of the Issuer. Under the terms of the
Atesteo Loan, Atesteo is required to reimburse the Issuer for any principal, interest and other
payments (including any commitment fee) to be made by the Issuer to the relevant lender under
such ancillary facilities. As of December 31, 2022, no drawings were made under such ancillary
facilities by Atesteo on behalf of and for the account of the Issuer.

On February 21, 2023, the Issuer entered into a loan and deposit master agreement with Atesteo
North America Inc. (“Atesteo N.A.”), a subsidiary of IHO Beteiligungs GmbH, under which the Issuer
may from time to time grant loans to Atesteo N.A. or Atesteo N.A. may from time to time make
deposits with the Issuer for terms of up to five years, with the specific terms of each loan or deposit
to be agreed on a case-by-case basis. Interest on loans and deposits will be calculated on the basis of
an applicable reference rate, plus (or, in the case of deposits made by Atesteo N.A., minus) a certain
margin. No loans or deposits have been made under the master agreement prior to the date of this
Offering Memorandum.

**_Intercompany Service Agreement_**

In December 2014, the Issuer entered into an intercompany service agreement, as amended from
time to time, with IHO Holding GmbH & Co. KG (previously named Schaeffler Holding GmbH & Co.
KG) pursuant to which IHO Holding GmbH & Co. KG provides certain accounting, tax and reporting
services to the Issuer. Pursuant to this agreement, the Issuer paid fees of €0.3 million in 2020, €0.5
million in 2021 and €0.5 million in 2022.


-----

**_Voting Rights and Share Pooling Agreement_**

On August 26, 2021, the Issuer and IHO Beteiligung entered into a voting rights and share pooling
agreement (the “Issuer Voting Rights and Share Pooling Agreement”) whereby the Issuer and IHO
Beteiligung, as pool members (together, the “Pool Members”), agreed to vote 24.01%, in the case of
the Issuer, and 1.00%, in the case of IHO Beteiligung, of the share capital held in each of Continental
AG and Vitesco AG as a unit. The purpose of the agreement is, inter alia, to pool the Pool Members’
interests and voting rights to secure influence in both Continental AG and Vitesco AG, by way of
consistent exercise of voting rights in annual general meetings and to provide for uniform decisionmaking with respect to any disposals of the pooled shares. Pursuant to the terms of the Issuer Voting
Rights and Share Pooling Agreement, the Pool Members are obliged to ensure that the shares held in
the pool continuously amount to more than 25% of the issued share capital of each of Continental AG
and Vitesco AG. Resolutions in the meeting of the pool members are taken with a simple majority.
Each pooled share of Continental AG and Vitesco AG, respectively, grants one vote in pool meetings.
The pooling agreement has been concluded for an indefinite term. The attribution rules under capital
markets law with regard to the total number of shares held by each of the pool members remain
unaffected.

**_Expense Reimbursement relating to the Offering_**

The Issuer has agreed to reimburse Schaeffler AG for its costs and expenses incurred in connection
with the Offering. We estimate that the reimbursed costs will be less than €1 million.

### Transactions of the Schaeffler Group

For a description of transactions of the Schaeffler Group with related parties, see note 5.4 to the
Audited Consolidated Financial Statements 2022 and note 5.5 to the Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements 2021, each included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**_Cooperation Agreements_**

Pursuant to a cooperation agreement, originally dated March 27, 2009 (as amended from time to
time), Continental AG and Schaeffler Technologies AG & Co. KG, a subsidiary of Schaeffler AG, have
agreed to act as independent entities, but to try to create synergies through a worldwide purchasing
cooperation, (the “Continental Cooperation Agreement”). Similarly, pursuant to a joint procurement
cooperation agreement dated February 16/17, 2022, between Schaeffler AG and Vitesco
Technologies GmbH, a subsidiary of Vitesco AG, the parties have agreed to act as independent
entities, but to try to create synergies through a worldwide purchasing cooperation (the “Vitesco
**Cooperation Agreement”). In addition, pursuant to a triparty purchasing cooperation agreement**
dated October 27, 2022 (the “Triparty Purchasing Cooperation Agreement”) and a joint
procurement agreement for non-production material dated February 21, 2023 (the “Triparty
**Procurement Cooperation Agreement” and, together with the Triparty Purchasing Cooperation**
Agreement, the “Triparty Cooperation Agreements” and, together with the Continental Cooperation
Agreement, and the Vitesco Cooperation Agreement, the “Cooperation Agreements”), Continental
AG, Vitesco Technologies GmbH, a subsidiary of Vitesco AG and Schaeffler AG, have agreed to
combine the purchasing volume of all three companies in certain sourcing negotiations. The
Continental Cooperation Agreement and the Vitesco Cooperation Agreement remain applicable for
purchases outside the scope of the Triparty Cooperation Agreements.

The purpose of each of the Cooperation Agreements is to strengthen the market and negotiation
position of the respective parties under each of the Cooperation Agreements by cumulating their
respective purchasing volumes, allowing them to jointly negotiate lower prices and to achieve
advantageous conditions, including procuring higher quality and higher performance from suppliers.


-----

However, the actual purchase of the mutually sourced products is conducted independently by each
of the respective parties under the relevant agreement and for the respective party’s own account.

The Triparty Purchasing Cooperation Agreement has an initial term of 24 months and the Triparty
Procurement Cooperation Agreement has an initial term of twelve months. Each Cooperation
Agreement will be renewed automatically for consecutive twelve month periods unless cancelled by
written notice prior to the end of the respective term.

**_Interest-bearing loans_**

With respect to a convertible loan receivable from a joint venture we recorded an impairment of €22
million in 2020 and €0.6 million in 2021. In 2022, we sold the convertible loan receivable and
recognized a gain of €3 million for the impairment reversal.

**_Disposal of Business in Russia_**

On December 29, 2022, we signed an agreement to sell our two Russian subsidiaries,
Schaeffler RUS OOO and Schaeffler Russland OOO, to PromAvtoConsult LLC for a purchase price of
€10 million. In accordance with the terms of the sale agreement, the shares in PromAvtoConsult LLC
will be transferred to a company controlled by a member of the Supervisory Board of Schaeffler AG.
The closing of the transaction is subject the approval of Russian authorities. Russian law requires,
among others, that when share interests in Russian entities are sold, either (i) the purchase price is
made in installments over one to two years or (ii) 10% of the deal value is ‘voluntarily’ contributed to
the Russian government. In light of this requirement, we are currently negotiating with the purchaser
regarding a possible deferral of the purchase price payment. However, even if the transaction
complies with the relevant Russian legal requirements, there can be no assurance that the
transaction will be completed or that the Russian authorities will not impose additional
requirements.

## General Information on the Issuer

### Formation, Incorporation, Trade Name and Registered Office

IHO Verwaltungs GmbH, a limited liability company (Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung)
organized under the laws of Germany, was formed on September 29, 2009 and is registered in the
Commercial Register of the Fürth Local Court (Amtsgericht) under HRB 14734. The Issuer’s registered
office is located at Industriestrasse 1-3, 91074 Herzogenaurach, Germany.

### Share Capital 

The issued capital of the Issuer amounts to €500,025,000 divided into 500,025,000 shares with a
nominal value of €1.00 each, all of which are fully paid up. The Issuer is a wholly owned subsidiary of
IHO Beteiligung. As of the Issue Date, all of the Issuer’s subsidiaries, i.e., Schaeffler AG and its
subsidiaries, will be Unrestricted Subsidiaries (as defined in the Indenture) of the Issuer. As a result,
Schaeffler AG and its subsidiaries or any future subsidiaries that are designated as Unrestricted
Subsidiaries will not be subject to the restrictive covenants in the Indenture, will not guarantee the
Notes and will not provide any collateral securing the Notes.

### Corporate Purpose 

Pursuant to Section 2 of the Issuer’s Articles of Association, the Issuer is a management holding
company which pools other companies under a uniform leadership and provides corresponding
services, including management services. The Issuer may set up subsidiaries and may incorporate,
form or acquire other companies.

The Issuer is a holding and finance company and does not hold any material assets other than 75.1%
of the issued share capital of Schaeffler AG, 36.0% of the issued share capital of Continental AG,
39.9% of the issued share capital of Vitesco AG.

### Fiscal Year and Term of the Issuer 

The duration of the Issuer is perpetual. Pursuant to Section 5 of the Issuer’s Articles of Association,
the fiscal year of the Issuer is the calendar year.

### Financial Statements

The Issuer prepares audited unconsolidated financial statements for each fiscal year. Pursuant to the
HGB, the Issuer is not required to prepare notes to the Issuer Audited Unconsolidated Financial
Statements. The Issuer is not required to produce any consolidated financial statements or any
interim financial statements. Pursuant to section 291 HGB, the Issuer is exempt from consolidating
the financial results of Schaeffler AG due to the fact that the financial results of the Issuer and
Schaeffler AG are consolidated in the financial statements of INA-Holding Schaeffler GmbH & Co. KG,
the ultimate parent company of the Issuer and Schaeffler AG.

### Auditor

The independent auditors of the Issuer for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022 were
KPMG AG Wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft, Bahnhofstrasse 30, 90402 Nuremberg, Germany. KPMG
AG Wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft is a member of the German Chamber of Public Accountants
(Wirtschaftsprüferkammer).

## Description of Other Indebtedness

_The following is a summary of the material terms of the principal financing arrangements of the_
_Issuer and the Schaeffler Group. The following summaries do not purport to describe all of the_
_applicable terms and conditions of such arrangements and are qualified in their entirety by reference_
_to the actual agreements. Unless defined herein, defined terms used in this “Description of Other_
_Indebtedness” have the meanings ascribed to them in the respective agreements described herein._

### Indebtedness of the Issuer 

**_Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement_**

The Issuer, as borrower, entered into a syndicated facilities agreement originally dated September 7,
2016 (as amended or, as the case may be, amended and restated on September 8, 2016, December
22, 2017, June 6, 2019, June 29, 2020 and February 3, 2021 (the “Issuer Revolving Facility
**Amendment Agreement”)) arranged by, among others, Bank of America Europe Designated Activity**
Company, Citibank N.A., London Branch, Citigroup Global Markets Limited, Deutsche Bank AG and
HSBC Bank plc, with Deutsche Bank Luxembourg S.A. as facility agent and Deutsche Bank AG, Filiale
Luxemburg as security trustee (the “Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement”). Pursuant to the terms
and conditions of the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement, the lenders have made available to the
Issuer a €800 million revolving credit facility (the “Issuer Revolving Facility”), which matures on
December 31, 2024. The Issuer Revolving Facility is available for drawings in cash or, up to an
aggregate amount of €50 million, by way of ancillary facilities until one month prior to the final
maturity date. Any commitment undrawn on such dates will be cancelled. As of December 31, 2022,
€160 million was drawn under the Issuer Revolving Facility. Up to €50 million of the Issuer Revolving
Facility are available for drawing, in the form of ancillary facilities, on behalf and for the account of
the Issuer, by Atesteo, which were unutilized as of December 31, 2022. See “Certain Relationships
_and Related Party Transactions—Transactions of the Issuer—Atesteo Loan.”_

_Interest_

The Issuer Revolving Facility bears interest at a rate of EURIBOR (provided that EURIBOR, if below
zero, will be deemed to be zero) plus the applicable margin. The applicable margin is determined by
reference to the leverage ratio in accordance with a margin ratchet mechanism in a range between
1.75% and 4.25% per annum. Accrued interest on the loans drawn under the Issuer Revolving Facility
will be payable in cash on the last day of each interest period but in any event on the date falling at
six-monthly intervals after the first day of the interest period of a loan. The rate and time of payment
of interest, commission, fees and any other remuneration in respect of ancillary facilities to the Issuer
Syndicated Facilities Agreement are agreed between the relevant ancillary lender and the borrower
of the relevant ancillary facility.

_Purpose_

The Issuer Revolving Facility may be used for general corporate purposes of any member of the IHO
Group (consisting of INA-Holding Schaeffler GmbH & Co. KG (“IHO”) and its subsidiaries but excluding
any Designated Non-Issuer Group Entity (as defined below)) or costs and expenses of any Restricted
Person (as defined in the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement) (including the payment of taxes).

The Borrower may also (i) fund any such purpose from sources other than the Issuer Revolving
Facility and apply amounts borrowed by it under the Issuer Revolving Facility towards refinancing of
such funding and/or (ii) for application towards the relevant purpose, where applicable, on-lend,
distribute or otherwise pass on amounts borrowed by it under the Issuer Revolving Facility to IHO
Beteiligungs GmbH (previously named Schaeffler Verwaltungs GmbH), the relevant member of the
IHO Group or, as the case may be, the relevant Restricted Person.


-----

_Repayment_

Each loan made under the Issuer Revolving Facility will be repaid (subject to an ability to roll over
drawings on a cash-less basis) on the last day of the interest period relating thereto and all amounts
outstanding under the Issuer Revolving Facility shall be repaid on the fifth anniversary of the date of
the most recent amendment and restatement agreement to the Issuer Syndicated Facilities
Agreement. Amounts repaid on loans made under the Issuer Revolving Facility may be re-borrowed
during the availability period applicable to it.

_Prepayment and cancellation_

Subject to certain conditions, the Issuer may voluntarily prepay its utilizations and/or permanently
cancel all or part of the available commitments under the Issuer Revolving Facility.

In addition to voluntary prepayments, the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement requires mandatory
prepayment of the loans made available under the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement in full or in
part in certain circumstances, including (i) with respect to any lender (or any holding company of a
lender), in full if it becomes unlawful in any applicable jurisdiction for such lender to perform any of
its obligations under the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement or to fund or maintain its
participation in any loans and (ii) with respect to any lender who so requires, in full following a
specified negotiation period if the Schaeffler Family ceases to own (directly or indirectly) or ceases to
hold (directly or indirectly) the right to exercise in their free discretion more than 50% of the share
capital and voting rights in the Issuer or the Issuer ceases to own (directly or indirectly) more than
50% of the voting shares in Schaeffler AG or otherwise loses control over Schaeffler AG (although
such lender will, at the request of the Issuer, assign at par its commitment and participation in any
facility to another lender willing to accept such assignment, subject to certain conditions).

The Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreements further provides that the Issuer shall apply an amount
equal to the net proceeds (the “Proceeds”) received by (i) any Restricted Person or any member of
the Issuer Group in connection with any direct or indirect sale, transfer or other disposal (whether
voluntary or involuntary, pursuant to a single transaction or a series of related transactions) of shares
in the Issuer and/or shares in Schaeffler AG which are subject to transaction security held by any
member of the Issuer Group (except for any disposal to any member of the Issuer Group) and (ii) a
member of the Issuer Group in connection with the sale, transfer or other disposal (whether
voluntary or involuntary, pursuant to a single transaction or a series of related transactions) of
Restricted Continental Shares or Restricted Continental Spin-Off Shares (each as defined in the Issuer
Syndicated Facilities Agreement and which includes Vitesco AG shares since its spin-off from
Continental AG in September 2021) by any member of the Issuer Group, at its discretion, either (A) in
full towards the cancellation of the Issuer Revolving Facility (and, to the extent necessary,
prepayment of the loans made available thereunder) or (B) towards the cancellation of the Issuer
Revolving Facility (and, to the extent necessary, prepayment of the loans made available thereunder)
and the payment, redemption or voluntary prepayment of any other financial indebtedness of the
Issuer Group which is regulated by the Issuer Group Security Pooling and Intercreditor Agreement
(including under any hedging agreement) pro rata to their respective nominal amounts.

_Security_

The Issuer Revolving Facility is, or as the case may be, will be, secured by security over (i) a certain
number of shares in Continental AG, (ii) a certain number of shares in Vitesco AG and any other
entity resulting from any demerger of business activities from Continental AG to the effect that all
shares in such entity are held by the shareholders of Continental AG and, as applicable, Continental
AG (“Continental Spin-Off”) and (iii) a certain number of shares in Schaeffler AG in accordance with
the terms of the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement.


-----

If Continental AG or, as the case may be, Vitesco AG or any other Continental Spin-Off effects a
capital increase from capital reserves, a share split or any measure having a similar effect, the
number of shares in Continental AG or, as the case may be, Vitesco AG or the relevant Continental
Spin-Off which are required to be pledged as transaction security would increase in proportion to the
increase in the number of outstanding Continental AG shares or, as the case may be, Vitesco AG or
the relevant Continental Spin-Off.

Security over shares in Continental AG, Vitesco AG, any other Continental Spin-Off or Schaeffler AG
securing the Issuer Revolving Facility will be released if the relevant shares are disposed of in
accordance with the terms of the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement (subject to certain
prerequisites as the case may be, including application of the relevant Proceeds in mandatory
prepayment as set out above and provided that the number of shares in Schaeffler AG required to be
pledged as transaction security must not fall below the number of shares in Schaeffler AG which
represents 50% plus one share of each of the voting shares and the share capital of Schaeffler AG at
any time).

_Financial Covenants_

In respect of its financial condition, the Issuer must comply with a leverage financial covenant as set
out in the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement on each specified testing date, being the last date of
the relevant testing period (which is a period of twelve months ending on each of March 31,
June 30, September 30 and December 31 of each year), by reference to the latest financial
statements or management accounts determined (i) on a consolidated basis for Schaeffler AG, (ii) on
an unconsolidated basis or, if it has subsidiaries, on a consolidated basis for any other entity (other
than a Restricted Person) in which a member of the Issuer Group directly holds or acquires more than
50% of the voting rights and share capital (together with Schaeffler AG, the “Majority Owned
**Entities”).**

The Issuer must ensure that the sum of (A) the ratio of the aggregate amount of the total net debt (as
calculated in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement)
on the relevant testing date of all members of the Issuer Group (for the avoidance of doubt, not
taking into account any borrowings of any member of the Schaeffler Group or any other Majority
Owned Entity) to HoldCo Earnings (as defined below) for the 12-month period ending on the relevant
testing date; and (B) the ratio of the aggregate amount of total net debt (as calculated in accordance
with the terms and provisions of the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement) of all Majority Owned
Entities which are not members of Issuer Group to the sum of the EBITDA of all Majority Owned
Entities which are not members of Issuer Group for the 12-month period ending on the relevant
testing date (in each case as calculated in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Issuer
Syndicated Facilities Agreement) (the “Issuer Leverage Ratio”) is not more than 6.50:1 for any testing
date falling on or prior to June 30, 2023, 6.00:1 for any testing date falling on September 30, 2023
and on December 31, 2023, 5.50:1 for any testing date falling on March 31, 2024 and on June 30,
2024 and 5.00:1 for any testing date falling on or after September 30, 2024, where “HoldCo
**Earnings” means, in respect to any relevant 12-month period, the sum of (i) (as the case may be,**
consolidated) EBITDA of all Majority Owned Entities for the relevant Period ending on the relevant
testing date (as calculated in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Issuer Syndicated
Facilities Agreement and on a pro rata basis, i.e., taking into account, for any Majority Owned Entity
which is not directly or indirectly wholly owned by the Issuer, such portion of EBITDA which
proportionally corresponds to the Issuer’s (direct or indirect) shareholding in such Majority Owned
Entity); (ii) dividend income received by any member of the Issuer Group during the relevant 12month period from any entity which does not qualify as a Majority Owned Entity; and (iii) any
interest received by any member of the Issuer Group during the relevant 12-month period from any
cash or cash equivalent investments; while (iv) deducting the sum of certain operational costs
incurred by all members of the Issuer Group during the relevant 12-month period.


-----

_General Covenants_

The Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement contains certain restrictive covenants customary for these
types of financings subject to certain specified exceptions provided for in the Issuer Syndicated
Facilities Agreement in respect of the relevant covenant (customized to the business of the Issuer
Group and adjusted to the current credit standing of the Issuer Group). Such restrictive covenants
(subject to agreed exceptions and qualifications) include, without limitation, restrictions on (i) the
granting of security for financial indebtedness (“negative pledge”), (ii) the disposal of assets
(including shares or interests), (iii) the incurrence of financial indebtedness owing to any member of
the Schaeffler Group in excess of €500 million and any financial indebtedness under any financing
taken out in the national or international loan or debt capital markets which is subject to the Issuer
Security Pooling and Intercreditor Agreement and which benefits from Transaction Security, (iv) the
granting of loans or credits to any third party or Restricted Person, (v) the provision of guarantees,
(vi) mergers and other reorganization measures, (vii) substantial changes to the general nature of the
business of the Issuer Group (taken as a whole), (viii) payments (including dividends and other
distributions) to Restricted Persons, (ix) the entry into enterprise agreements, (x) the entry into
transactions with or for the benefit of any person which is not a member of the Issuer Group other
than on arms’ length (or, from the Issuer’s perspective, better) terms and for fair market value and
(xi) the redemption, repurchase or repayment by the Issuer of its share capital.

Furthermore, the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement requires compliance with certain customary
affirmative covenants (subject to agreed exceptions and qualifications) including, among others, with
relation to (i) required authorizations and consents (including environmental approvals), (ii)
compliance with laws (including environmental laws), (iii) pari passu ranking of unsecured and
unsubordinated debt obligations, (iv) preservation of assets, (v) payment of taxes, (vi) further
assurance, (vii) granting of access, (viii) preservation of holding company status of the Issuer and (ix)
holding of shares in Continental AG, Vitesco AG or in any other Continental Spin-Off and in Schaeffler
AG.

Additionally, the Issuer is obliged to provide certain financial and other information to the lenders
under the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement including, among others, regarding the financial
condition of IHO, Schaeffler AG, the Majority Owned Entities and the Issuer Group.

_Restricted payments and separation of decks_

The Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement generally restricts payments in cash or in kind (including
dividends, other distributions, repayment of shareholder loans, granting of loans, granting of any
guarantee for indebtedness of any Restricted Person or otherwise) by any member of the Issuer
Group and the Schaeffler Group to any Restricted Person, subject to certain exceptions, including for
payments for fair market value under arm’s length transactions with Restricted Persons and further
for specified limited cash amounts which may be distributed or paid to any Restricted Person in any
fiscal year

In addition, the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement provides that no member of the Issuer Group
shall incur or permit to subsist any actual or contingent payment liability to, or in respect of the
obligations of, or enter into any contract or arrangement with, or transfer to or exchange any assets
with, any Restricted Person (including any acts which have the same economic effect as any of the
foregoing), unless otherwise permitted under the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement.

_Designated Non-Issuer Group Entity_

The Issuer may designate any operating Majority Owned Entity (together with any intermediate
holding company newly established or acquired by any member of the Issuer Group for the purposes
of acquiring and/or holding any participation in any such entity) in respect of which the Issuer has
given notice promptly upon the closing of the relevant acquisition that it elects that the relevant


-----

entity or group of entities shall not constitute a member of the Issuer Group for the purposes of the
Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement, and any subsidiary of any entity so designated (“Designated
**Non-Issuer Group Entity”), provided that no borrower or guarantor may be designated as a**
Designated Non-Issuer Group Entity; and no entity holding shares in Schaeffler AG and/or shares in
Continental AG, Vitesco AG or any other Continental Spin-Off (other than shares in Continental AG,
Vitesco AG or any other Continental Spin-Off owned by an entity as at the date on which that entity
(or its holding company) becomes a Majority Owned Entity (as defined in the Issuer Syndicated
Facilities Agreement) and which had not been acquired by that entity (or its holding company) in
contemplation of it (or its holding company) becoming a Majority Owned Entity) may be designated
as a Designated Non-Issuer Group Entity.

_Disposal of shares in Continental AG, Vitesco AG or any other Continental Spin-Off or Schaeffler AG_
_and release of security_

Shares in Continental AG, Vitesco AG or any other Continental Spin-Off which are subject to
transaction security can be disposed of at any time, provided that the disposal is made on arm’s
length and for fair market value and the net proceeds from any such share disposal are used, to the
extent required under the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement, to cancel the Issuer Revolving
Facility and, as the case may be, prepay the loans made available thereunder.

Shares in Continental AG, Vitesco AG or any other Continental Spin-Off which are not subject to
transaction security may be disposed of (i) to any person, any member of the Issuer Group or any
member of the Schaeffler Group if made on arms’ length terms and effected while no event of
default under the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement is continuing, or (ii) to any other member of
the Issuer Group if the relevant entity has become a guarantor under the Issuer Syndicated Facilities
Agreement.

Shares in Schaeffler AG which are subject to transaction security may be disposed of on arm’s length
terms for fair market value, provided that (i) the net proceeds from such disposal are used, to the
extent required under the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement, to cancel the Issuer Revolving
Facility and, as the case may be, prepay the loans made available thereunder and (ii) the number of
shares in Schaeffler AG required to be pledged as transaction security must not fall below the
number of shares in Schaeffler AG which represents 50% plus one share of each of the voting shares
and the share capital of Schaeffler AG at any time.

Shares in Schaeffler AG which are not and which, in accordance with the terms of the Issuer
Syndicated Facilities Agreement, do not have to be subject to transaction security may be disposed of
to any person, any member of the Issuer Group or any member of the Schaeffler Group if made on
arms’ length terms and effected while no event of default under the Issuer Syndicated Facilities
Agreement is continuing.

_Events of Default_

The Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement contains certain customary events of default, the
occurrence of which would allow the majority lenders to direct the agent to cancel the commitments,
declare that all or part of the loans together with accrued interest and all other amounts accrued or
outstanding under the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement or related finance documents be
immediately due and payable.

These events of default, subject to certain agreed grace periods, thresholds, materiality qualifiers and
other exceptions, include, without limitation, (i) failure to make payment of amounts due and
payable in connection with the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement or related finance documents,
(ii) failure to comply with the financial covenant or other obligations, (iii) the making of payments by
a member of the Issuer Group to a Restricted Person which are not permitted pursuant to the terms
of the Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement; (iv) misrepresentation; (v) cross-default with respect to


-----

other financial indebtedness of the Issuer and/or any other member of the Issuer Group, subject to a
threshold of €100 million; (vi) certain insolvency events or proceedings in relation to the Issuer, any
other member of the Issuer Group or Schaeffler AG; (vii) certain creditors’ processes, including
expropriations, attachments or sequestration of assets of any member of the Issuer Group or similar
events subject to a threshold of €25 million; (viii) failure to comply with the provisions of the Issuer
Security Pooling and Intercreditor Agreement by any member of the HoldCo/MidCo Group (meaning
IHO and its subsidiaries other than any member of the Schaeffler Group from time to time);
(ix) material adverse change and (x) qualification of the audit report for the annual audited financial
statements of IHO or the Issuer.

_Governing Law_

The Issuer Syndicated Facilities Agreement and any non-contractual obligations arising out of or in
connection with it are governed by German law.

_Terms and conditions of the Existing Issuer Notes_

The terms and conditions of the Existing Issuer Notes are, except for the maturity and the interest
